(1978 Code § 1-6-7)
1-7-7: DUTIES:
A. Generally: Every village official, besides the powers and duties assigned thereto by statute and ordinance, shall have the further powers and perform
the duties which usually pertain to his office, and shall be subject to such other rules and regulations as the village president and board of trustees may
from time to time establish. (1978 Code § 1-6-8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 18/618
B. Accounting For Monies: Every official or employee of the village who shall collect monies belonging to the village shall, each month or as otherwise
provided by the village president and board of trustees, pay over to the village treasurer such monies, together with an itemized written report covering
his collections for the preceding month. (1978 Code § 1-6-10)
C. Licenses And Permits Issued: All licenses and permits issued by any official pursuant to an ordinance of the village shall be in writing, and duplicates
thereof shall be kept in a permanent file. (1978 Code § 1-6-12)
D. Property To Successor: Any person having been an official of the village shall, within five (5) days after notification and request, deliver to his successor
in office all property, books and effects of every description in his possession belonging to the village and pertaining to his office. (1978 Code § 1-6-11)
1-7-8: COMPENSATION:
A. Established: The salaries of all officials, employees and appointees of the village shall be the amount fixed from time to time by ordinance of the village.
The salaries of the village officials hereinafter designated shall be in the following amounts:
1. Village President: For any village president whose term of office commences on or after April 5, 2005, the president of the village board of trustees
shall receive an annual compensation for the performance of his/her duties in the amount of seven thousand four hundred dollars ($7,400.00).
Further, the village president shall receive the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each meeting he/she attends that is held by a citizen's group, business
organization, developer, municipal organization, other municipal corporations, or any other governmental entity, so long as the meeting is attended
by the village president on behalf of the village and when such meeting pertains to the governmental affairs of the village. The village president shall
submit a voucher to the village confirming his/her meeting attendance prior to receiving any payment.
2. Village Trustee: For any trustee whose term of office commences on or after April 5, 2005, such village trustee shall receive an annual compensation
for the performance of his/her duties in the amount of four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00). Further, each trustee shall receive the sum of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each meeting he/she attends that is held by a citizen's group, business organization, developer, municipal
organization, other municipal corporations, or any other governmental entity, so long as the meeting is attended by the trustee on behalf of the village
and when such meeting pertains to the governmental affairs of the village. The trustee shall submit a voucher to the village confirming his/her
meeting attendance prior to receiving any payment.
3. Village Clerk: For any village clerk whose term of office commences on or after April 13, 1999, such village clerk shall receive an annual
compensation for the performance of his/her duties in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
4. Village Treasurer: The village treasurer shall receive an annual compensation for the performance of his/her duties in the amount of one thousand
five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). In the event the finance director also serves as the village treasurer, the designated salary of the village treasurer
shall not be paid.
5. Village Liquor Control Commissioner: The village liquor control commissioner shall receive an annual compensation of one thousand six hundred
dollars ($1,600.00).
6. Village Emergency Management Agency Coordinator: The village emergency management agency coordinator shall receive an annual
compensation of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
B. Annual Payments: The salaries of the village officials shall be paid annually on May 1 of each year.
C. Reimbursement Of Salaries: In the event the village president, a village trustee, the village clerk, the village treasurer, the village liquor control
commissioner, or the village emergency management agency coordinator cannot fulfill his/her term of office for any reason other than death or serious
illness, then said village official leaving office shall reimburse to the village a portion of his/her annual salary as follows:
1. In the event a village official leaves office on or before August 31, said village official shall refund seventy five percent (75%) of his/her annual salary
to the village.
2. In the event a village official leaves office on or before November 30, said village official shall refund fifty percent (50%) of his/her annual salary to
the village.
3. In the event a village official leaves office on or before February 28, said village official shall refund twenty five percent (25%) of his/her salary to the
village. (Ord. 2004-67, 9-2-2004)
1-7-9: INDEMNIFICATION:
The village shall be responsible for, hold employees harmless from and pay for damages or monies which may be adjudged, assessed or otherwise levied
against any village employee except as otherwise provided by law, so long as the employee is acting or was acting within the scope of his employment,
and so long as the employee cooperates with the village in the defense of the action or actions or claims. Employees shall have legal representation by the
village in any civil cause of action brought against an employee resulting from or arising out of the performance of his duties, except as otherwise provided
herein. Employees shall be required to cooperate with the village during the course of the investigation, administration or litigation of any claim arising out
of this section. The village will provide the protections set forth hereinabove so long as the employee cooperates with the village in defense of the action or
actions or claims. The village shall not indemnify or defend any employee for any actions arising out of claims for punitive or exemplary damages. In
addition, the village responsibility with regard to this section shall not extend to any criminal charges brought against an employee. (Ord. 96-76, 8-1-1996)
1-7-10: SOCIAL SECURITY:
A. Policy And Purpose: It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village and the purpose of this section to extend to eligible employees, effective as of
July 1, 1966, the benefits of the federal old age, survivors and disability insurance provisions of the federal social security act, and amendments
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 19/618
thereto. In pursuance of said policy and for that purpose, the village president shall take such action as may be required by applicable state and federal
laws or regulations.
B. Agreement With State Employee Retirement System: The village president is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the social
security unit of the state employee retirement system to secure coverage of eligible employees.
C. Withholdings: Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the purpose provided in subsection A of this section are hereby authorized to be
made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the proper
state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws or regulations. (1978 Code § 1-10-1)
D. Employer Contributions: Employer contributions and administrative expense shall be paid to the state agency in accordance with applicable state laws
and regulations from amounts appropriated for such purposes. (1978 Code § 1-10-1; amd. 2011 Code)
E. Records And Reports: The village clerk shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations. (1978 Code § 1-10-1)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK
1-7A-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until his/her successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute. (1978 Code
§ 1-7-1)
1-7A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Generally: The village clerk shall have all the powers and perform all the duties now or hereafter provided by the laws of this state and the ordinances of
the village. Among other things, it shall be his/her duty as follows:
1. To keep his/her office at the place appointed by the board of trustees.
2. To attend all meetings of the board of trustees and to take minutes of all its proceedings.
3. To record such minutes, together with all ordinances and resolutions passed by the board of trustees, in books to be kept for that purpose.
4. To publish all proceedings of the board of trustees and all ordinances required by law to be published.
5. To serve all notices, either by personal service, by publication or by posting, required by law or the order of the board of trustees or the president to
be served, unless such notices are expressly ordered to be served by some other person.
6. To notify, within five (5) days after the result of any election is declared or appointment made, all persons elected or appointed to any village office of
their election or appointment, and unless such persons shall respectively qualify within ten (10) days after such notice, the office shall become
vacant.
7. To file all ordinances, communications, receipts and other documents required to be filed, and to arrange the same in systematic order for ready
reference.
8. To keep the corporate seal of the village and affix the same to all papers which require it.
9. To be the custodian and keeper of all the books, records, ordinances and papers of the village, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance.
10. To make copies of all papers in his/her office, and transcripts from journals and other records and files of his/her office, certified under the corporate
seal for use in evidence when required.
11. To file or cause to be filed a certified copy of each tax levy ordinance with the county clerk within the time required by law. (1978 Code § 1-7-3)
B. Custodian Of Documents: The village clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village which are not assigned to the custody of
some other officer. (1978 Code § 1-7-4)
C. Signature: The village clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this
formality. (1978 Code § 1-7-5)
D. Records Kept: In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by statute to keep, he/she shall keep a register of all
licenses and permits issued, and the payments thereon; a record showing all the officers and regular employees of the village; and such other records
as may be required by the board of trustees. (1978 Code § 1-7-6)
E. Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the village clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute
or ordinance. (1978 Code § 1-7-7)
1-7A-3: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 20/618
In case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a
successor to fill such office until the next annual village election, as is provided by statute. The president and board of trustees may appoint a village clerk
pro tempore whenever necessary, as provided by statute. (1978 Code § 1-7-8; amd. 2011 Code)
1-7A-4: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
A. There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The village clerk is authorized to appoint a deputy clerk who shall have the power and duty to execute
all documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the village clerk, and affix the seal of the village thereto whenever required. When
signing any documents, the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk followed by the word "By" and the deputy clerk's own name and the
words "Deputy Clerk".
B. The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised by such deputy clerk only in the absence of the village clerk from his/her office, and only
when either written direction has been given by the village clerk to exercise such power, or the president and board of trustees have determined by
resolution that the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function.
C. The deputy clerk shall serve at the pleasure of the village clerk and shall have the authority and power herein described, and such further power and
authority as may be provided by statute. (1978 Code § 1-7-9)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
1-7B-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
The office of village administrator is hereby created. The village administrator shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees. (1978 Code §§ 1-8-1, 1-8-2; amd. 2011 Code)
1-7B-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
A. The village administrator shall be appointed on the basis of his/her executive and administrative qualifications, with special reference to his/her
educational background, actual experience or knowledge of municipal management and the accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office. In
addition, the village administrator must, at the time of his/her appointment, possess the following minimum qualifications:
1. An advanced degree (beyond bachelor's degree) from an accredited American college or university in the area of public administration (or similarly
designated area of study); and
2. At least four (4) years' administrative experience in municipal or business practice.
B. The village administrator may, in substitution for the qualifications cited in subsections A1 and A2 of this section, at the time of his/her appointment,
have served for seven (7) or more years either as the assistant village administrator for the village or in some other clearly administrative (i.e.,
department head) capacity for the village. Any such individual must, at the time of the appointment to the position of village administrator, be currently
employed in an administrative position for the village. (1978 Code § 1-8-2)
1-7B-3: RESIDENCY:
The village administrator shall, within twelve (12) months of his/her appointment to that position, become a permanent, full time resident of the village. The
village administrator shall, for his/her entire tenure in that position with the village, remain a permanent, full time resident of the village. (1978 Code § 1-8-
2)
1-7B-4: TERM OF OFFICE:
The village administrator shall be appointed for a term not to exceed four (4) years plus sixty (60) days. It is expected that the term of the village
administrator shall run concurrently with that of the village president. In the event the position of village administrator becomes vacant during the term of a
village president or the village administrator's term is set at less than four (4) years plus sixty (60) days, any village administrator appointed to that position
shall be given a term not to exceed the remaining term of the previous village administrator or village president, whichever is shorter. In the event an
incumbent village president is reelected to that office, the term of the village administrator will still expire after no more than sixty (60) days, necessitating
reappointment of the individual serving as village administrator to that position. In the event an incumbent village administrator is not reappointed and does
not also receive the approval of the board of trustees within sixty (60) days of a village president's new term, then the term of the incumbent village
administrator shall expire. The village president shall have no authority to appoint a temporary village administrator except as provided by this code. (1978
Code § 1-8-2)
1-7B-5: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be designated and approved by the village president and board of trustees. (1978 Code
§ 1-8-3; amd. 2011 Code)
1-7B-6: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 21/618
The Village President, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, may remove the Village Administrator at any time. (1978 Code § 1-8-2)
1-7B-7: CONTRACT FOR SERVICES:
The Village Administrator may be given a written contract for services for a definite period of time, not to exceed the term as described in section 1-7B-4 of
this article. (1978 Code § 1-8-2)
1-7B-8: DUTIES:
The Village Administrator shall exercise general supervision over and be the administrative head of all departments and activities of the Municipal
government of the Village, shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments, and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed
by ordinance or directed by the Village Board of Trustees, including, but not limited to, the following:
A. Maintain Office; Devote Time To Duties: The Village Administrator shall maintain an office in the Village Hall and devote his/her entire time to the
performance of his/her duties.
B. Act As Purchasing Agent; Purchasing Powers And Duties: In the event of a vacancy in the Office of the Purchasing Agent, the Village Administrator
shall act as the Purchasing Agent until such time as the office is no longer vacant and shall have such powers and duties as are set forth in title 3,
chapter 1 of this Code.
C. Hiring, Suspending Or Discharging Employees; Evaluation Of Employees; Recommend Compensation: Subject to limitations prescribed by the Board of
Trustees or by State law, the Village Administrator shall have the authority to hire and to discharge all employees. No appointment shall be made upon
any basis other than that of merit and fitness. Any and all removals or suspensions shall be immediately reported, in writing, to the Village President
and Board of Trustees with specific reasons given for said action. The Village Administrator shall establish a procedure by which there shall be a
regular (meaning no less than once per year) performance evaluation of each and every Village employee, including department heads. Said
procedure shall be presented to the Board of Trustees for their information within the final quarter of each fiscal year or at some other mutually
convenient time. The Village Administrator shall also recommend to the Board the rate of compensation for all employees.
D. Submit Budget; Assist In Preparation Of Appropriation Ordinance: The Village Administrator shall prepare and submit to the Village Board of Trustees
for its consideration as soon as practicable after the close of each fiscal year, a budget containing estimates of revenues and expenses for the ensuing
fiscal year, which can serve as a basis for the preparation of the appropriation ordinance for that year, and he/she shall assist in the preparation of such
appropriation ordinance.
E. Serve As Business Manager: The Village Administrator shall act as Business Manager of the Village under the direction of the Board of Trustees and in
cooperation with the Village Treasurer and Village Clerk, and shall control and direct all expenditures made by the Village. He/she shall, before such
expenditures are presented to the Board of Trustees for approval, certify as to the correctness of all bills and accounts and shall have supervision over
the accounting work of the Village. He/she shall keep or cause to be kept full and complete books of accounts showing the exact condition of the
financial affairs of the Village, and shall supervise the keeping of all necessary records to accomplish this to the extent that such supervision is not
vested in the Village Treasurer or Village Clerk by statute or ordinance.
F. Keep Inventory; Custodian Of Village Property: The Village Administrator shall keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the Village
and the location of such property. He/she shall be responsible for the care and custody of all Village property which is not by statute or ordinance
assigned to some other officer or body for care and control.
G. Enforce Laws And Ordinances: The Village Administrator shall enforce the laws and ordinances within the Village.
H. Control Village Departments: The Village Administrator shall exercise control of all departments of the Village and divisions thereof.
I. Serve As Department Director Or Superintendent During Vacancies: The Village Administrator shall have and exercise the power, authority and duty of
any Director or Superintendent of a department or division thereof prescribed by this Code during the time when the Office of such Director or
Superintendent shall be vacant where no person shall have been appointed thereto.
J. Issue Licenses And Permits: The Village Administrator shall issue all licenses or permits not otherwise provided for by the Statutes of the State of
Illinois. (1978 Code § 1-8-4)
K. Duties During Emergencies: The Village Administrator shall assign employees to perform duties or assume responsibilities outside the scope of the
position descriptions and to direct and implement the Village emergency operations plan in the event of a Village disaster declaration or a homeland
security code red threat. (Ord. 2019-21, 4-18-2019)
1-7B-9: COOPERATION WITH OTHER VILLAGE OFFICERS, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS:
A. The Village Administrator shall render to the several officers of the Village, and such officers shall render to him, all such assistance as is possible in the
performance of their respective duties, and all officers and employees of the Village shall furnish and disclose to the Village Administrator such oral or
written information and material relating to the affairs of the Village as he shall request.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 22/618
B. The Village Administrator shall advise and assist all regularly constituted boards, committees and commissions of the Village and provide necessary
facilities for their operation and purpose, as directed by the Village Board of Trustees.
C. The Village Administrator shall attend all regular and special meetings of the Board of Trustees unless excused by said Board.
D. The Village Administrator shall, from time to time, make recommendations to the Board of Trustees relative to the adoption of such ordinances and
resolutions as he may deem necessary and such reports or recommendations relative to the affairs of the Village as he may deem advisable or as the
Board of Trustees may request. (1978 Code § 1-8-5)
1-7B-10: REPORTS AND STATEMENTS:
A. Monthly Reports And Statements: The Village Administrator shall render or cause to be rendered and correlated monthly to the Village Board of
Trustees a written report covering the work of each department or operation of the Village under his management, and monthly statements showing the
exact financial condition of the Village as of the end of the preceding month and a summarized statement of receipts and expenditures.
B. Annual Reports And Statements: The Village Administrator shall, at the end of each fiscal year of the Village, prepare and present to the Board of
Trustees a written report summarizing the workings of each department, office or operation of the Village under his management during the fiscal year,
and a financial statement including the same information for each fiscal year as is required on the monthly financial statement provided by subsection A
of this section. (1978 Code § 1-8-6)
1-7B-11: ASSISTANT VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR; ACTING VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
A. Office Created: The Office of Assistant Village Administrator is hereby created.
B. Qualifications: The Assistant Village Administrator shall possess a bachelor's degree from an accredited American college or university in the area of
public administration (or similarly designated area of study).
C. Powers And Duties: The Assistant Village Administrator shall exercise such powers, duties and responsibilities as are delegated by the Village
Administrator or as otherwise provided by ordinance. In accomplishing the duties of his office, the Assistant Village Administrator shall be under the
supervision of and shall report to the Village Administrator. In addition, in the absence of the Village Administrator through temporary absence,
disability, vacancy in office or otherwise, the Assistant Village Administrator shall carry out the powers, duties and responsibilities of the Village
Administrator.
D. Chief Of Police May Serve As: In the absence of, or where no Assistant Village Administrator has been appointed, the Chief of Police shall carry out the
powers, duties and responsibilities of the Village Administrator until such time as a Village Administrator or Assistant Village Administrator is appointed
as provided by this section. (Ord. 2013-61, 10-3-2013)
ARTICLE C. DIRECTOR OF FINANCE
1-7C-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
The office of director of finance is hereby created. Wherever in this code or other ordinances of the village the term "finance director" shall appear, it shall
mean and it shall be synonymous with the term "director of finance". The director of finance shall be appointed by the village president, by and with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees. (1978 Code §§ 1-16-1, 1-16-2)
1-7C-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The director of finance shall be chosen on the basis of objective executive, administrative and financial qualifications, with special reference to educational
background, actual experience and knowledge in the area of municipal and public finance and the accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office.
No person, however, shall be qualified to serve in the position of director of finance unless said individual possesses the following minimum qualifications:
graduation from a four (4) year college or university with major coursework in accounting, finance, business or related field; thorough, but not less than six
(6) years', experience in financial administration, including senior level supervisory experience; MPA/MBA or CPA are desirable; or any equivalent
combination of training and experience which provides the following knowledge, abilities and skills:
A. Thorough experience and knowledge of the applicable laws and administrative policies governing municipal finance practice and procedure.
B. Thorough knowledge of the principles and practices of municipal accounting.
C. Thorough knowledge of the principles and methods of organization, management and supervision.
D. Ability to plan, organize and direct comprehensive financial programs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 23/618
E. Ability to formulate and install accounting methods and procedures and ensure that these comply with federal, state and local laws.
F. Ability to prepare complex financial reports for presentation to experts and to the public.
G. Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with village officials and the public.
H. Ability to assess needs, perform fiscal planning, target available resources and implement effective programs.
I. Ability to provide informed financial advice to the village administrator, village board of trustees and the public.
J. Ability to communicate effectively, both orally and in writing. (1978 Code § 1-16-2)
1-7C-3: RESIDENCY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2013-61, 10-3-2013)
1-7C-4: TERM OF OFFICE:
The Director of Finance shall be appointed for a term not to exceed four (4) years plus sixty (60) days. The term of the Director of Finance shall run
concurrently with that of the Village President. In the event the position of Director of Finance becomes vacant during the term of a Village President or the
Director of Finance's term is set at less than four (4) years plus sixty (60) days, any Director of Finance appointed to that position shall be given a term not
to exceed the remaining term of the previous Director of Finance or Village President, whichever is shorter. In the event an incumbent Village President is
reelected to that office, the term of the Director of Finance will still expire after sixty (60) days, necessitating reappointment of the individual serving as
Director of Finance to that position. In the event an incumbent Director of Finance is not reappointed and does not also receive the approval of the Board
of Trustees within sixty (60) days of a Village President's new term, then the term of the incumbent Director of Finance shall expire, and that office shall be
declared vacant. The Village President shall have no authority to appoint a temporary Director of Finance except as provided by this Code. (1978 Code
§ 1-16-2)
1-7C-5: COMPENSATION:
The Director of Finance shall receive such compensation as shall be designated and approved by the Village President and Board of Trustees. (1978
Code § 1-16-3; amd. 2011 Code)
1-7C-6: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The Village President, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, may remove the Director of Finance at any time pursuant to the requirements for
removal of office established by the Illinois Municipal Code. (1978 Code § 1-16-2)
1-7C-7: CONTRACT FOR SERVICES:
The Director of Finance may be given a written contract for services for a definite period of time, not to exceed the term as described in section 1-7C-4 of
this article. (1978 Code § 1-16-2)
1-7C-8: DUTIES:
The Director of Finance shall exercise general supervision over and be the Executive Manager for planning, organizing and directing the activities of the
Department of Finance and assisting in the long range strategic planning for the Village and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by
ordinance or directed by the Village Board of Trustees, including, but not limited to, the following:
A. The Director of Finance shall maintain an office in the Village Hall and devote his/her entire time to the performance of his/her duties. Other duties shall
include, but not be limited to, the following: planning, organizing and directing all operations of the Department of Finance, including budgeting,
accounting, payroll, appropriation, disbursement and investment of all Village funds and other fiscal activities. Work also includes long range financial
planning. Supervision is exercised over Finance Department personnel directly or through a subordinate supervisor. Work is performed under the
administrative direction of the Village Administrator and the compliance with Federal, State and Village rules and regulations. Work is reviewed through
conferences and reports for overall program effectiveness.
B. Other duties and responsibilities shall include the following:
1. Plan, organize and direct the management and administration of fiscal records in compliance with Federal and State Statutes and this Code.
2. Assist the Village Administrator in long term strategic and financial planning.
3. Supervise, train, direct and evaluate department personnel and monitor all activities and operations of the department; set goals and objectives and
establish guidelines for performance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 24/618
4. Develop systems, policies and procedures for transacting financial matters. Develop plans for internal and external financing of projects.
5. Direct general accounting activities and develop and maintain internal control systems; act as the main contact person for the annual audit.
6. Implement Village Board goals as they relate to financial management programs.
7. Coordinate the Village involvement in various Municipal self-insurance pools, if any.
8. Prepare fiscal studies, income and expenditure estimates, cost/benefit analyses and financial reporting as required by the Village Administrator and
by law.
9. Advise the Village Administrator, Village Board of Trustees and other officials on budgetary and fiscal management.
10. Coordinate development of the annual budget, including the capital improvement plan. Assist in the preparation of ordinances to implement the
budget, including tax levy and tax levy abatement ordinances; monitor budget performance.
11. Coordinate the various functions of the Finance Department with all other departments and other public agencies.
12. Supervise procurement and purchasing of goods and services for the Village.
13. If so requested by the Village Board, attend Village Board of Trustees and other meetings as required and prepare items for Board action.
14. Promote and maintain responsive community relations.
15. Perform related work as required. (Ord. 2019-22, 4-18-2019)
1-7C-9: ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF FINANCE:
A. Position Created; Selection: The job position of Assistant Director of Finance is hereby created. If the necessary appropriations are made by the Village
Corporate Authorities for the position of Assistant Director of Finance, the Assistant Director of Finance shall be selected by the Village Administrator,
with direct input and recommendations from the Director of Finance.
B. Qualifications: The Assistant Director of Finance must possess the same qualifications as the Director of Finance, except that the Assistant Director of
Finance need not possess more than two (2) years' experience in financial administration and need not possess senior level supervisory experience.
C. Powers And Duties: The Assistant Director of Finance shall exercise his/her powers, duties and responsibilities as are delegated to the Assistant
Director of Finance by the Director of Finance, the Village Administrator or as otherwise provided by ordinance. In addition, in the absence of the
Director of Finance through disability, vacancy in office or otherwise, the Assistant Director of Finance shall carry out the powers, duties and
responsibilities of the Director of Finance, but shall not be deemed an officer of the Village. (1978 Code § 1-16-5)
ARTICLE D. DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
1-7D-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The office of director of community development is hereby created. The director of community development shall be appointed by the village president, by
and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, for such term as may be determined at the time of appointment. In accomplishing the duties of
his/her office, the director of community development shall be under the supervision of and shall report to the village administrator. (1978 Code § 4-1-1b;
amd. 2011 Code)
1-7D-2: COMPENSATION:
The director of community development shall receive such salary as is designated and approved by the village president and board of trustees. (1978
Code § 4-1-1b; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE E. DIRECTOR OF GOLF COURSE OPERATIONS
1-7E-1: PURCHASING POWERS AND DUTIES:
The person or firm which the village president and board of trustees designates or contracts with as the manager of the village golf course facility is hereby
expressly authorized, except where specific provision to the contrary is made by state law or by the village president and board of trustees, to purchase
and make expenditures for supplies, materials, equipment and services needed by the village for the operation or maintenance of the village golf course
facility for which funds are provided by appropriation, budget, golf course revenues or special fund designated for such purpose. The director of golf course
operations may exercise this authority, in his discretion, without previous authorization by the board of trustees to purchase supplies, materials, equipment
or services needed by the village for the operation and maintenance of the village golf course facility costing not more than ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00). In all other respects, all purchase orders or contracts for supplies, materials, equipment or services needed by the village for the operation
and maintenance of the village golf course facility involving the expenditure of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be let to the lowest
responsible bidder after a public advertisement for bids and approved by the village president and board of trustees unless such board, by vote of twothirds
(2/3) of all the trustees elected, shall waive public advertisement for bids. (1978 Code § 1-11-8)

Chapter 8
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
1-8-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created the department of public works of the village, which department shall consist of a director of public works and such other officers
and employees as may from time to time be provided by the village president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2013-61, 10-3-2013; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-
2014)
1-8-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR:
A. The director of public works shall have charge and supervision over all public property of the village, including all streets, parkways, sidewalks,
municipal buildings and all other property of the village not specifically assigned to some other officer.
B. The director of public works shall have charge of and be responsible for the condition of all motor vehicles, trucks and other public works equipment of
the village and of all buildings or places in which the same are housed and kept.
C. The director of public works shall submit a proposal to be acted upon by the board of trustees before the expenditures of any monies on behalf of the
village. (Ord. 2013-61, 10-3-2013; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
1-8-3: RESIDENCY REQUIRED:
The director of public works shall, within twelve (12) months of his/her appointment to that position, become a permanent, full time resident of the village.
The director of public works shall, for his/her entire tenure in that position with the village, remain a permanent, full time resident of the village. (Ord. 2013-
61, 10-3-2013; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
Chapter 9
ETHICS
1-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be given the definitions provided in this section:
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any
individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; b) relating
to collective bargaining; or c) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elective office, or who has been appointed to fill a
vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the election code1.
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 3 of the Illinois public labor relations act2.
COMPENSATED TIME: Means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time
requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment but, for purposes of this chapter, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods,
personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are
not fixed, "compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the
officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate, in whole or in part, for time worked in excess of
the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of the election code3.
EMPLOYEE: A person employed by the village of Glendale Heights, whether on a full time or part time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are
subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an
independent contractor.
EMPLOYER: The village of Glendale Heights.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an
officer or employee.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive: a) compensation for employment; b) service credit towards pension
benefits; and c) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or this chapter, regardless of whether the officer is compensated
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 26/618
for service in his or her official capacity.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include
activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; b) relating to collective bargaining; or c) that are
otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under section 9-3 of the election code4, but only with regard to those activities that
require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY: A. Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other
political event.
B. Soliciting contributions, including, but not limited to, the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser,
political meeting, or other political event.
C. Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value or intended as a campaign contribution.
D. Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization
for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
E. Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
F. Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
G. Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort
to get voters to the polls.
H. Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any
referendum question.
I. Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in the capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
J. Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires.
K. Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for
elective office or for or against any referendum question.
L. Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question.
M. Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
N. Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention.
O. Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
A. Is seeking official action: 1) by an officer; or 2) by an employee; or 3) by the officer or another employee directing that employee;
B. Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the officer; or 2) with an employee; or 3) with the officer or another employee directing that
employee;
C. Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the officer; or 2) by an employee; or 3) by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
D. Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duties of the officer or employee. (Ord. 2004-
28, 5-13-2004)
1-9-2: ETHICS ADVISOR:
A. Position Created: The village president, with the advice and consent of the president and board of trustees, shall designate an ethics advisor for the
village. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the village unless the position has been created as an office by
the village.
B. Duties: The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the
provisions of this chapter and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the president and board of
trustees. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
1-9-3: ETHICS COMMISSION:
A. Created; Appointment; Restrictions: There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ETHICS COMMISSION OF THE VILLAGE OF
GLENDALE HEIGHTS. The commission shall be comprised of three (3) members appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees. No person shall be appointed as a member of the commission who is related, either by blood or by marriage up to the degree of
first cousin, to any elected village officer. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Terms Of Office: At the first meeting of the commission, the initial appointees shall draw lots to determine their initial terms. Two (2) commissioners shall
serve two (2) year terms, and the third commissioner shall serve a one year term. Thereafter, all commissioners shall be appointed to two (2) year
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 27/618
terms. Commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms.
C. Organization: At the first meeting of the commission, the commissioners shall choose a chairperson from their number. Meetings shall be held at the
call of the chairperson or any two (2) commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two (2) commissioners, and official action by the commission shall
require the affirmative vote of two (2) members. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
D. Removals And Vacancies: The president and board of trustees may remove a commissioner in case of incompetency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in
office after service on the commissioner by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a copy of the written charges against the commissioner and after
providing an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel upon not less than ten (10) days' notice. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as
original appointments. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
E. Powers And Duties: The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
1. To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers.
2. Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary
actions, impose fines in accordance with section 1-9-7 of this chapter and refer violations of section 1-9-4 or 1-9-5 of this chapter to the appropriate
attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this chapter and not
upon its own prerogative.
3. To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons who may
have violated the provisions of this chapter.
4. To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all
officers and employees of the village to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with
requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for disciplinary discharge.
5. The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
1-9-4: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
A. No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any "compensated time", as defined in section 1-9-1 of this
chapter.
B. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village in connection with any prohibited political activity.
C. At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as part of that
officer or employee's duties; 2) as a condition of employment; or 3) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off).
D. No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being
awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or
otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any
prohibited political activity.
E. Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that
are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this chapter.
F. No person either: 1) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment; or 2) in a position, the salary for which is paid in
whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant in aid
programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political party or of a political
organization or club. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
1-9-5: GIFTS:
A. Gift Ban: Except as permitted by this section, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee
(collectively referred to herein as "recipients"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any "prohibited source", as defined herein, or which is
otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section.
B. Exceptions:
1. This section is not applicable to the following:
a. Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public.
b. Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or immediate family member, pays the fair market value.
c. Any:
(1) Contribution that is lawfully made under the election code; or
(2) Activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political organization or candidate.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 28/618
d. Educational materials and missions.
e. Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business.
f. A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great
uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law,
daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, or half sister, and
including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee.
g. Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances,
the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not
because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the
circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as:
(1) The history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts
between those individuals;
(2) Whether, to the actual knowledge of the recipient, the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or
business reimbursement for the gift; and
(3) Whether, to the actual knowledge of the recipient, the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gifts to other
officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members.
h. Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day; provided, that the food or
refreshments are: 1) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared; or 2) catered. For the purposes of this subsection
B1h, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means.
i. Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that
are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position
or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances.
j. Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of this chapter, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or
employee from another officer or employee, and "intergovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee
of another governmental entity.
k. Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death.
l. Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
2. Each of the exceptions listed in this subsection B is mutually exclusive and independent of every other.
C. Disposition Of Gifts: An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee does not violate this
chapter if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its
value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under section 501(c)(3) of the internal revenue code of 1986, as now or hereafter
amended, renumbered, or succeeded. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
1-9-6: COMPLAINT PROCEDURE:
A. Filing Complaints: Complaints alleging a violation of this chapter shall be filed with the ethics commission.
B. Notice Of Complaint: Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt
requested, a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by
certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three (3) business days after receipt by
the commission. The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the
sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed.
C. Review Of Complaint; Decision On Validity:
1. Upon not less than forty eight (48) hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is
deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this chapter, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the
complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the open meetings act. The commission shall issue
notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause, to
proceed, within seven (7) business days after receiving the complaint.
2. If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 1-9-5 of this chapter and there is a determination of probable cause, then the
commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within four (4) weeks after the complaint's receipt. Alternatively, the
commission may elect to notify in writing the attorney designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and request that the
complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause,
then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that
notice shall be made public.
3. If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 1-9-4 of this chapter, then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney
designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the
custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation.
D. Hearing: On the scheduled date and upon at least forty eight (48) hours' public notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the
complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 29/618
the open meetings act.
E. Decisions And Recommendation: Within thirty (30) days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the commission shall either: 1)
dismiss the complaint; or 2) issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the village administrator or impose a fine upon the
violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for discipline, and any fine imposed shall be a matter of public information.
F. Demand Of Public Hearing:
1. If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven (7) business
days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of
the recommendation or fine.
2. Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the demand, the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint upon at least forty eight (48)
hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within seven (7) days thereafter, the
commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation to the alleged violator and to the village administrator or impose a fine upon the violator, or
both.
G. Complaints Filed Near Election Dates: If a complaint is filed during the sixty (60) days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a
candidate, the commission shall render its decision as required under subsection F of this section within seven (7) days after the complaint is filed, and
during the seven (7) days preceding that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of that election, if possible.
H. Time Limit For Filing Complaint: A complaint alleging the violation of this chapter must be filed within one year after the alleged violation. (Ord. 2004-28,
5-13-2004)
1-9-7: PENALTIES:
A. Violations Of Section 1-9-4:
1. A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 1-9-4 of this chapter may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00). (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
2. A violation of section 1-9-4 of this chapter shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the village by filing in the circuit court an
information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction
shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt.
B. Violations Of Section 1-9-5:
1. A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 1-9-5 of this chapter is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one thousand one
dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
2. A violation of section 1-9-5 of this chapter may be prosecuted by the ethics commission through the designated administrative procedure. (Ord.
2004-28, 5-13-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
C. Intentional False Reports: Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this chapter to the local enforcement
authorities, the state's attorney or any other law enforcement official, may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a
penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00).
D. Additional Enforcement: In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally
violates any provision of section 1-9-4 or 1-9-5 of this chapter is subject to discipline or discharge. (Ord. 2004-28, 5-13-2004)
Chapter 10
ELECTIONS
1-10-1: ELECTION DISTRICTS:
The village is hereby redivided into six (6) districts as described in exhibit A (consisting of 6 pages), attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a
part hereof, and as illustrated in exhibit B attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof. Each of the six (6) districts shall be
represented by one trustee who shall be elected by only the electors of that district. (Ord. 2001-41, 6-7-2001)
1-10-2: MANNER OF CONDUCTING ELECTIONS:
All elections held within the village shall be conducted in the manner prescribed by state law. (1978 Code § 1-11-2)
1-10-3: COMPENSATION OF ELECTION JUDGES AND OFFICIALS:
Election officials and election judges shall receive no more than the maximum compensation permitted by state law. (1978 Code § 1-11-3)

Chapter 11
VILLAGE RECORDS
1-11-1: OPEN RECORDS:
All ordinances, resolutions, minutes of public meetings and correspondence of the village board of trustees and other bodies of the village shall be
available for inspection by the public at reasonable times during normal business hours, upon request being made to the village clerk. (1978 Code § 1-11-
1; amd. 2011 Code)
1-11-2: AVAILABILITY OF RECORDS; FEES:
As provided by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/3 (2005), rules and regulations concerning the time and place where records may be made available, the
persons from whom said records may be obtained, and the associated duplication fees to be charged are hereby established as follows:
A. All records subject to the freedom of information act shall be made available for inspection and/or copying in the office of the functional unit of the village
responsible for the storage of the record requested, only during the regularly scheduled working hours of the unit responsible for the storage of the
record requested.
B. Requests for inspection and/or copying of public records subject to the freedom of information act shall be presented in writing to the village clerk or to
the department head or other designated employee of the functional unit of the village responsible for the storage of the record requested.
C. The village clerk shall maintain and make available to the public an index of village records with an indication on said index of the functional unit of the
village responsible for storage of the record.
D. The village clerk shall also maintain a listing of the regularly scheduled working hours of the functional units of the village responsible for the storage of
records, as well as the title of the department head or other employee designated to receive requests for inspection of records in each functional unit.
E. The indexes required to be maintained by the village clerk shall be posted at the office of the village clerk and at the office of each functional unit
responsible for the storage of records subject to the freedom of information act.
F. Costs incurred for duplication and/or certification of records provided in accordance with the freedom of information act shall be borne by the individual
requesting said duplication and/or certification rather than the general public.
G. The corporate authorities find that the costs listed below are reasonably calculated to reimburse the actual cost to the village to reproduce and certify
public records pursuant to 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/6. Copies of public records shall be provided by the office of the village clerk, the
department head or other designated employee of the functional unit of the village responsible for the storage of the record requested, and fees shall
be charged in accordance with the following schedule:
Duplication of letter and legal size documents $1.00 per page
Photographs (per photograph) 8 x 10 = $10.00
5 x 7 = 8.00
3 x 5 = 5.00
If still photographs are requested from recordings, add an additional $5.00 per photograph
Video recordings CD/DVD recordings = $30.00
VHS tape recordings = 25.00
Audio recordings $15.00
Accident reports 6.00
Reconstructed accidents (reports) 25.00
Copies of manuals 25.00
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 31/618
H. Pursuant to 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/6, all fees imposed may be reduced or waived at the discretion of the village clerk or the department head
of the functional unit of the village responsible for the storage of the record requested. All requests for reductions or waivers shall be made in writing.
(Ord. 2005-44, 6-16-2005)
1-11-3: FEES FOR SUBPOENAED RECORDS:
A. Fees shall be charged to all persons issuing a subpoena to the village or its departments for documents in accordance with the following fee schedule:
Duplication of letter and legal size documents $1.00 per page
Photographs (per photograph) 8 x 10 = $10.00
5 x 7 = 8.00
3 x 5 = 5.00
If still photographs are requested from recordings, add an additional $5.00 per photograph
Video recordings CD/DVD recordings = $30.00
VHS tape recordings = 25.00
Audio recordings $15.00
Accident reports 6.00
Reconstructed accidents (reports) 25.00
Copies of manuals 25.00
B. All fees imposed may be reduced or waived at the discretion of the village clerk or the department head of the functional unit of the village responsible
for the storage of the record subpoenaed. All individual requests for reductions or waivers shall be made in writing. (Ord. 2005-44, 6-16-2005)
Chapter 12
OFFICIAL COMPREHENSIVE PLAN
1-12-1: PLAN ADOPTED:
The revised official comprehensive plan of the village, dated November 30, 1973, printed in pamphlet form and incorporated herein by reference, is hereby
adopted and designated as the revised official comprehensive plan of the village. (1978 Code § 6-1-1)
1-12-2: AMENDMENT PROCEDURE:
Either the plan commission or the village board of trustees, in the manner provided by statute, may initiate or originate proposed amendments to the
official comprehensive plan adopted herein. (1978 Code § 6-1-2; amd. 2011 Code)
1-12-3: COPIES OF PLAN:
The village clerk shall keep in the village hall for inspection by interested persons copies of the official comprehensive plan and any amendments thereto.
The village clerk shall also make available copies of the official comprehensive plan for purchase as provided in chapter 11 of this title. (1978 Code § 6-1-
3; amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 13
DISCLOSURE OF INTERESTS IN REAL ESTATE
1-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 32/618
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AGENT: A person authorized to act for another person or corporation.
APPLICANT: One who applies for any benefits on behalf of himself or some other entity.
BENEFICIAL INTEREST: Any interest in a land trust.
BENEFICIARY: Any person, corporation or other entity having a beneficial interest in a land trust.
CORPORATION: A body of persons authorized by law to act together as a single person and, for the purpose of this chapter, includes any association,
joint stock company, syndicate or partnership.
LAND TRUST: An express agreement whereby the legal and equitable title to real estate is held by a trustee for the benefit of beneficiaries who have the
exclusive right to manage and control said real estate.
LESSEE: One who has an interest in real estate by virtue of a lease.
NOMINEE: One designated to act for another, with limited authority.
OPTION HOLDER: One having the right to purchase real estate upon compliance with conditions named in a contract.
STOCKHOLDER: One owning certificates of stock in a corporation or membership in an association, joint stock company, syndicate or partnership. (1978
Code § 7-1-4)
1-13-2: DISCLOSURE REQUIRED:
A. Any application to the village board of trustees, village clerk or any other village board or commission for authorization, benefit, license, permit, variation,
zoning amendment or planned unit development relating to real estate shall be signed by the owner, lessee, option holder, agent or nominee of either.
B. If the application is made by a person other than the fee owner, it shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the owner that the person signing the
application has authority to make the application, and the application shall disclose the full names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant
and owner.
C. If the applicant or the owner is a corporation, the application shall disclose the names and addresses of the officers, directors, registered agents and
those shareholders or members owning in excess of five percent (5%) of the outstanding stock or interest in the corporation.
D. If the applicant is a trustee, the full name, address, telephone number and the extent of the interest of each beneficiary must be disclosed.
E. If the applicant is a beneficiary, nominee or option holder, the application must disclose the names, addresses and telephone numbers of those persons
or entities for whom he is acting, and if it is a corporation, there shall be compliance with the provisions of subsection C of this section. (1978 Code § 7-
1-4)
1-13-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person making a false or incomplete statement in the application shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00). After a statement is determined to be falsified, missing or incorrect, a written notice of the omission or falsification shall be sent to the
applicant. Each day that elapses until the date the required information is furnished or corrected shall constitute a separate offense. (1978 Code § 7-1-4;
amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 14
ANNEXATIONS
1-14-1: APPROVAL PROCEDURE:
A. Each petition for annexation to the village shall be accompanied by petitions for annexation of the same territory to the relevant school district, the public
library district and the fire protection district, unless the territory is already entirely within such districts, or any of them.
B. If a petition for annexation is pending before the plan commission or the village board, a preliminary plat for subdivision will not be acted upon by the
plan commission until the petition for annexation has been approved or disapproved by the village board of trustees. (Ord. 2012-55, 9-6-2012)
1-14-2: ANNEXATION FUNDS:
A. Fees For Petitions To Annex:
1. Established: No land shall be annexed to the village except upon the payment of both a nonrefundable application fee and an annexation fee as set
forth in chapter 15 of this title. (Ord. 2011-82, 10-20-2011; amd. Ord. 2014-63, 10-16-2014)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 33/618
2. Payment; Refunds: Such fees shall be paid by the owners to the village clerk upon the filing of the petition to annex. The annexation fee, but not the
application fee, shall be refunded to the owners of the property in the event that the village president and board of trustees fail to act upon the
petition to annex within one hundred twenty (120) days following the filing thereof, or if for any other reason the requested annexation fails to be
completed. (Ord. 2011-35, 6-16-2011)
B. Annexation Agreement; Deposit Requirements: Where an annexation is conditioned upon the execution of an annexation agreement, the owner or
petitioner, in addition to the foregoing fees, shall be responsible for payment to the village the following cash deposit to be applied against all costs and
expenses incurred thereby with regard to such annexation agreement including publication costs of legal hearing notices and fees paid to the village
attorney and village engineer for drafting, review, inspection and other related services; said costs to be payable when incurred and to be
nonrefundable. Any costs and expenses incurred in excess of the following cash deposit shall be invoiced by the village to the owner or petitioner who
shall be responsible for payment of the invoice upon its receipt. Any unused portion of the cash deposit provided in this subsection shall be refunded to
the owner of the property or petitioner upon annexation or in the event that the village president and board of trustees fail to act upon the petition to
annex within one hundred twenty (120) days following the filing thereof, or if for any reason the requested annexation fails to be complete.
Under 5 acres $ 500.00
5 to 10 acres 1,000.00
10 to 20 acres 1,500.00
20 acres and over 2,000.00

the village clerk showing payment of the fees and, if applicable, the cash deposit provided in this section.
D. Application Of Fee And Deposit To Other Zoning Situations: If the owner or petitioner should apply for a zoning amendment, conditional use, variance or
a planned unit development in addition to annexation, only one application fee and cash deposit shall be required. (1978 Code § 1-11-4)
