(B) If the seller is selling on behalf of a company or business, the name, address, and telephone number of such company or business shall also
be recorded/reported.
(C) If the junk/scrap is brought by motor vehicle to a licensee for sale, the make, model, color, and license plate number of that vehicle shall be
recorded/reported. This subsection does not apply to persons bringing scrap precious metals into pawnshops or secondhand stores.
(D) The date and time of the transaction.
(E) A digital photograph or, if the licensee has a video system, a video segment of each individual type and form of bulk material purchased by
the licensee shall be linked to the record of that transaction.
b. Sales By Licensees:
(1) Licensees do not need to record/report any information pertaining to the sale of junk/scrap material.
B. In the event the electronic reporting system malfunctions or is otherwise not operational, the licensee shall, at all times during such malfunction or
nonoperation, be required to keep written records of any and all transactions made during the period of malfunction or nonoperation, to include all
information required by this section. These written records shall be reported/uploaded to LeadsOnline, or the village of Glendale Heights' current
electronic reporting system, as soon as practicable after the electronic reporting system is functional. No such written records shall be erased,
mutilated or changed. Written records shall be open and available for review upon request by the village of Glendale Heights finance director or any
peace officer during regular business hours. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-5: PAWNBROKERS; ISSUANCE OF SIGNED RECEIPT:
Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of making any advancement or loan, deliver to the person pawning or pledging any property a signed receipt
containing an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all the goods, articles or other things pawned or pledged, the amount of
money, value or thing loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same, the rate of interest to be paid on such loan, and the name and residence of the
person making the pawn or pledge. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-6: PAWNBROKERS; EMPLOYMENT OF PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE:
No pawnbroker shall permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to take pledges or pawns. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-7: SECONDHAND DEALER NOT TO ACT AS A PAWNBROKER:
No secondhand dealer shall receive any article or thing by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall it loan or advance any sum of money on the security of any
article or thing, unless also separately licensed as a pawnbroker under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-8: WAITING PERIODS:
No articles received on pawn or pledge by any pawnbroker, shall be permitted to be redeemed or removed from the place of business of such pawnbroker
for forty eight (48) hours after the delivery of the signed receipt required by section 4-12-5 of this chapter. No articles pawned or pledged shall be sold or
disposed of by any pawnbroker within one year from the time the pawner or pledger is in default in the payment of interest on the money so advanced by
the pawnbroker, unless by the written consent of the pawner or pledger.
No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall expose for sale, or sell or barter, or melt, crush/compact, destroy, or otherwise dispose of, any non-scrap/junk
article within thirty (30) days of the time of purchasing or receiving the same, nor until the same has been in or upon the premises where the same are
offered, exposed, bartered or sold, at least thirty (30) days.
Scrap/junk articles must be held for seventy two (72) hours prior to being melted, crushed/compacted, destroyed or otherwise disposed of. (Ord. 2012-69,
11-15-2012)
4-12-9: PROHIBITED TRANSACTIONS:
A. No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer, in the course of conducting business, shall receive any articles for pawn, pledge, advancement of money, loan,
resale, or personal use from:
1. Minors who are under eighteen (18) years of age.
2. Any person appearing to be intoxicated or under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
3. Any person known to the pawnbroker or secondhand dealer to have been convicted of theft, residential burglary, burglary, home invasion, vehicular
invasion, armed robbery, robbery or electronic fencing under the laws of the state of Illinois, or the equivalent laws of any other state. A peace officer
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 118/618
may provide such criminal conviction information to a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer, and a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer may also access
the LeadsOnline "no buy" list prior to making a transaction to ensure that the prospective pawner/seller has not been convicted of any such crime.
4. Any person bringing such articles to the premises in a shopping cart.
5. Any person presenting a serial numbered non-scrap/junk article from which the serial number has been removed or obliterated.
B. In the event that any of the above enumerated persons shall attempt to conduct a prohibited transaction, a representative of that business shall notify
the village of Glendale Heights police department of the incident while the person is still present in the business if safe to do so, or otherwise as soon
as the person has left the business. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-10: REPORT OF FALSE/FICTITIOUS/FORGED/ALTERED ID CARD:
In the event that a person seeking to sell or pawn any item presents to the owner/operator/employee of a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer what is
reasonably believed to be a false/fictitious/forged/altered ID card, a representative of that business shall notify the village of Glendale Heights police
department of the incident while the person is still present in the business if safe to do so, or otherwise as soon as the person has left the business. (Ord.
2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-11: REPORT OF LOST OR STOLEN ARTICLES TO POLICE:
Every pawnbroker or secondhand dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things under circumstances which would lead a
reasonable person to conclude that they have been lost or stolen, or which have been alleged or supposed to have been lost or stolen shall immediately
notify the village of Glendale Heights police department of such receipt and, forthwith on demand, exhibit the same to any member of the village of
Glendale Heights police department. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-12: RETURN OF STOLEN PROPERTY:
Upon written notice from a law enforcement officer indicating that property in the possession of a pawnbroker is subject to a hold order and is needed for
the purpose of furthering a criminal investigation and prosecution, the pawnbroker shall release the property subject to the hold order to the custody of the
law enforcement officer for such purpose, and the officer shall provide a written acknowledgment that the property has been released to the officer. The
release of the property to the custody of the law enforcement officer shall not be considered a waiver or release of the pawnbroker's property rights or
interest in the property. Upon completion of the criminal investigation, the property shall be returned to the pawnbroker who consented to its release;
except that, if the law enforcement officer has not completed the criminal investigation within one hundred twenty (120) days after its release, the officer
shall immediately return the property to the pawnbroker or obtain and furnish to the pawnbroker a warrant for the continued custody of the property.
The pawnbroker shall not release or dispose of the property except pursuant to a court order or the expiration of the holding period of the hold order,
including all extensions. In cases where criminal charges have been filed and the property may be needed as evidence, the prosecuting attorney shall
notify the pawnbroker in writing. The notice shall contain the case number, the style of the case, and a description of the property. The pawnbroker shall
hold such property until receiving notice of the disposition of the case from the prosecuting attorney. The prosecuting attorney shall notify the pawnbroker
and claimant in writing within fifteen (15) days after the disposition of the case. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-13: INSPECTION OF RECORDS BY POLICE:
The books and computer records, as well as every article or other thing of value so pawned or pledged, shall at all times be open to inspection by the
village of Glendale Heights police department. In addition, the village of Glendale Heights police department shall be authorized to inspect the books or
records of any business it has reasonable cause to believe is conducting transactions which should be licensed under this chapter.
The books and computer records, pawn receipts, or any other records required by this chapter or any rule promulgated in accordance with this chapter
shall be maintained for a period of three (3) years after the date on which the record or receipt was prepared. These records and receipts shall be open to
inspection by the village of Glendale Heights police department at all times during the three (3) year period. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-14: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No business licensed under this chapter shall purchase or accept as pawn or pledge, or otherwise, any goods, articles or things whatsoever, from any
person, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-15: SOLICITATION OF ARTICLES:
No person licensed under this chapter shall be permitted to solicit business of any nature upon any street or public highway in the village of Glendale
Heights.
Enforcement of this section shall be by the village of Glendale Heights police department, with a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense,
and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for any subsequent offenses. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-16: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in, carry on, or conduct the business of a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer within the village of Glendale Heights, unless licensed
to do so. A pawnbroker's license and secondhand dealer's license are separate from each other. A person may hold more than one license under this
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 119/618
section.
Each license issued pursuant to this chapter, shall terminate on December 31 next following its issuance, and the renewal fee shall be due and payable in
full on or before February 1 of each year. Provided, however, any new licensee applying for an annual license after August 1 of the license year shall pay
an amount equal to one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee from the time the license is granted until its termination on December 31 next following its
issuance. Any new licensee applying for an annual license from February 1 through July 31 of the license year shall pay the full annual license fee. No
licensee shall receive any pro rata refund for any unused portion of the license, and no license shall be issued for an amount less than one-half (1/2) of the
annual fee.
Violations of this section will result in proceedings to revoke any and all village of Glendale Heights issued business licenses held by a licensee under this
chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-17: APPLICATION:
Any person desiring a license as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall make application in writing to the village of Glendale Heights clerk, setting out
in the application the full name and residence of the applicant, if an individual, and if a corporation, the name and residence of each of its officers. Such
application shall also set out the location at which it is intended or desired to conduct such business, and such other information as the village of Glendale
Heights clerk shall from time to time deem appropriate.
The chief of police, or his designee, or any other officer or agent designated by the village of Glendale Heights board of trustees, shall investigate each
license applicant and shall report in writing whether or not such applicant is a person of good character. No license shall be issued to any person,
partnership, corporation or other entity, if any owner, manager, partner, officer, director or shareholder owning more than five percent (5%) of the shares of
stock in the corporation has been convicted of any felony offense or convicted of the offense(s) of possession of stolen goods, burglary, robbery, or who
has been convicted of any criminal offense involving dishonesty or moral turpitude.
Every applicant for a license under this chapter, as well as every owner, partner, manager, officer, director, employee, and, in this case, of a corporate
applicant, every shareholder owning more than five percent (5%) of the shares of stock in the corporation shall undergo a criminal background
investigation, which investigation may include fingerprinting, prior to the issuance of a license under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-18: PERSONNEL AND OWNERSHIP CHANGES:
A. Any changes in partnership, officers, directors, managers, or persons holding directly or beneficially more than five percent (5%) of the stock or
ownership interests of establishments licensed under this chapter shall be reported in writing to the village of Glendale Heights clerk within ten (10)
days of the change. All new personnel and/or stockholders shall meet all of the standards of this chapter and must otherwise qualify to hold a license
under this chapter. All such changes in personnel or ownership shall be subject to review by the village of Glendale Heights clerk within thirty (30) days
of the change. In addition to any other license fees, the cost of any background investigation conducted by the village of Glendale Heights police
department shall be borne by the new partner(s), officer(s), director(s), manager(s) or person(s) holding directly or beneficially more than five percent
(5%) of the stock.
B. When a license has been issued to a partnership or limited liability company and a change of ownership occurs by one or more partners/members, then
a new application for a license under this chapter must be submitted and the license application shall be accompanied by the appropriate license fee.
C. When a license has been issued to a partnership or limited liability company and any partner/member is or becomes ineligible to hold a license under
this chapter, that license shall be terminated.
D. When a license has been issued to a corporation or limited liability company and a change takes place in officers, directors, managers, members or
shareholders of more than five percent (5%) of the stock, resulting in the holding of office or shares of stock by one who is not eligible for a license,
said license shall terminate.
E. When a license has been issued to a corporation and a transfer in stock ownership of fifty one percent (51%) or more occurs, or a transfer in stock
ownership occurs resulting in a change in the ownership of the controlling interest in the corporation by one or more persons, then a new license
application for a license under this chapter must be submitted and the corporation shall pay the appropriate license fee.
F. When a license has been issued to an individual who is no longer eligible for a license, said license shall terminate.
G. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall subject a licensee to the suspension or revocation of a license issued under this chapter. Fines
and penalties under this section shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day, per violation.
Any false information provided on an application shall result in the denial or revocation of a license issued under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-
2012)
4-12-19: LICENSE TO STATE LOCATION OF BUSINESS:
Every license granted under this chapter shall designate the place in which the licensee shall be authorized to carry on such business. Such business shall
not be carried on or conducted in any other place than that designated by the license. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-20: CHANGE OF LOCATION OF BUSINESS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 120/618
In case any licensee under this chapter shall remove his place of business from the place designated on such license, no business shall be carried on or
engaged in at the new location under such license until written notice of such change has been given by the licensee to the village of Glendale Heights
clerk, and such change has been noted by the village of Glendale Heights clerk upon such license. The address of the place of business shall thereupon
be changed on the sides of any vehicle used by such licensee under this chapter, and made to correspond with such new place of business. (Ord. 2012-
69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-21: LICENSE TO BE PUBLICLY POSTED:
Every license granted under this chapter shall be conspicuously posted for public viewing so as to be seen by anyone entering the place of business,
whether that place of business is a fixed storefront or temporary, nonfixed location, or in/on any vehicle licensed under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-
2012)
4-12-22: BOND:
Every person licensed under this chapter shall at the time of receiving a license, execute a bond to the village of Glendale Heights in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with good and sufficient sureties, conditioned for the due observance of the ordinances of the village of Glendale Heights
respecting business activities regulated under this chapter. The bond will be returned upon sale or closure of business, or expiration of the license,
whichever comes last. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-23: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; FEE:
The village of Glendale Heights clerk shall grant licenses to applicants under this chapter that pass a background check conducted by the village of
Glendale Heights police department, to conduct business at the place designated in the application for and during the period of such license, upon
payment by the applicant to the village of Glendale Heights of an annual license fee in the amount set forth in section 4-2-2 of this title.
Any person employed by or providing volunteer work for the licensee at the business at any time during the period of the license, shall also be required to
pass a background check conducted by the village of Glendale Heights police department, if that employee or volunteer engages in the collection, receipt,
purchase or sale of articles regulated by this chapter.
The results of all background checks shall be provided to the village of Glendale Heights clerk, who shall determine if the applicant and all
employees/volunteers of the business for which the license is sought meet satisfactory standards of good character. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-24: REVOCATION:
It shall be the duty of the village of Glendale Heights police chief to report to the village of Glendale Heights clerk of any failure of a licensee to comply with
any provision of this chapter, and the village of Glendale Heights clerk shall then commence administrative hearing procedures to revoke the license of
such person. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
4-12-25: PENALTY PROVISIONS:
Unless otherwise specifically recited in a given section of this chapter, the penalty for violations of this chapter shall be as provided in the general penalty
provisions of this code and/or revocation of a license issued under this chapter. (Ord. 2012-69, 11-15-2012)
Chapter 13
HOTELS AND MOTELS
4-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
The terms "hotel" and "motel", when used in this chapter, include every building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public
to be a place where lodging, or lodging and food, or suites, or other accommodations are offered for a consideration to guests, in which ten (10) or more
rooms or suites, or other accommodations are used for the lodging, or lodging and food, for such guests. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-1996)
4-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct, keep, manage or operate, or cause to be conducted, kept, managed or operated, a hotel or a motel without having obtained a
license. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-1996)
4-13-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a hotel or motel license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. The
application shall also state the proposed premises where such hotel or motel is located, the number of rooms in such building, which of such rooms in the
building are to be occupied as sleeping rooms, and the number of persons proposed to be accommodated or allowed in each room. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-
1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 121/618
4-13-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL OF LICENSE:
The director of community development shall make or cause to be made such investigations as deemed necessary to determine whether the applicant's
proposed premises complies with all the applicable provisions of this code. No license shall be issued to any applicant whose proposed premises does not
comply with the applicable provisions of this code. Village officials shall indicate on the application for a license the results of their investigation and their
approval or disapproval of the application. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-1996; amd. 2011 Code)
4-13-5: COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS:
No house, building or accessory structure hereafter constructed or erected in the village shall be used as a hotel or motel, and no house, building or
accessory structure hereafter erected and not now used for such purpose, or any building, house, structure or portion thereof which is now used or
intended to be used or occupied for hotel or motel purposes, shall be converted into, used as, or leased for a hotel or motel unless such building and every
part thereof shall conform to the requirements of this chapter and to such other applicable requirements of the building, zoning, housing, fire prevention,
health and sanitation regulations of this code. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-1996)
4-13-6: INSPECTIONS:
The director of community development shall inspect or cause to be inspected, as often as deemed necessary, in accordance with the housing regulations
of this code, every hotel and motel in the village to determine whether there is compliance with all applicable provisions of this code. (Ord. 96-73, 7-25-
1996)
Chapter 14
SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, AND ALTERNATIVE
NICOTINE PRODUCTS
4-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall be defined as provided in this section:
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS: A product or device not consisting of or containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of
nicotine, whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing, or by any other means. The definition of an alternative nicotine
product shall include any cartridge used with or any component of an alternative nicotine product. Alternative nicotine products exclude cigarettes,
smokeless tobacco, or other tobacco products as these terms are defined in this chapter and any product approved by the United States food and drug
administration as a nontobacco product for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is
being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose.
TOBACCO ACCESSORIES: Cigarette papers, pipes, holders of smoking materials of all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items designed
primarily for the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products or of substances made illegal under any statute of the state of Illinois or of substances whose
sale, gift, barter, or exchange is unlawful under any statute of the state of Illinois.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or
dipping tobacco.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment,
dispenses tobacco products. (Ord. 2007-106, 11-1-2007; amd. Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
A. It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give away, deliver, or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away, or delivering,
tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products within the village without having first obtained a tobacco dealers' retail sale of
tobacco license pursuant to chapter 1 of this title. Such license shall be in addition to any other license required by this code.
B. In addition, it shall be unlawful to permit smoking at an establishment which also sells tobacco products, tobacco related products, tobacco accessories,
or alternative nicotine products without having first obtained a tobacco dealers' retail sale of tobacco and smoking license pursuant to chapter 1 of this
title. Such license shall be in addition to any other license required by this code. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
A. Applications for licenses hereunder shall be made in writing and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 1 of this title. (Ord.
2007-106, 11-1-2007)
B. The applicant shall comply with all health and sanitation regulations of the village and the regulations of the village police department. (1978 Code § 3-
11-5)
4-14-4: LICENSE FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 122/618
The license fees for tobacco dealers' licenses shall be as set forth in section 4-2-2 of this title. (Ord. 2007-106, 11-1-2007)
4-14-5: SALES TO MINORS; REQUIRED SIGNAGE:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, or any licensee, including its principal, clerk, agent or servant, to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver
tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine products, or any cartridge or component of an alternative nicotine product to any person
under the age of eighteen (18) years. Provided, however, that delivery of tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine products, or any
cartridge or component of an alternative nicotine product to a person over the age of sixteen (16) years shall not be a violation of this subsection when
such delivery is to an employee of a holder of a tobacco dealers' license for the purpose of resale by the tobacco dealer.
B. Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided herein shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products,
tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products and on or upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or
alternative nicotine products for sale. Each sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, OR ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER
EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, and the lettering shall be at least one inch (1") high. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff.
1-1-2014)
4-14-6: PURCHASE, POSSESSION BY MINORS PROHIBITED:
A. Purchase; False Identification: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase tobacco products, tobacco
accessories, alternative nicotine products or any cartridge or component of an alternative nicotine product, or to misrepresent his identity or age, or to
use any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative nicotine products, or any
cartridge or component of an alternative nicotine product.
B. Possession: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to possess any tobacco products, tobacco accessories, alternative
nicotine products, or any cartridge or component of an alternative nicotine product. Provided, however, that the possession of tobacco products,
tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products by a person under the age of eighteen (18) years under the direct supervision of the parent or
guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-7: PRESENCE OF MINORS ON PREMISES PROHIBITED:
A. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a tobacco dealers' retail sale of tobacco and smoking license, his or her agent or employee to suffer or permit any
person under the age of eighteen (18) years to be or remain in, within, or upon the premises where the sale of tobacco products, tobacco accessories,
or alternative nicotine products are licensed. This subsection shall not apply to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years who is accompanied
by his or her parent or guardian.
B. For the purpose of preventing the violation of this section, any licensee, his agent or employee may refuse to allow entry to the premises or refuse to
sell tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products to any person who is unable to produce adequate written evidence of
identity and of the fact that he or she is over the age of eighteen (18) years, as required by this section. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-8: AGE OF EMPLOYEES:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to engage, employ or permit
any person less than eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products in any licensed premises.
(Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-9: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, tobacco
accessories, or alternative nicotine products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such licensee's or person's
business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products free of charge to any person on any
right of way, park, playground or other property owned by the village, any school district, any park district or any public library; except, the sale of
tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products to persons twenty one (21) years of age or older may occur upon the issuance
of a special license by the village president for distribution or sale in a specific recreation area for a designated time period not to exceed seven (7)
days.
B. 1. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products
within fifty feet (50') of any school, childcare facility or other building used for educational or recreational programs for persons under the age of
eighteen (18) years. The reference points for measuring the distance between the educational or recreational facility and the facility selling tobacco
products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products are as follows:
a. Educational or recreational building: The point of the building closest to the business selling the tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or
alternative nicotine products.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 123/618
b. Business: All entrances to the particular business selling the tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products to which the
general public has access. This does not include service entrances or entrances used only by employees. If the business is open to the public on
all sides, for example a kiosk or stand, the surface of the structure closest to the educational or recreational building will be used.
2. Any premises where access by persons under the age of eighteen (18) years is prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of that business located at such premises shall be exempt from the
requirements of this subsection. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-10: VISIBILITY OF INTERIOR OF PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for the premises upon which the sale of tobacco products, tobacco accessories, or alternative nicotine products are licensed to have,
between the area four feet (4') vertically above ground level and six feet (6') vertically above ground level, running horizontally the entire length of such
premises, any screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing in the window or upon the doors of such licensed premises or inside such premises, which
shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times. No booth, screen, partition or other
obstruction, nor any arrangement of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such licensed premises which shall prevent a full view of
the interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk, and such premises must be so located that there shall be a full view of where tobacco
products, tobacco accessories, and alternative nicotine products are sold. The premises shall be continuously lighted during business hours by natural
light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises are clearly visible. In the event the view into any such licensed premises is wilfully
obscured by the licensee, or any employee or agent of any such licensee, or in any manner obstructed, then such license shall be subject to revocation. In
order to enforce the provisions of this section, the village president shall have the right to require the licensee to file plans, drawings and photographs
showing the clearance of the view as required by this section. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-11: RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSEE FOR EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by an officer, director, manager or other agent or
employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee. Such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or
omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 2007-106, 11-1-2007)
4-14-12: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
A. Administration And Enforcement Official: The village president shall be charged with the administration of this chapter.
B. Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses; Fines In Lieu: The village president may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this
chapter if he or she determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, the
village president may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each
violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
C. Notice Of Suspension Or Revocation; Public Hearing Required: No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except
after seven (7) days' written notice to the licensee affording the licensee a public hearing before the village president and giving the licensee an
opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven (7) day notice provision shall begin the day following
delivery by certified mail or by personal service.
D. Grounds For Determination: The village president shall, within seven (7) days after such hearing and the imposition of a suspension, revocation, or fine,
state in a written order the reason for such determination. The written order shall also state: 1) the duration of any suspension; 2) whether the license
has been revoked; or 3) the amount of any fine. A copy of the written order shall be served upon licensee within the same period.
E. Additional Costs:
1. Any licensee determined by the village president to have violated any of the provisions of this chapter shall pay to the village the costs of the hearing
before the village president for such violation. The village president shall determine the costs incurred by the village for said hearing, including, but
not limited to, court reporter fees, the costs of transcripts of records, attorney fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other
miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the village president may allow.
2. The licensee shall pay said costs to the village within thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the village president. Failure to pay said costs
within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this chapter and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the imposition of a fine.
(Ord. 2009-37, 4-16-2009)
F. Reissuance Of License After Revocation: When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to said licensee for a
period of six (6) months thereafter to conduct the business of selling "tobacco products", "tobacco accessories", or "alternative nicotine products", as
defined in section 4-14-1 of this chapter, within the premises described in such revoked license. (Ord. 2013-67, 11-7-2013, eff. 1-1-2014)
4-14-13: SALE OF BIDI CIGARETTES PROHIBITED:
No person shall sell, give away, barter, exchange or otherwise furnish to any other person a bidi cigarette. As used in this section, "bidi cigarette" means a
product that: a) contains tobacco that is wrapped in tembumi or tendu leaf, or that is wrapped in any other material identified by the United States secretary
of the treasury because the material is similar in appearance or other characteristics to the tembumi or tendu leaf; b) does or does not contain a smoke
filtering device. (Ord. 2000-55, 8-3-2000)
4-14-14: PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 124/618
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for the first offense and succeeding offenses
during the same calendar year, and each day that such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 2000-55, 8-3-2000;
amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 15
VEHICLES FOR HIRE
4-15-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
This chapter is adopted for the following purposes:
A. To encourage the best possible public passenger vehicle service under a competitive system with regulation only to the extent necessary to protect the
safety and welfare of the citizens.
B. To adopt a system of regulation which takes into account and consideration the present day method and operation of public passenger vehicle service
in the area including the use of owner operated vehicles, agency agreements and other contractual relationships between owners and drivers of public
passenger vehicles and companies with dispatching facilities.
C. To assure that public passenger vehicles are clean, comfortable and safe and are operated in accordance with reasonable standards and regulations
for the protection of all passengers.
D. To provide flexibility in the number of public passenger vehicles eligible to service the village provided same comply with the safety standards
established herein.
E. To accomplish the above purposes by licensing of public passenger vehicle dispatching companies and owners of all vehicles for hire with a principal
place of business within the village. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
AGENCY AGREEMENT: A contract or agreement between a dispatching company and a public passenger vehicle owner relating to the use of a public
passenger vehicle in a licensed service area and dispatching services therefor.
CERTIFICATE: A certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the village authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a vehicle for hire business
in the village.
DISPATCHER: A person, firm or corporation licensed to dispatch public passenger vehicles within the village and control the interrelationship of public
passenger vehicles which have a contractual relationship with their dispatching service company.
HOLDER: A person to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been issued.
INSPECTION STATION: Official state of Illinois testing station or such other facility designated by the chief of police to conduct inspections required by this
chapter.
LIMOUSINE/LIVERY VEHICLE: Any privately owned vehicle intended to be used for the transportation of persons for compensation as a result of
individual contract, when the payment is not based on a meter charge, but is prearranged for a designated destination on a trip or hourly basis.
MANIFEST: A daily record prepared by a taxicab driver of all trips made by the driver showing the time and place of origin, destination, number of
passengers and the amount of fare of each trip.
OPEN STAND: A public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere in the village which has been designated by the village as being reserved
exclusively for the use of taxicabs.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE: Vehicles for hire used for transportation of passengers.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE DISPATCHER'S LICENSE: A license issued to any person, firm or corporation who operates a public passenger vehicle
dispatching service under a designated name and which dispatches public passenger vehicles for transportation purposes, whether such public passenger
vehicles are owned by the dispatching company, or by third parties who have agency agreements with the dispatching company.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE DRIVER: Any person who drives a public passenger vehicle.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE OWNER: Any person owning a public passenger vehicle.
RECIPROCAL LICENSING LIST: A list prepared by the chief of police or his designated agent setting forth the names of municipalities who license and/or
inspect public passenger vehicles which licensing and inspection process is deemed acceptable to the village therefore permitting a holder to obtain a
certificate from the village without the need for extensive or duplicate investigations or inspections.
TAXICAB: A motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for compensation, having a seating capacity of less than six (6)
persons and not operated on a fixed route.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 125/618
TAXIMETER: A meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures, mechanically, the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the
fare is based.
VEHICLE FOR HIRE: A "taxicab", "livery vehicle", or "limousine" as defined in this section. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-3: CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY:
A. Certificate Required: No person shall conduct, engage in, maintain, or operate a public passenger vehicle, including a home occupation, or a public
passenger vehicle dispatching service, with a principal place of business within the village without first having obtained a certificate of public
convenience and necessity under this chapter.
B. Application For Certificate: An application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be filed with the village clerk upon forms provided
by the village containing such information as is generally required by the village for all business licenses, and in addition, the following information shall
be furnished:
1. The name and address of the applicant;
2. The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts
giving rise to such judgments;
3. The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers;
4. The number of public passenger vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant or agency agreement with the applicant, the vehicle
identification numbers for each public passenger vehicle, proof that each public passenger vehicle has passed the required safety inspections, and
the location of proposed depots and terminals;
5. The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the applicant's public passenger vehicles;
6. Names and addresses of all public passenger vehicle drivers controlled by the applicant or having an agency agreement with a dispatcher;
7. Certification that all public passenger vehicle drivers meet the requirements of this chapter; and
8. Such further information as the village clerk may require.
Such application shall be verified under oath.
C. Public Hearing; Time; Notice: Upon the filing of an application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the village clerk shall submit the
same to the village board of trustees, and said board shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the
applicant. Due notice shall also be given to the general public by posting a notice of such hearing in the village hall. Any interested person may file with
the village clerk a memorandum in support of or in opposition to the issuance of a certificate.
D. Approval Or Denial Of Application:
1. Approval; Issuance Of Certificate:
a. If the village board of trustees finds that additional public passenger vehicles are required in the village by the public convenience and necessity
and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform such public transportation, and to conform to the provisions of this chapter, then the board
shall direct the village clerk, upon compliance by the applicant with the provisions hereof, to issue a certificate stating the name and address of the
applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under the certificate and the date of issuance.
b. If the village board of trustees finds from the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the issuance of a
certificate, it shall notify the applicant of its findings, and within sixty (60) days thereafter, the applicant shall comply with the further provisions of
this chapter for the issuance of a certificate.
2. Denial: If the village board of trustees finds from its investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the issuance of
a certificate, the board shall forthwith notify the applicant of such finding.
E. Proof Of Financial Responsibility: No certificate shall be issued or continued in operation unless the applicant has complied with all the provisions of the
Illinois vehicle code requiring proof of financial responsibility in the form of an indemnity bond or liability insurance of operators of motor vehicles used
for the transportation of passengers1. Before a certificate is issued, the applicant shall submit to the village clerk a certificate from the Illinois secretary
of state for each motor vehicle to be operated or controlled by the applicant evidencing that proof of financial responsibility for each of such motor
vehicles has been submitted to the Illinois secretary of state.
F. Fee: No certificate shall be issued or continued in operation unless the applicant or the holder has paid an annual fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00);
however, in the case of certificates issued on or after July 1, the applicant shall be required to pay only one-half (1/2) of the fee specified above. The fee
shall, after the initial issuance of the certificate, be paid by January 1 of each year.
G. Transfer Of Certificate: No certificate may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the village board of trustees.
H. Renewal: The issuance of a certificate shall be based on all evidence presented at the public hearing and shall be in the sole discretion of the village
board of trustees. Once issued, the certificate shall automatically be annually renewed (with receipt of annual renewal fee) and remain in existence until
such time as revoked or suspended. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 126/618
4-15-4: LIMOUSINE/LIVERY VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. Certificate Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, engage in, maintain, own, or operate a limousine/livery vehicle either by himself or
through an agent, employee or partner, without first having obtained a certificate as herein provided. Any limousine/livery vehicle licensed, housed and
operated in a municipality other than Glendale Heights is exempt from the provisions of this section.
B. Dispatcher Affiliation: No certificate shall be issued to any livery without an agency agreement with a dispatcher. The agency agreement shall identify
the livery as one under the control and operation of the dispatcher and acknowledge the joint and several obligations imposed upon the holder and the
dispatcher as set forth in this chapter.
C. Drivers: It shall be the responsibility of the holder to immediately update the village with the name and address of all his or its new limousine/livery
vehicle drivers. All drivers must have all required licenses issued by the state of Illinois. A holder shall be responsible for each driver being properly
licensed and their compliance with the regulations and conditions of this chapter.
D. Identification: Each limousine/livery vehicle must display an emblem or certificate issued by the village as an indication of compliance with the licensing
provisions of this chapter. The emblem or certificate shall be displayed as designated by the chief of police.
E. Inspections:
1. Inspection Required: A holder shall submit each limousine/livery vehicle to an inspection station for inspection prior to the issuance of a certificate or
the renewal thereof and shall also submit said vehicle for reinspections during the certificate year. The frequency of reinspections shall be within the
discretion of the chief of police; provided that each limousine/livery vehicle shall be inspected no less than two (2) times per year. Upon notification
from the chief of police or his designated agent, the holder shall submit said vehicle to an inspection station within seven (7) days from the date of
notification.
2. Inspection Stations:
a. The inspection station shall comply with established procedures and criteria for conducting inspections and the minimum standards in order to
approve a vehicle. Said criteria are hereby incorporated by reference into the provisions of this section.
b. A holder may use an inspection station of his choice.
c. A holder is responsible for inspection and reinspection fees.
d. All inspections shall include, but need not be limited to, the following:
(1) Vehicle make, year and vehicle identification number.
(2) State license number and year.
(3) Village vehicle license number and year.
(4) Vehicle color.
(5) Vehicle number.
(6) Company name.
(7) Service brakes.
(8) Emergency brakes.
(9) Horn.
(10) Rearview mirror.
(11) Windshield wipers and washers.
(12) Headlights.
(13) Taillights.
(14) Stoplights.
(15) Turn signals.
(16) Speedometer.
(17) Steering.
(18) Interior condition.
(19) Exterior condition.
(20) Windows.
(21) Tires.
(22) Current bond sticker.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 127/618
Any limousine/livery vehicle failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five (5) working days to allow for repairs. The vehicle cannot
be used as a limousine/livery vehicle until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. If the limousine/livery vehicle does not pass
reinspection within the five (5) working day period, or such longer period as the chief of police, in his discretion, may determine, the
limousine/livery vehicle may not be used as a public passenger vehicle.
e. In lieu of a certificate from an inspection station, a certificate from the reciprocal licensing list will be accepted.
F. Violations: Any holder who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to having his or its certificate suspended or revoked, or be
subject to the payment of a fine, as set forth in section 4-15-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-5: MISCELLANEOUS LIMOUSINE/LIVERY REGULATIONS:
The following regulations shall apply to the owners and/or operators of all limousine/livery vehicles. It shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or
operator of said vehicles, as well as the dispatcher to ensure compliance with the following provisions:
A. Condition Of Vehicle: In addition to the inspection requirements of the proceeding section, each limousine/livery vehicle shall be safe for operation at all
times and shall not be damaged, deteriorated or otherwise be in a condition so as to render said vehicle unfit for use as a public passenger vehicle.
B. Number Of Passengers: No limousine/livery vehicle shall carry more than the rated passenger load per vehicle.
C. Receipts: On request, any person paying a fare shall be entitled to a receipt indicating the amount paid.
D. Conduct Of Driver: It shall be unlawful for any on duty driver or operator of a limousine/livery vehicle to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs or to
use any profane or obscene language to or in the presence of any passenger.
E. Advertising: It shall be unlawful for any limousine/livery vehicle to advertise or affix signs to said vehicle for the purpose of advertising businesses or
commercial uses unrelated to said livery company. This includes any limousine/livery vehicle stored or parked within the village regardless of whether it
is regulated under this chapter.
F. Holding Areas: Limousine/livery vehicles shall not park in open stands.
G. Scope Of Operations: Limousine/livery vehicles shall not pick up or solicit passengers from the streets, but are limited in scope of operation to carrying
passengers on a contract basis at a price agreed upon prior to employment and by arrangement of the parties at the time of initial contact.
H. Prohibited Material Conveyance: It shall be unlawful for any limousine/livery vehicle to convey toxic, hazardous or biological waste material at any time.
(Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-6: TAXICAB VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. Certificate Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate or lease a taxicab within the corporate limits of the village without first having
obtained a certificate in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
B. Dispatcher Affiliation: No certificate shall be issued to any taxicab without a dispatcher or agency agreement with a dispatcher. The agency agreement
must identify the taxicab as one under the control and operation of the dispatcher and acknowledge the joint and several obligations imposed upon the
holder and dispatcher as set forth in this chapter.
C. Insurance: It shall be the responsibility of the holder to ensure that each taxicab has a policy of insurance or certificate of insurance indicating coverage
for personal injury in an amount of not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) per person, five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) per accident, and not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in full force and effect during the certificate
period or a portion thereof subject to notification of renewal. In the event that such policy or certificate of insurance becomes ineffective or expires or in
the event a holder has failed to deposit a currently valid certificate or policy of insurance, the certificate herein provided for shall automatically terminate
without further notice.
D. Drivers: It shall be the responsibility of a holder to immediately update the village with the name and address of his or its new taxicab drivers. All drivers
must have all required licenses issued by the state of Illinois. A holder shall be responsible for each driver being properly licensed and their compliance
with the regulations and conditions of this chapter.
E. Identification: Each side of every taxicab shall have, in letters identifiable from a minimum distance of twenty feet (20'), the name of the taxicab
company which the taxicab is associated with, the telephone number of said company, and the number which the company has assigned to the
taxicab. In addition, each taxicab must display an emblem or certificate issued by the village as an indication of initial compliance with the provisions of
this chapter. The emblem or certificate shall be displayed as designated by the chief of police or his designated agent.
F. Taximeter: Each taxicab shall be equipped with an approved, accurate and inspected taximeter to register, in plain view of the passenger and with
proper illumination, the fare as accumulated while said taxicab is in operation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 128/618
G. Inspections:
1. Inspection Required: A holder shall submit each taxicab for inspection to an inspection station prior to the issuance of a certificate or the renewal
thereof and shall also submit said vehicle for reinspections during the certificate year. The frequency of reinspections shall be within the discretion of
the chief of police; provided that each taxicab will be inspected no less than one time per year. Upon notification from the chief of police or his
designated agent, a holder shall submit said vehicle to an inspection station within seven (7) days from the date of notification.
2. Inspection Stations:
a. The inspection station shall comply with established procedures and criteria for conducting inspections and the minimum standards in order to
approve a vehicle. Said criteria are hereby incorporated by reference into the provisions of this section.
b. A holder may use inspection stations of his choice.
c. A holder is responsible for inspection and reinspection fees.
d. A list of inspection stations shall be given to each holder, together with the notice that taxicabs must be inspected.
e. All inspections shall include, but need not be limited to, the following:
(1) Vehicle, make, year and vehicle identification number.
(2) State license number and year.
(3) Village vehicle license number and year.
(4) Vehicle color.
(5) Vehicle number.
(6) Company name.
(7) Service brakes.
(8) Emergency brakes.
(9) Horn.
(10) Rearview mirror.
(11) Windshield wipers and washers.
(12) Headlights.

(17) Taximeter.
(18) Rates displayed.
(19) Steering.
(20) Interior condition.
(21) Exterior condition.
(22) Windows.
(23) Tires.
(24) Current bond sticker.
Any taxicab failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five (5) working days to allow for repairs. The vehicle cannot be used as a
taxicab until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. If the taxicab does not pass reinspection within the five (5) working day
period, or such longer period as the chief of police, in his discretion, may determine, the taxicab may not be used as a public passenger vehicle.
f. In lieu of a certificate from an inspection station, a certificate from the reciprocal licensing list will be accepted.
H. Violations: Any holder who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to having his or its certificate suspended or revoked, or be
subject to the payment of a fine, as set forth in section 4-15-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-7: MISCELLANEOUS TAXICAB REGULATIONS:
The following regulations shall apply to the owner and/or operators of all taxicabs. It shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or operators of said
vehicles, as well as the dispatcher to ensure compliance with the following provisions:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 129/618
A. Condition Of Vehicle: In addition to the inspection requirements of the preceding section, each taxicab shall be safe for operation at all times and shall
not be damaged, deteriorated or otherwise be in a condition so as to render said vehicle unfit for use as a public passenger vehicle.
B. Number Of Passengers: No taxicab shall carry more than the rated passenger load per vehicle.
C. Established Rates And Charges: All rates and charges for taxicab service in the village of Glendale Heights provided by dispatcher and taxicabs shall
be fair, reasonable and competitive. The dispatcher shall provide the village with a schedule of its rates, including meter rates and fixed rates for trips to
O'Hare and Midway Airports. The village shall be notified of any change in the designated rates in writing thirty (30) days in advance of the date the
change occurs. The village shall have the right to publish the rates to its residents in such form or manner as deemed appropriate by the village.
D. Posting Established Rates And Charges: There shall be affixed on the inside of each taxicab in a conspicuous place and in such manner that the same
may be easily and conveniently read by any person riding in such taxicab, a card in a frame covered by glass or other transparent material setting forth
the rates of fare as prescribed by the preceding subsection.
E. Inspection Of Taximeters:
1. No taximeter shall be attached to a taxicab unless it has been inspected by an inspector approved by the chief of police and found to be accurate
and sealed by such inspector. A holder shall keep certificates of accuracy issued by the inspector for each taximeter in each taxicab and provide the
same for inspection by a passenger or any police officer upon request. The expense for such inspections shall be that of the holder.
2. Each taximeter shall be inspected annually not more than thirty (30) days prior to December 31, or such other date set by the chief of police or his
designee, and a certificate of accuracy, as provided above, shall be submitted by the holder to the village prior to the renewal of the certificate. In the
event a complaint is made that any taximeter registers improperly or inaccurately, the chief of police or his designee shall immediately examine and
inspect or cause such examination and inspection of such taximeter complained of. Upon request by the chief of police, the holder shall submit any
taximeter installed on a taxicab to an inspection to determine its accuracy.
F. Demand For Service: Each holder is responsible for each taxicab operating under its control to regularly and daily operate taxicabs in the village to the
extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demand for such taxicab service, including a twenty four (24) hour telephone service. Reasonable
service shall be further interpreted to require a thirty (30) minute maximum response time for each call for taxicab service.
G. Passenger Service: It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who seeks taxicab service, provided such
person is not intoxicated and conducts himself in an orderly manner. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab already occupied by a passenger without
the consent of said passenger. The driver shall transport his passenger to the point of destination by the most direct available route from the point of
origin.
H. Receipts: On request, any person paying a fare shall be entitled to a receipt indicating the amount paid.
I. Conduct Of Driver: It shall be unlawful for any on duty driver or operator of a taxicab to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs or to use any profane
or obscene language to or in the presence of any passenger.
J. Taxicab Stands: Taxicabs without passengers and waiting for a dispatched assignment must do so at an open stand.
K. Exclusive Permission Granted/Interurban Operations: Subject to the conditions and limitations of this chapter, exclusive permission and authority are
hereby granted to holders to operate a taxicab upon the public streets and other public ways within the corporate limits of the village unless suspended
or revoked.
L. Advertising: It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to advertise or affix signs to said vehicle for the purpose of advertising businesses or commercial uses
unrelated to said taxicab company. This subsection includes any taxicabs stored or parked within the village regardless of whether it is regulated under
this chapter.
M. Prohibited Material Conveyance: It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to convey toxic, hazardous or biological waste material at any time.
N. Manifests:
1. Every taxicab driver shall maintain a manifest. All such completed manifests shall be returned to holder by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of
duty. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished to the driver by the holder and shall be of a character approved by the village board of trustees.
2. A holder shall retain and preserve all manifests in a safe place for one calendar year. The manifests shall be available to the police department.
O. Advance Payment: A holder or taxicab driver shall have the right to demand his fare of the person so employing him upon entering his vehicle, and may
refuse to convey any person who shall not comply with the demand.
P. Refusal Of Passenger To Pay Fare: It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any public passenger vehicle operating pursuant
to this chapter after having hired the same, and it shall be unlawful for any person to hire any public passenger vehicle with intent to defraud the person
from whom it is hired of the value of such service. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 130/618
4-15-8: DRIVERS:
A. Driver Meets Requirements: No holder shall permit its public passenger vehicles to be operated in the village unless the holder or public passenger
vehicle driver has first certified, under oath, to the village that the public passenger vehicle driver meets the requirements set forth in this chapter.
B. Qualifications: Public passenger vehicle drivers shall meet the following qualifications:
1. Be twenty one (21) years of age or over;
2. Be of sound health with good eyesight, and not subject to any disease or infirmity of body or mind which might render him unfit for the safe operation
of a public passenger vehicle;
3. Be able to read, write and speak the English language;
4. Be clean in dress and person and not addicted to the use of drugs or intoxicating liquors;
5. Not have been convicted of a felony, class A misdemeanor, or crime of moral turpitude;
6. Have a secretary of state's driving abstract showing no convictions for any of the following offenses:
a. Driving under the influence of a controlled substance, cannabis or an intoxicating compound2 or similar provision of a local ordinance or any like
offense of another state or country within the past five (5) years;
b. Reckless driving3 or a similar provision of a local ordinance or any like offense of another state or country, within the past five (5) years;
7. Must not have had his driver's license suspended or revoked in any state within the past three (3) years as a consequence of violations of law
concerning his operation of a motor vehicle; and
8. Possess all valid licenses issued by the state of Illinois.
C. Conduct And Appearance:
1. No on duty public passenger vehicle driver shall use any profane or obscene language or gestures, shout or call to prospective passengers, or
engage in violent, abusive, indecent, profane, boisterous, or unreasonably loud conduct.
2. Every public passenger vehicle driver shall maintain a reasonable degree of personal hygiene and be dressed in clean clothing that is not soiled or
otherwise offensive. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
4-15-9: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, FINE:
Any holder or public passenger vehicle driver who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to having his certificate or privileges suspended or
revoked, or having a fine imposed subsequent to the procedures set forth in title 1, chapter 4, article A of this code. At such hearing, the chief of police or
his designated agent shall provide evidence relative to the cited violation and the accused may provide such testimony, evidence or explanation as the
accused deems necessary. After hearing the evidence presented, the hearing officer may suspend, revoke and/or fine up to one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) any person which the hearing officer finds liable of violating any provision of this chapter; or in the alternative render a finding of not liable as
the case may be. In cases where the public health, safety and welfare is jeopardized by such violation, the chief of police may temporarily suspend said
certificate or privileges pending a hearing before the hearing officer. In addition, the chief of police or his designated agent is authorized to resolve or abate
minor violations without the need for a hearing and without the imposition of suspension, revocation or fine. Notwithstanding the above, a certificate or
privileges shall automatically be suspended for violations relating to ineffective insurance or upon the finding of false information submitted on any
application form. Appeals of automatic suspensions may be made to the village board of trustees and shall be held in accordance with the provisions of
this section. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
Chapter 16
AUCTIONS
4-16-1: CONDUCT OF AUCTIONS:
A. No person, other than an auctioneer or employee named in the license application for operation of an auction, may conduct an auction. Each auctioneer
may have no more than two (2) employees on the same license.
B. No action shall be conducted on the public streets or ways of the village.
C. This section shall not apply to public officers acting within their official capacity pursuant to judicial orders or ordinances or resolutions of any public
body politic nor to sale of real estate pursuant to a mortgage or trust deed. (1978 Code § 3-1-23)
Chapter 17
HOUSE AND GARAGE SALES
4-17-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 131/618
No person shall sell, offer for sale or conduct the sale of any junk, secondhand, antique or other used or discarded items of personal property from any
residence in the village or from any area classified as residential in the village zoning ordinance without first obtaining a permit therefor. Included within the
terms of this section shall be sales commonly known as "house sales", "attic sales", "garage sales" and "basement sales". The provisions of this section
shall not apply to bankruptcy, estate or other sales under judicial process and sales conducted from church, school, homeowner association or civic
property by not for profit organizations. (1978 Code § 3-6-1)
4-17-2: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; FEE AND CONTENTS:
The village clerk is authorized to issue a permit required by this chapter to any resident upon compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the
payment of a ten dollar ($10.00) fee. Said permit shall list, in addition to the applicant, all other persons participating in such sales by name and address,
and the village clerk shall keep a record of all participants which shall be checked prior to the issuance of a permit. (Ord. 2002-81, 10-3-2002; amd. Ord.
2011-53, 8-18-2011)
4-17-3: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF PERMITS PER YEAR:
No person shall be permitted to conduct a house or garage sale from his premises or participate in a garage or house sale conducted by another resident
more than four (4) times during any calendar year. No more than four (4) permits shall be issued to any person as a permit holder or permit participant
during any calendar year for the purpose of conducting or participating in such house or garage sale. (Ord. 2002-81, 10-3-2002)
4-17-4: PERMIT FOR DESIGNATED SALE ONLY; POSTING REQUIRED; NONTRANSFERABILITY:
A permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid only for the particular sale and premises designated on the permit. The permit shall be posted in the
front yard area so as to be easily seen by the police and shall be nontransferable. (1978 Code § 3-6-3)
4-17-5: DAYS AND HOURS OF SALES:
Sales regulated by this chapter shall be limited to a period of three (3) consecutive days and shall be conducted only during the period from nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. (Ord. 2002-81, 10-3-2002)
4-17-6: ADVERTISING SIGNS:
A. Location: All signs advertising any sale held pursuant to this chapter shall be located on private property and shall comply with all pertinent ordinances
of the village relating to signs. No such sign or other advertising matter shall be located or posted in any public park or building in the village. (Ord.
2002-81, 10-3-2002; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Information Required: The garage sale signs must contain the following information:
1. The day of the sale;
2. The hours of the sale; and
3. The address where the sale is to take place.
C. Removal: All garage sale signs authorized under this chapter shall be removed no later than eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on the last day of the sale. In the
event all garage sale signs authorized under this chapter are not removed prior to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on the last day of the sale as provided in
this subsection, the village shall impose a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per sign for each day the sign is displayed beyond the last day of the sale
on each garage sale permit applicant. (Ord. 2002-81, 10-3-2002)
4-17-7: PROHIBITIONS:
A. Sales Held By Other Than Owner/Occupant: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter who is not the owner of the
premises where such sale is held.
B. Selling Business: It shall be unlawful for anyone to conduct a retail selling business pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter or to engage in any
sales other than those of junk, secondhand, antique or other used or discarded items of property.
C. Location: No sales regulated by this chapter and no sale items shall be located in the front yard area of any residence or on any public sidewalk or
parkway area.
D. Use Of Loudspeakers And Amplifiers: No sale held pursuant to this chapter shall be conducted with the use of outdoor loudspeakers or other
amplification equipment. (1978 Code § 3-6-3)
4-17-8: REVOCATION OF PERMIT OR RIGHT TO PERMIT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 132/618
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the immediate revocation of the permit under which said person is a
permit holder or permit participant, and shall be further subject to the loss of the privilege of obtaining a permit or of having the right to participate in such
permit in the future. (1978 Code § 3-6-4)
Title 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
Chapter 1
FOOD AND FOOD SERVICE
5-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
FOOD: Beverages, other than alcoholic liquor, as well as food.
FOOD DEALER: Every person engaged in the sale of food or beverages, other than intoxicating liquor, intended for human consumption.
RESTAURANT: Any place where food or drink, other than alcoholic liquor, is prepared or served to the public for consumption on the premises or is sold in
a fully prepared form. (1978 Code § 9-1-1)
5-1-2: SALE OF UNWHOLESOME, ADULTERATED FOODS PROHIBITED:
A. Unwholesome Food: No person shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human
consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any reason.
B. Adulterated Food: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, or keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which has
been adulterated by any material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with state law governing the same. (1978 Code § 9-1-2)
5-1-3: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD OR DRINK:
Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the director of community development or other officer designated by the
village board of trustees as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The director of community development or
other officer designated by the village board may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is
unwholesome or adulterated. (1978 Code § 9-1-3; amd. 2011 Code)
5-1-4: PERSONS HANDLING FOOD:
A. All persons engaged in handling food or coming in contact with food intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to
person and clothing.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or
preparation of any food. It shall be unlawful to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared or sold,
or to deliver such food. (1978 Code § 9-1-4)
ARTICLE A. FOOD DEALERS
5-1A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION AND FEE:
It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without first having secured a license therefor. Application for such license
shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this code relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled. Such
license shall not be issued by the village unless the applicant presents, or has presented on his behalf, to the village clerk, satisfactory evidence of the
possession of a valid permit from the county board of health. The license fee shall be determined by the square footage area of the business as provided
in section 4-2-1 of this code. (1978 Code § 3-8-1)
5-1A-2: GENERAL SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit
any accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind to remain therein for more than twenty four (24) hours, and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying
animal or plant material to remain on such premises. No dogs, cats or other animals shall be permitted on such premises. Premises used for the storage,
preparation or sale of food intended for human consumption shall also be kept free from flies, vermin and rodents. (1978 Code § 3-8-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 133/618
5-1A-3: INSPECTIONS:
