Title 6
POLICE AND PUBLIC SAFETY
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 159/618
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
6-1-1: CREATED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby created a police department in and for the village, said police department to consist of the chief of police, who shall be ex officio village
marshal, a deputy chief of police, and such sergeants, patrol officers and other police officers, auxiliary police, and other employees as the village
president and board of trustees may determine to be necessary as provided in the annual budget for the village. There is also hereby established the
exempt rank of commander, the number of such commanders to be determined from time to time by the president and board of trustees as provided in
said annual budget. (Ord. 2006-45, 8-17-2006)
6-1-2: ORGANIZATION:
The police department shall be organized and shall function as provided by the rules and regulations and subject to the control of the village authorities
and as may be provided by ordinance and applicable provisions of state law. (1978 Code § 10-1-2)
6-1-3: APPOINTMENTS, PROMOTIONS AND DISCHARGES:
A. Appointments And Promotions: Appointments and promotions within the police department, other than to the office of chief of police or to the exempt
rank of deputy chief of police or commander, shall be made by the board of police commissioners in the manner provided by state law. All original
appointments, except those exempt ranks stated hereinabove, shall be for a probationary period of eighteen (18) months and can be terminated at any
time during such period without a hearing upon a report and recommendation by the chief of police that the applicant has been deemed to be
unqualified or unfit to serve as a police officer. (1978 Code § 10-1-3)
B. Discharges: No police officer shall be discharged from the police department except after a hearing on written charges before the board of police
commissioners as provided by law; provided, however, this shall not be construed as affecting the power of the village president and board of trustees
to appoint and remove the chief of police. (1978 Code § 10-1-5)
6-1-4: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, each police officer of the village shall take and execute the proper oath of office. (Ord. 2006-45, 8-17-2006)
6-1-5: CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of chief of police.
B. Appointment; Term; Removal: The chief of police shall be appointed by the village president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, and shall serve at their pleasure. He/she shall hold office for such a term as established by the board of trustees, but said term shall not
exceed the term of the village president in office at the time of the appointment as chief of police and thereafter until a successor is appointed and
qualified, during which said time he/she shall have the same rights, powers and duties as hereinafter provided for the chief of police. However, if no
chief of police is appointed and approved within sixty (60) days following the taking of office of the village president after an election, the incumbent
chief of police shall not continue in office, and that position shall be declared vacant until a successor is appointed and qualified. If the person
appointed chief of police was, at the time of such promotion, a member of the police department, then said individual shall retain his/her status and
rank while serving as chief and shall revert to such status and rank when said term as chief has ended.
C. Residency: The chief of police shall, within twelve (12) months of his/her appointment to that position, become a permanent, full time resident of the
village. The chief of police shall, for his/her entire tenure in that position with the village, remain a permanent, full time resident of the village.
D. General Powers And Duties: The chief of police shall be the chief executive officer of the police department. The chief of police shall be responsible for
the management and fiscal management of the police department, including the direction and control of operations and administration, subject to the
supervision of the village administrator. As such, he shall have the custody, care and control of the public property of the police department, all
firearms, and all fixed and mobile equipment assigned to the police department. The chief of police shall devote his whole time to the municipal affairs
of the village to preserve the peace, order, safety and cleanliness thereof, and to this end, he shall execute and enforce all village ordinances and all
orders of the president and board of trustees. In addition, the chief of police shall execute, or cause to be executed, all orders of the president and
board of trustees or village administrator so far as they relate to the preservation of public health, and shall be charged with the duty of protecting the
rights of persons and the protection of property in the village and of providing a proper police force at every conflagration or disaster. The chief of police
shall make rules and regulations as well as general orders and operating procedures governing the conduct of members and operations of the police
department. In addition, the chief of police shall designate one or more ordained ministers to serve as voluntary police chaplains, without pay, and he
shall define their duties.
E. Reports Required: The chief of police shall, prior to the first meeting of the village board of trustees in March of each year, make an annual report in
writing on the state of the police department with a detailed report of the transactions of the department for the preceding calendar year, with such
statistics and suggestions in regard to the requirements of the department as he may deem advisable. He shall also make reports of any matter
concerning the police department whenever requested by the village president or board of trustees.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 160/618
F. Record Of Prisoners Kept: It shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep a record of the names of all persons arrested or committed to the county jail
in a book to be provided for such purpose. The record shall show the date of arrest or committal, the number of days imprisoned, the amount of the
fine, when and to whom paid, and the date of discharge or other disposition of such persons. (Ord. 2013-61, 10-3-2013)
6-1-6: DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Position Created; Appointment; Qualifications; Compensation: There is hereby created the position of deputy chief of police. The deputy chief of police
shall be appointed by and shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police. The deputy chief of police shall have been a sworn police officer of the
department prior to his appointment as deputy chief of police. He shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed by the president and board of
trustees. (1978 Code § 10-1-14-1)
B. Powers And Duties: The deputy chief of police shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and shall provide those services as required by the
chief of police. In the event the chief of police is not able to perform his duties, the deputy chief of police shall have the same powers and duties
generally as that of chief of police. (1978 Code § 10-1-14-2)
6-1-7: COMMANDER:
A. Position Created; Appointment; Compensation: The position of commander is hereby created. Each commander shall be appointed by and shall serve
at the discretion of the chief of police. The position of commander shall be exempt from the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et
seq., and all appointments to the position of commander shall be made at the discretion of the chief of police, without the advice or consent of the
board of police commissioners. Commanders shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed by the president and board of trustees.
B. Qualifications; Examination:
1. Each commander shall have been a sworn police officer of the department holding the rank of sergeant immediately prior to his or her appointment
by the chief of police. Prior to such appointment to the position of commander, in order to establish the minimum qualifications for the position of
commander, each commander shall have been required to obtain a passing grade upon a written examination which is to be administered by an
outside testing agency to be designated by the chief of police, and a passing grade for an oral exercise, to be conducted by a minimum three (3)
member panel. The panel shall consist of the chief of police and at least two (2) persons employed or previously employed by police agencies other
than the village of Glendale Heights. After the administration of the written examination and the oral exercise, all candidates for the position of
commander who have received the minimum passing grades shall be evaluated by the chief of police. The chief of police shall make the appointment
after having obtained the approval of the village administrator.
2. Appointments to the position of commander shall be made by the chief of police without the necessity of new written exams or oral exercises, if such
appointment is made within two (2) years of the date upon which the last written exam for such position was conducted.
C. Removal: In the event the chief of police determines to remove any officer from the position of commander, the chief of police shall be required to obtain
the approval of the village administrator. Upon termination of the appointment to the position of commander by the chief of police, the officer shall revert
to and be established in the rank of sergeant which he held immediately prior to his appointment as commander, and thereafter shall be entitled to all
benefits and emoluments of such prior rank, without regard as to whether a vacancy then exists in such rank. (Ord. 2000-21, 4-6-2000)
6-1-8: POWERS AND DUTIES OF POLICE:
A. Serve Processes: Any regular member of the police department shall have power and authority, and it shall be his duty to serve and execute warrants
and other processes for the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with the violation of any village ordinance or any crime, misdemeanor
or offense against the peace of the state or the village or held for examination or trial, or taken on execution for the commission of any crime,
misdemeanor or violation of any law or ordinance of the village, and while serving or executing or assisting in the service or execution of any such
warrant or process, he shall be vested with and have all the powers and authority conferred on constables by the common laws and laws of the state.
(1978 Code § 10-1-6)
B. Assist Fire Department: It shall be the duty of the police department to aid all fire departments providing service to the village by giving alarm in case of
fire and by clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of the fire so that the members of the fire department shall not be hindered or
obstructed in the performance of their duties. (Ord. 2013-15, 4-18-2013)
C. Arrest And Detain: The members of the village police department are hereby authorized to arrest, with or without process, or on view, any person who
shall break the peace or is found violating any ordinance of the village or any criminal law of the state, and to take such person before a court of
competent jurisdiction, or if necessary, to detain such person in custody overnight or on Sunday in any safe place until he can be brought before a court
of competent jurisdiction.
D. Appear As Witnesses; Fees: All police officers making arrests shall appear as witnesses before the court where the trial may be had, shall procure all
necessary evidence in their power, and furnish a list of witnesses to the court and the village attorney, and no village officer shall be entitled to any
witness fees to be taxed against the village in any action for the violation of an ordinance where the village is plaintiff.
E. Temporary Questioning: A police officer, after having first identified his office, may stop any person in any public place for a reasonable period when that
person is wearing known gang colors, gang emblems or other gang insignia or identification or reasonably appears to be engaged in the
communication of gang related messages or signals through the use of hand signals, commonly known as "gang signs" or other means of
communication, or as otherwise provided by law, and the officer has probable cause to believe from the totality of the circumstances that the person is
committing, is about to commit, or has committed any offense under the ordinances of the village of Glendale Heights or under the laws of the state of
Illinois. Once stopped, the officer may make reasonable inquiry as to the circumstances of the stop and may demand the name and address of the
person and an explanation of his activities. Such detention and temporary questioning shall be conducted in the vicinity where the person is stopped
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 161/618
whenever practicable. Whenever a police officer has stopped a person for temporary questioning pursuant to this subsection and the officer has reason
to believe that his or another officer's safety may be jeopardized or reasonably believes that he or another officer is in danger of attack, he may search
the person for weapons. Any lawfully possessed weapon discovered at the time of said search shall be returned to that person upon the completion of
questioning. (1978 Code § 10-1-6)
6-1-9: WORKERS' COMPENSATION:
All duly appointed police officers of the village shall be considered to be employees of the village, within the meaning of the state workers' compensation
act, and as such, shall be entitled to the benefits and protection thereof. (1978 Code § 10-1-7)
6-1-10: POLICE PENSION FUND:
Pursuant to the provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 through 5/3-149, there is hereby established a police pension fund for the benefit of the
members of the police department of the village. (1978 Code § 10-1-11; amd. 2011 Code)
6-1-11: TRAINING:
A. Village Participate In State Training Program: The village hereby elects to participate in the police training program provided in the Illinois police training
act. (1978 Code § 10-1-10)
B. Regular Members To Complete Training Course: No person shall be appointed to the regular police department of the village as a permanent police
officer until he has been certified by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board as having successfully completed an approved training
course, as provided in the Illinois police training act, and within a probationary period not to exceed one year.
C. Board Of Police Commissioners To Require Training In Its Rules: The board of police commissioners shall provide in its rules that any person appointed
to the police department of the village shall not become a regular member of said police department until he has completed the training course required
by this section not later than eighteen (18) months after the date of his initial employment. (1978 Code § 10-1-10; amd. 2011 Code)
D. Costs: All costs expended by the village and not reimbursed, on the accomplishment of the police training program by a person appointed as a
probationary police officer of the village, shall be repaid, in full, by said person to the village in the event that said person should leave the employment
of the village prior to the end of one year following his completion of the police training program and obtains employment with another police
department or police agency or organization involving police or investigative work. Each person, as a requirement of his employment as a probationary
police officer of the village, shall execute an agreement with the village, on a form provided by the village for this purpose, as a contract and agreement
by said person to reimburse the village for such police training program costs as provided in this subsection. (1978 Code § 10-1-10)
6-1-12: DUTY TO ASSIST POLICE:
It shall be the duty of every citizen in the village, when called upon by any member of the police department, to promptly aid and assist such officer in the
execution of his police duties. (1978 Code § 10-1-8; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE A. PART TIME POLICE CORPS
6-1A-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established in the village a part time police corps consisting of such number of part time police officers, who shall serve the village as
employees, as the corporate authorities shall from time to time deem necessary. (Ord. 2008-51, 8-7-2008)
6-1A-2: APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL:
The village president is hereby authorized to appoint, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, part time police officers as employees. Prior to
the appointment becoming effective, all proposed part time police officers shall be fingerprinted, and their fingerprints shall be checked by the Illinois state
police and the federal bureau of investigation for any possible criminal record. In addition, all proposed part time police officers shall submit to a polygraph
and psychological testing. The appointment of all part time police officers may be terminated by the village president at any time. The employment of all
part time police officers shall be considered "at will". (Ord. 2008-51, 8-7-2008)
6-1A-3: MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:
Appointed part time police officers shall meet the following hiring standards:
A. Must be a U.S. citizen;
B. Must be twenty one (21) years of age or older;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 162/618
C. Must possess a high school diploma or GED equivalency;
D. Must have a valid Illinois driver's license;
E. Must have eyesight of 20/20, or correctable to 20/20;
F. Must not be colorblind;
G. Must be in good physical health and able to pass Illinois law enforcement training standards board POWER test;
H. Must be able to pass a physical examination by a licensed medical doctor prior to the physical agility test, or have a valid waiver issued by a licensed
medical doctor stating that the applicant is capable of participating in a physical agility test;
I. Must be certified by the state, within one year of the date of appointment, demonstrating: 1) completion of four hundred (400) hours of law enforcement
training; 2) completion of the basic part time law enforcement officer training program as approved by the Illinois law enforcement training standards
board; or 3) certification from another U.S. state that is equivalent to the state of Illinois training standards;
J. Must not have a felony conviction, or any findings of guilty pertaining to other crimes involving moral turpitude, as determined in the sole discretion of the
village1; and
K. Must meet all standards set forth in the firearm owners identification card act2. (Ord. 2008-51, 8-7-2008)
6-1A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Part time police officers shall be members of the village police department, except for pension purposes. The number of hours a part time police officer
may work within a calendar year is restricted to no more than one thousand (1,000) hours. Part time police officers shall not be assigned to direct or
supervise full time police officers, nor shall they be used as permanent replacements for full time police officers. Part time police officers shall be peace
officers and conferred upon them shall be those powers and duties granted by law. Part time police officers shall enforce the ordinances of the village and
laws of the state of Illinois. They shall preserve order, prevent infractions of the law, and arrest violators of the laws of the state of Illinois and ordinances of
the village. (Ord. 2012-39, 6-7-2012)
6-1A-5: TRAINING:
Part time police officers shall be trained under the intergovernmental law enforcement officer's in-service training act in accordance with the procedures for
part time police officers established by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board. A part time police officer hired after January 1, 1996, who has
not yet received certification under section 8.2 of the Illinois police training act, shall be directly supervised. (Ord. 2008-51, 8-7-2008)
6-1A-6: FAMILIARIZATION WITH RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Part time police officers shall familiarize themselves with, and be subject to and obey, all ordinances and other rules, regulations, and policies and
procedures governing the conduct and operation of the village police department. (Ord. 2008-51, 8-7-2008)
ARTICLE B. AUXILIARY POLICE CORPS
6-1B-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established in the village an auxiliary police corps consisting of such number of auxiliary police officers, who shall serve the village as
employees, without pay, as the corporate authorities shall from time to time deem necessary. (1978 Code § 10-1-12-1)
6-1B-2: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
Auxiliary police officers shall be appointed by the village president, subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and shall hold such
appointments for a term of one year, or until the same shall be terminated at the discretion of the village president, with the consent of the board of
trustees. (1978 Code § 10-1-12-2)
6-1B-3: NOT POLICE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS; UNIFORM AND IDENTIFICATION:
Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police department of the village and shall wear a uniform and identification symbol prescribed
by the chief of police, which uniform and symbol shall be different and distinct from that worn by the members of the regular police department. (1978
Code § 10-1-12-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 163/618
6-1B-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police and shall have
the following powers and duties which shall only be exercisable when properly assigned to them and when on duty and in uniform:
A. To aid in directing traffic in the village;
B. To aid in the control of natural or manmade disasters;
C. To aid in case of civil disorder; and
D. To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the chief of police on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the regular
police department to perform normal and regular police duties, except those duties granted to a conservator of the peace. (Ord. 2008-22, 3-20-2008)
6-1B-5: USE OF FIREARMS, IDENTIFICATION CARD AND BADGE RESTRICTED:
Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms, except with the permission of the chief of police, and except when in uniform and in the performance of
their duties, nor shall they use their police identification card or badge to effectuate an arrest at any time. (Ord. 2008-22, 3-20-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
6-1B-6: TRAINING AND FAMILIARIZATION WITH RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Auxiliary police officers, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures by
the village chief of police or his designee, and shall familiarize themselves with and be subject to and obey all ordinances and other rules, regulations,
policies and procedures governing the conduct and operation of the regular police department of the village. (1978 Code § 10-1-12-6)
6-1B-7: TERMINATION FOR VIOLATIONS:
Violation of any of the rules, regulations, policies and procedures of the regular village police department or of any of the provisions of this article shall
subject an auxiliary police officer to termination of his appointment. (1978 Code § 10-1-12-7)
ARTICLE C. COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICER
6-1C-1: POSITION CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is hereby created in the village the position of community service officer to be hired by the village president and board of trustees to assist the
village police department in the accomplishment of certain jobs and functions which do not require the power and authority of a police officer. Such officer
shall function so as to allow the members of the village police department more time to perform police and public safety duties for the health, welfare and
safety of the citizens of the community. (1978 Code § 10-1-13-1)
6-1C-2: POLICE CHIEF SUPERVISION; UNIFORM AND IDENTIFICATION; WEAPONS:
Persons employed in the position of community service officer shall be placed under the supervision of the chief of police and shall be assigned such tasks
as the chief deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article. Such officer shall wear a uniform and identification symbol prescribed by the chief of
police, which uniform and symbol shall be different and distinct from that worn by the members of the regular police department, part time police corps and
auxiliary police corps. Such officer, as a civilian employee, shall not carry a firearm or other weapon. (1978 Code § 10-1-13-2; amd. 2011 Code)
6-1C-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A community service officer shall, at all times during the performance of his or her duties, be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police, and
such officer shall perform his or her duties only when the same have been properly assigned by the chief of police and only during duty periods and while
in uniform. Powers and duties of a community service officer shall be of a nonpolice nature and shall not include any power ordinarily given to the regular
police officers by the ordinances of the village or this code or by state statutes to preserve the peace, to enforce laws and ordinances, to investigate
crimes, to direct traffic, to serve warrants and summons, to make searches or seizures of property, to make arrests, or to issue traffic citations for moving
traffic violations. Community service officers may be assigned to and may perform the following duties, which, by being specifically set forth, are not
intended herein to be exclusively limited:
A. The performance of duties as a radio dispatcher in the police department;
B. The performance of custodial inventory, filing system, clerical and stenographic functions within the police department;
C. The giving of safety lectures and operation of training films relating to bicycle and automobile safety within the school system or other functions relating
to the police department;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 164/618
D. The response and handling of assistance calls concerning animals, lockouts of vehicles and houses, lost children and missing persons, stranded
motorists and malfunctioning motor vehicles;
E. To investigate and issue complaints for violation of this code or village ordinance provisions of a noncriminal nature including issuance of "tag on" tickets
concerning parking meter and vehicle parking violations, the issuance of complaints regarding dogs and other animal offenses, snow removal, zoning
and building code offenses;
F. To investigate and handle the disposition of incidents of broken electrical wire, gas leaks, water main breaks, fallen trees or tree limbs upon public
sidewalks and streets, and broken or damaged public property including traffic signs or signals, light posts, parking meters and street signs;
G. To inspect from time to time all parking meters and other municipal property for operating efficiency and to make collections of parking meter monies;
H. To undertake traffic surveys and other investigations deemed necessary to assist the police department or the village board with traffic or public safety
problems;
I. To perform school crossing guard duties or the operation of the police pistol range;
J. To appear in court to testify in regard to complaints or tickets issued by such officer or in which such officer is a witness; and
K. To perform all other duties of a nonpolice nature as may be assigned by the chief of police. (1978 Code § 10-1-13-3)
Chapter 2
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
ARTICLE A. EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
6-2A-1: ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE; COMPOSITION:
A. There is hereby established the local agency for emergency services and disaster relief for the village to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from disaster caused by the explosion in the village or in neighboring areas of atomic or other means from without or by means of
sabotage or other disloyal actions within, or from fire, flood, earthquake, telecommunications failure or other natural or technological causes, in
accordance with the Illinois emergency management agency act of 1992. Said organization shall be known as the GLENDALE HEIGHTS
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY, and every mention in this article of the local emergency management agency or of the provisions of the
Illinois emergency management agency act shall be synonymous with and shall apply and include, within the context and meaning of said provisions,
the term "EMA" standing for the "emergency management agency" and the provisions of the Illinois emergency management agency act.
B. The EMA will consist of all emergency planning, exercise, and emergency operating center activities as well as the "ESDA" (emergency services and
disaster agency), which will serve as the field response unit, to support emergency activities and units that emerge from the citizen corps as set forth in
article B of this chapter. The EMA will function under the supervision and direction of the chief of police. In addition, the local emergency management
agency shall consist of the coordinator, and any additional members as deemed necessary by the chief of police and approved by the village
administrator. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-2: COORDINATOR:
A. Office Established; Appointment; Residency: There is hereby established the office of the emergency management coordinator for the village. The
emergency management coordinator shall be appointed by the village president and shall be a regular employee of the village. The coordinator does
not need to be a resident of the village, however, the coordinator shall live within fifteen (15) miles of the village corporate limits.
B. Succession Upon Inability To Serve: In the event the coordinator is absent, resigns, dies, or is otherwise unable to serve, the village administrator shall
designate an individual to act as coordinator until a new coordinator is appointed by the village president.
C. General Duties: The emergency management coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of
the local agency subject to the direction and control of the chief of police. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-3: MEMBERS:
A. Field Coordinator: Under the oversight of the emergency management coordinator of the village, an ESDA field coordinator will be appointed by the
village administrator. The field coordinator shall be responsible for the operations of the ESDA unit, and will serve administrative functions relating to
the operation of the ESDA unit as directed by the emergency management coordinator of the village.
B. Volunteer Members: Volunteer members of the ESDA unit will be appointed by the village administrator. The maximum staffing level will be fifteen (15)
members. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 165/618
6-2A-4: OATH OF OFFICE:
Each person, whether compensated or uncompensated, who is appointed to serve in any capacity in the EMA shall, before entering upon his or her duties,
take an oath, in writing, before the emergency management coordinator or any other person authorized to administer oaths in the state, which oath shall
be filed with the emergency management coordinator, and which oath shall be substantially as follows:
I , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time that I am affiliated with the
Glendale Heights Emergency Management Agency, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence.
(Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-5: FUNCTIONS:
A. The EMA shall perform such functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the local, county, and state emergency operations plan and
programs, orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Illinois emergency management agency and, in addition, shall conduct such
functions outside the corporate limits as may be required under any mutual aid agreement or compact as are entered into as provided by the Illinois
emergency management agency act.
B. The emergency management coordinator shall prepare and submit to the county office of homeland security and emergency management for review
and certification an "emergency operations plan" describing the organization, mission, and functions of the village and supporting services for
responding to and recovering from disasters. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-6: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAMS:
A. Members Designated: All or any members of the EMA may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the governor or the state
director of the Illinois emergency management agency.
B. Team Leader: The leader of a mobile support team shall be designated by the director of the Illinois emergency management agency.
C. Compensation; Powers And Duties: Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the
governor, or the state director of the emergency management agency, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, privileges
and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while serving, shall be entitled
to at least one dollar ($1.00) per year compensation from the state, as provided by law. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-7: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The coordinator of the EMA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective
until it has been approved by the village board of trustees and by the applicable political subdivisions. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-8: COOPERATION WITH STATE AGENCIES:
If the governor declares that a disaster exists, it shall be the duty of the EMA to cooperate fully with the state emergency management agency and with the
governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-9: COMPENSATION:
Members shall receive for such training time or response activities such compensation as may be established by the village board of trustees through the
annual budget. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-10: STATE REIMBURSEMENT OF VILLAGE EXPENSES:
The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement by the state to the village for the compensation paid and the
actual and necessary travel, subsistence and maintenance expenses of paid employees of the village while serving outside its corporate limits pursuant to
call as members of a mobile support team, and for all payments made for death, disease or injury of those paid employees arising out of and incurred in
the course of that duty, and for all losses of damage to supplies and equipment of the village resulting from the operations. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-11: EMERGENCY PURCHASES:
A. The village board of trustees may, on recommendation of the emergency management coordinator, authorize any purchase or contract necessary to
place the village in a position to combat a declared disaster and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 166/618
assistance to victims of those disasters.
B. In the event of a declared disaster, the emergency management coordinator of the village is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such
services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or
formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Illinois emergency management agency act;
provided, that if the village board of trustees meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (Ord.
2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2A-12: OFFICE:
The village administrator is authorized to designate space in the village hall or elsewhere for the EMA as its office. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
ARTICLE B. CITIZEN CORPS COUNCIL
6-2B-1: ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE:
There is hereby established a citizen corps council in the village. The general purpose of the council is to promote community preparedness and enhance
homeland security through communication, coordination and collaboration among the various citizen corps programs throughout the village. The citizen
corps council is to unite the strength of every citizen by means of education, training, and volunteer services to make the village safer, better prepared, and
determined to respond to crime and all kinds of disasters, including threats of terrorism. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2B-2: APPOINTMENT; MEMBERSHIP:
The village president shall appoint, with the consent of the village board, members to the citizen corps council. Membership may include representatives
from the village board, police and fire departments, the emergency management coordinator, emergency medical services or healthcare providers, major
industries or other groups such as leaders from educational institutions, faith based organizations, the business community, environmental and
transportation groups, utility providers, or other groups that represent a large cross section of the community. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2B-3: TERM; REAPPOINTMENTS; REMOVALS:
Membership on the citizen corps council is limited to three (3) years. The village president may reappoint members at his or her discretion. The village
president may remove a member from the council as deemed necessary. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2B-4: ORGANIZATION:
The council, at its first meeting, shall elect officers consisting of one chairperson and one vice chairperson. The council shall establish bylaws governing
their meetings and activities and shall present them to the village board for approval. The bylaws shall provide that the council meet at least once quarterly.
(Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2B-5: AUTHORITY:
The citizen corps council is authorized to take such action and to create programs as necessary to mobilize the citizens of the village to volunteer to help
prepare for local and national emergencies. The council has no authority to enter into any agreement or contract or to expend any funds without the prior
approval of the village board. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
ARTICLE C. LOCAL DISASTERS
6-2C-1: DECLARATION:
The village president, or his or her interim emergency successor as provided under this code and identified in the village emergency operations plan, shall
have the authority to declare a local disaster, which shall activate the village emergency operations plan and thereby authorize the furnishing of necessary
aid and assistance. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2C-2: CONTINUANCES OR RENEWALS:
Any initial order or proclamation declaring a local disaster shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the
consent of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)
6-2C-3: NOTICES:
Any declaration, continuance or termination of a local disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the village clerk.
(Ord. 2009-11, 2-19-2009)

Chapter 3
FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
ARTICLE A. FIRE CODE
6-3A-1: ADOPTION OF CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the village and incorporated herein by reference the 2006 edition of the international fire code, as promulgated by the
International Code Council, Inc., as the fire code of the village for regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion
hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in
the occupancy of buildings and premises in the village, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the community development director available
for public use, examination and inspection. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of the international fire code are hereby
referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes set forth in section 6-3A-
2 of this article. (Ord. 2008-60, 8-21-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
6-3A-2: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
The 2006 international fire code adopted by section 6-3A-1 of this article is hereby amended as follows:
Section 101.1 is amended to read as follows:
Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the fire code of the village of Glendale Heights, herein after referred to as "this code".
(Ord. 2008-60, 8-21-2008)
Section 108.1 is amended to read as follows:
Section 108.1 General. Whenever the director of community development disapproves an application or refuses to grant a permit applied for, or when
it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply or the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the
applicant may appeal from the decision of the director of community development to the fire chief and board of trustees of either the Glenside fire
protection district or Bloomingdale fire protection district, DuPage County, Illinois, in writing, within fifteen (15) days from the date of the decision
appealed.
Section 109.3 is amended to read as follows:
Section 109.3 Violation Penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or
shall erect, construct, alter, repair a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the director of community development, or of a
permit or certificate issued under the provisions, shall be penalized with a fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $1,000.00. Each day shall be
considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 2008-60, 8-21-2008; amd. 2011 Code)
Section 311.1 is amended by adding the following paragraphs to read as follows:
Temporarily unoccupied buildings, structures, premises or portions thereof, including tenant spaces, shall be safeguarded and maintained in
accordance with this section. Fire protection systems required by this code or the 2006 international building code as amended and adopted by the
village of Glendale Heights shall be installed, repaired, operated, tested and maintained in accordance with this code. The building owner shall provide
updated key holder information as required by the fire protection district having jurisdiction.
Vacant structures which have been unoccupied for more than twenty four (24) consecutive months shall be required to be inspected prior to occupancy.
The building or occupied portion(s) shall be required to be equipped with a full automatic fire alarm system as specified in section 907 and be directly
monitored by the authority having jurisdiction.

vehicle parking or storage.
Section 503.6 is amended by adding the following paragraph to read as follows:
Section 503.6 Security Gates. Where security gates are installed, they shall be equipped with an approved key switch that activates the operation of
the gate. The key switch and its location shall be approved by the fire code official. The security gates and the emergency operation shall be
maintained operational at all times. At properties equipped with security gates, provisions shall be made for securing the gate in a locked position using
a double padlock system. A padlock approved for this use by the fire code official shall be provided in addition to the occupant's padlock.

Section 903.4.2.1 Alarms Audio/Visual Indicating Devices. In addition to the required ten (10) inch water flow bell, a weather tight visual warning
device shall be provided above the fire department connection. The color shall be approved by the fire district having jurisdiction.

Section 903.4.2.2 Audio/Visual Devices. Alarm indicating appliances, audio/visual devices, shall be provided, seen and heard in all areas of every
building per NFPA 72. All sprinklered buildings shall be provided with occupant notification devices. This will provide full building notification per NFPA
72.
