6-3A-3: ENFORCEMENT OF CODE:
The enforcement of the fire code adopted in this article shall be the responsibility of that bureau of fire prevention established by the appropriate fire
protection district exercising jurisdiction as to those portions of the village falling within the boundaries of such district. Enforcement action shall be under
the administrative supervision of the chief of the appropriate district fire department who shall serve as chief of the bureau of fire prevention. (1978 Code
§ 5-1-5; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE B. FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION REGULATIONS
6-3B-1: FIRE PREVENTION PROVISIONS ENUMERATED:
A. Identification Of Hazardous Materials: Any hazardous materials shall be identified for health, flammability and reactivity in accordance with NFPA 704M,
"Identification System For Fire Hazards Of Materials", 1969 edition.
B. Fire Procedure Notice: Owners, managers and agents of multiple dwelling units with three (3) or more living units shall post and maintain in a
conspicuous location within each dwelling unit a notice in writing which explains what procedures to use in the event of fire. The notice shall contain a
diagram of exit routes and all fire exits.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 170/618
C. Construction To Prevent The Spread Of Fire, Gas And Smoke:
1. Walls, partitions, floors, ceiling roofs, openings therein and other features necessary for prevention of spread of fire, smoke and gases shall be
maintained in proper condition and repair at all times.
2. All openings including doors shall be provided with automatic self-closing devices designed to keep opening protective devices closed.
3. Approved smoke and gas detecting devices may be considered for closing doors where openings must normally remain open.
D. Testing Stairs, Fire Escapes And Tunnels: All stairs, fire escapes, tunnels and similar safety devices shall be periodically tested for their safe use.
E. Stock Maintenance: All stock shall be kept in a neat, orderly, compact manner in accord with good housekeeping.
F. Packing Materials: Wherever and whenever stock is dispensed directly from a shipping container and combustible material is used as protective
packing, such packing material shall be removed from the container and taken care of by removing to the outside in a closed container. Such container
shall be kept closed at all times except when removing stock therefrom.
G. Removal Of Packing And Waste Materials: No persons shall store in any building excess amounts of combustible empty packing cases, barrels, boxes,
rubber tires, shavings, excelsior, rubbish, paper bags, litter, hay, straw and similar combustibles. Aisles and storage of the above mentioned
combustibles necessary for the performance of business shall be kept in an orderly and neat manner. Combustible materials shall be removed daily or
more often as is necessary to suitable vaults, bins or separate buildings. Such practices shall be approved by the bureau of fire prevention.
H. Open Flames And Lights: No open flames or lights and no heating or lighting apparatus or equipment capable of igniting flammable materials shall be
allowed unless such apparatus is well adhered to and permanently mounted on a glass globe or similar approved device.
I. Tenant Separation: Each tenant space shall be separated from each other by walls, partitions and floor-ceiling assemblies having at least a one hour
approved fire rating.
J. Firewalls: Where required, firewalls shall be installed between buildings or to divide complexes or buildings into areas for firefighting control. Openings in
firewalls shall be protected in accordance with NFPA 80, "Standards For Fire Doors And Windows", 1973 edition.
K. Fire Stops: Vertical and horizontal spread of fire shall be controlled by properly located and installed fire stops.
L. Elevators:
1. All elevators shall be designed to automatically return to the main floor in case of fire.
2. One elevator shall be designed for emergency control.
3. One elevator shall be designed to allow access to and hold an ambulance cot with patient in a horizontal position.
4. All elevators shall be designed in accordance with nationally recognized standards.
5. Fire safety and emergency operating facilities for elevators shall be approved by the bureau of fire prevention.
M. Smoke And Heat Venting:
1. All exit components and all buildings over ten thousand (10,000) square feet gross area or over two (2) stories in height shall be provided with
emergency smoke and heat venting.
2. Venting may be accomplished by gravity and/or mechanical methods.
3. All venting shall be designed in accordance with nationally recognized standards.
4. All venting methods shall be approved by the bureau of fire prevention.
N. Fire Department Access:
1. Public or private access shall be provided to each building so that the first responding fire department unit will be so located that all points of the
interior of the building may be reached by one hundred fifty feet (150') of fire department initial attack hose.
Where the size of the building and height of the building do not allow this criteria to be met and an interior standpipe system is connected to a public
water system and equipped with a fire department connection, the above criteria may be considered met when approved by the fire prevention
bureau.
2. Public or private access for motor fire apparatus shall be provided around the building so that it may be properly laddered and operation of
mechanically elevated mechanisms may be properly utilized. Minimum width of fire lanes shall be fifteen feet (15'), with greater widths to
accommodate vehicles when turning.
3. Access routes shall be so arranged that fire department apparatus may respond from all points of the building to adjacent fire hydrants along routes
not to exceed three hundred feet (300') from the most remote point of the building to the closest fire hydrant.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 171/618
4. Fire lanes on private property shall be approved by the bureau of fire prevention, and parking of motor vehicles or otherwise obstructing such fire
lanes or access routes by use of chains, barricades or other means shall be prohibited at all times.
5. Private fire department access roads and ways shall be properly maintained and accessible at all times.
6. Access routes shall be circulating for adequate fire apparatus movement.
7. Access roads shall not be less than fifteen feet (15') from adjacent buildings.
O. Water Supplies For Fire Department Use:
1. Water Supplies; Quantity: The following are fire department pumper supplies which should be available commensurate with the hazards therein:
Single-family detached residential 1,000 gpm
Town/row or cluster housing 1,500 to 2,000 gpm
Apartment type construction 3,000 to 4,000 gpm
Industrial type development 3,000 to 5,000 gpm
Research and developmental laboratories 3,000 to 4,000 gpm
Business and commercial areas 3,000 to 4,500 gpm
Mercantile centers 3,000 to 6,000 gpm
(1978 Code § 5-1-4)
2. Fire Hydrants: Fire hydrants shall be in compliance with the provisions of section 10-2-2, amendment 903.3.5.3 of this code. (2011 Code)
6-3B-2: PLAN REVIEW:
A. Plan Review Required: Plans showing all fire protection related features, fire resistant assemblies and any conditions affecting fire protection or fire
prevention shall be submitted to the appropriate bureau of fire prevention prior to the commencement of construction, alterations, additions and the
increasing of fire hazards or relocating of fire hazards within buildings.
B. Applications: Applications shall be made on a form provided by the said bureau of fire prevention and shall include complete details of such information,
including three (3) sets of plans, and said applications shall be made prior to issuances of other permits by the village.
C. Required Information: All plans shall bear the name, address and seal of licensed professionals when necessary in accordance with statutes of the
state of Illinois regarding architects, professional engineers and structural engineers.
D. Inspections: If inspections are required, the bureau of fire prevention shall be notified at least one day in advance of all such inspections so that they
may be accomplished at the appropriate time while all facilities, construction, equipment, etc., are visible and in such condition so as to be adequately
inspected. (1978 Code § 5-1-7)
6-3B-3: OCCUPANCY PERMITS:
A. Permit Required:
1. All buildings are required to have an occupancy permit issued by the director of community development verifying that it meets the requirements of
the international fire code. (Ord. 2002-23, 4-4-2002; amd. 2011 Code)
2. The occupancy permit shall be required for all existing buildings in accordance with subsection A1 of this section.
3. Occupancy permits shall be required for buildings which change use, and special hazards controlled by this code, added to or remodeled or altered.
B. Compliance With Fire Code: No occupancy permit shall be issued unless the building is in conformance with the requirements of the international fire
code.
C. Expiration And Renewal: Occupancy permits shall expire annually from the date of issuance and may be renewed if buildings are maintained in
conformance with this chapter. (Ord. 2002-23, 4-4-2002)
6-3B-4: EMERGENCY CONDITIONS:
When, in the opinion of the bureau of fire prevention, there is actual and immediate danger because of hazardous conditions which endanger life or may
cause adverse effects upon adjoining properties, the bureau may order the building to be immediately vacated and cause immediate remedial action if
necessary. The cost of such remedial action shall be borne by the owner of the premises. (1978 Code § 5-1-8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 172/618
6-3B-5: EXPLOSIVE, FLAMMABLE AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
A. Storage Limits:
1. Explosives And Blasting Agents: The limits referred to in section 12.5b of the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code in which storage
of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited are the village corporate limits.
2. Flammable Liquids In Outside Aboveground Tanks:
a. The limits referred to in section 16.22a of the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code in which storage of flammable liquids in
outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are the village corporate limits.
b. The limits referred to in section 16.61 of the fire prevention code in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited are
the village corporate limits.
c. No flammable liquids or gases shall be stored within two hundred feet (200') of any building or ground used as a hospital, church or school.
Flammable liquids shall not be used for washing or cleaning purposes in any gasoline filling station. All flammable liquids and rags and waste
materials impregnated with such liquids shall be stored in covered metal containers. No flammable wastes shall be permitted to drain into any
sewer or stormwater drainage system.
3. Bulk Storage Of Liquefied Petroleum Gases: The limits referred to in section 21.6a of the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code in
which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases is restricted are hereby established as the village corporate limits. (1978 Code § 5-1-9; amd. 2011
Code)
B. Transportation Routes:
1. The routes referred to in section 12.7M of the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code for vehicles transporting explosives and
blasting agents are hereby established as follows: North Avenue (Route 64) and otherwise by special permit detailing route, quantities, hazards,
protection provided and need, approved and issued by the bureau of fire prevention.
2. The routes referred to in section 20.14 of the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals
and other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows: North Avenue (Route 64) and otherwise by special permit detailing route, quantities,
hazards, protection provided and need, approved and issued by the bureau of fire prevention. (1978 Code § 5-1-9)
6-3B-6: NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES; PERMITS REQUIRED:
The board of trustees of the appropriate fire protection district shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an
opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits within their respective jurisdictions, in addition to those
now enumerated in the American Insurance Association's fire prevention code. The appropriate bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a
conspicuous place in its office and the village hall and shall distribute copies thereof to interested persons. (1978 Code § 5-1-12; amd. 2011 Code)
6-3B-7: FIRE INSPECTORS:
The chief of the fire department of each said fire protection district shall assign and train such members of the department as may be deemed necessary
to serve as fire inspectors, and shall recommend to the village board of trustees the employment of additional technical inspectors under such terms and
conditions as the board shall prescribe. (1978 Code § 5-1-6)
Chapter 4
ALARM SYSTEMS
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
AUTOMATIC SIGNAL DEVICE: Any automatic protection device which automatically sends a recorded signal, warning or voice alarm directly to the village
police over regular public telephone lines upon detection of a fire or intrusion.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of a signal device through electrical or mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the owner
or lessee of a signal device or of his employees or agents. "False alarm" does not include alarm signals activated by violent conditions of nature,
telephone line interruptions, acts of God, or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the signal device user.
MINIMUM INSTALLATION AND CLASSIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: The provisions of the most current edition of the publication numbered UL681 and
entitled "Installation, Classification And Certification Of Burglar Alarm Systems", as published by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc.
MONITORING SYSTEM: The system installed at the village police department to receive visual or audible signals from an approved automatic signal
device.
SIGNAL DEVICE: An approved electrically operated instrument which automatically sends visual and/or audible alarm signals over a signal line to be
registered by indicators at a monitor panel at the receiving terminal, and which meets the installation and classification requirements of this chapter. (1978
Code §§ 4-9-1, 4-9-8)
6-4-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FAILURE TO OBTAIN:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 173/618
A. No person shall install, operate or maintain in his home, place of business or other premises a signaling device calculated to summon the police or fire
department, or that is connected directly or indirectly to the monitoring system at the police department or fire department, or to any alarm answering
company's receiving location without first obtaining a permit for each separate alarm system he wishes to install. (1978 Code § 4-9-2)
B. The failure of any person to obtain a signal device system user permit as required by this section constitutes an offense punishable by a fine as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1978 Code § 4-9-13; amd. 2011
Code)
6-4-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
A. Application for permits to so install, maintain and operate a signaling device shall be filed with the village clerk on forms supplied by the village and shall
be accompanied by the required fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (1978 Code § 4-9-3)
B. Each application for permit shall set forth the names, addresses and telephone numbers of both the installer of the signal device and the owner of the
premises on or in which the device will be installed as well as a description of the system and the location where it is to be installed. Each such
application shall further set forth emergency telephone numbers of the signal device user and the names, addresses and telephone numbers of key
holders to the premises and signal device system who can respond to the alarm location as soon as possible, but not to exceed forty five (45) minutes.
Each permit application shall also contain the written approval of the owner of the premises described in such application to the following paragraph,
which will be set forth on the application:
The undersigned, as the legal and beneficial owner of the property described in this application hereby agrees that the Village shall not be liable for
any defects in operation of signal device systems, for any failure or neglect of any person in connection with the installation and operation of
equipment, the transmission of alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages or the relaying of such signals and messages. In the event that the
Village finds it necessary to disconnect a defective signaling device or any device which is used in a manner which violates the provision of the
Municipal Code, the Village shall incur no liability by such action.
(1978 Code § 4-9-4)
6-4-4: APPROVAL OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
Each application shall be referred to the chief of police, or his designated agent, for review, written rejection or written approval. Such rejection or approval
shall be based upon the application and the signaling device complying or failing to comply with the provisions hereof upon inspection. Upon inspection
and rejection or rejections, each reinspection shall be subject to a reinspection fee of five dollars ($5.00). (1978 Code § 4-9-5)
6-4-5: ELECTRICAL PERMIT AND COMPLIANCE WITH BUILDING CODES REQUIRED; FINAL INSPECTION; ISSUANCE OF
PERMIT:
Any person desiring to install a signal device after January 1, 1983, shall obtain an electrical permit from the village department of community
development. All signal devices shall be installed, maintained and operated in accordance with the village building code, the national electrical code, and
the most current edition of the publication numbered UL681 entitled "Installation, Classification And Certification Of Burglar Alarm Systems", as published
by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc. No permit for use of a signal device shall be issued without a certificate of final inspection issued by the department of
community development. No permit allowing the connection of a signaling device to the monitoring system shall be issued until it has been first determined
that such device and the installation thereof comply with all provisions hereof. Each permit must bear the dated, written signature of the chief of police,
shall describe the premises to which such permit is issued and the name, address and telephone number of the owner thereof. (1978 Code § 4-9-6; amd.
2011 Code)
6-4-6: PERMIT NOT WARRANTY OF DEVICE:
The issuance of a permit shall in no way constitute a warranty of the signal device involved, and issuance of said permit shall be specifically subject to the
village disclaimer of liability as detailed in subsection 6-4-3B of this chapter and further detailed in section 10/2-206 of the local governmental and
governmental employee's tort immunity act, 745 Illinois Compiled Statutes. (1978 Code § 4-9-7; amd. 2011 Code)
6-4-7: FALSE ALARMS:
A. Responsibility For False Alarms; Records Kept; Revocation Or Suspension Of Permit: Each person, firm or corporation holding a permit for the
operation or maintenance of a signaling device shall be responsible for any false alarms transmitted by the device which they operate or maintain. The
chief of police shall maintain a record of all false alarms so transmitted and, pursuant to the required notice and opportunity to be heard, may revoke or
suspend the permit for operation of the signaling device involved in the transmission of four (4) false alarms in any one year or make reasonable
charges therefor. (1978 Code § 4-9-8)
B. Charges:
1. Established: The chief of police shall charge a permit holder a service fee for each false alarm in any one calendar year transmitted by a signal
device as follows:
False alarms 1 through 3 No charge
False alarms 4 through 6 $ 50.00 each false alarm
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 174/618
False alarms 7 through 9 100.00 each false alarm
All false alarms after 10 150.00 each false alarm
(Ord. 2011-71, 9-15-2011)
2. Payment: Such charges shall be payable to the police department by the user permit holder upon receipt of a statement for such charge within thirty
(30) days of issuance of such statement.
3. Exemptions: No charge shall be imposed for false alarms for thirty (30) days after initial installation or ten (10) days after major alterations or
additions, nor will any alarms be held accountable to the permit holder in these circumstances. (Ord. 2011-27, 6-2-2011)
4. Failure To Pay; Disconnection; Reconnection Charge: The signal device shall be disconnected in the event of failure to pay the service charge within
thirty (30) days of receipt of the statement. When all charges have been paid and all problems with the signaling system and/or its users have been
corrected, and a reconnection to the system is desired by the user, a service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be paid by the user prior to
reconnection. (1978 Code § 4-9-12)
C. Hearing: Every signal device user shall be entitled to an informal hearing with the chief of police, or such person as delegated by him, for each false
alarm in excess of four (4). At the informal hearing, the signal device user may offer evidence that the alarm activation for which he is being charged
comes within one of the permissible exceptions. Said hearing should be requested within five (5) days after receipt of the statement of the charge for a
false alarm. Failure to timely request such hearing shall constitute an admission that the service charge is justified and due to the police department.
(1978 Code § 4-9-10)
6-4-8: TESTING OR DEMONSTRATING DEVICES:
There shall be no testing or demonstrating signal device systems without first notifying the police department prior to such test or demonstration and
obtaining the permission of the chief of police. Any activation due to a test or demonstration without said notice and permission shall be deemed a false
alarm. (1978 Code § 4-9-11)
6-4-9: AUTOMATIC SIGNAL DEVICES PROHIBITED:
No person shall operate or maintain any automatic signal device or automatic protection device which automatically transmits a signal, message or
warning directly to the village police/fire department or its agents. A violation of this section constitutes an offense punishable by a fine as provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1978 Code § 4-9-14; amd. 2011 Code)
6-4-10: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
A. Grounds: The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to suspend or revoke a permit on the following grounds:
1. Suspension:
a. Failure to comply with the application for permit.
b. Failure to properly operate or maintain a signaling device or any part thereof.
c. The transmission of four (4) false alarms to the monitoring system in any one year.
2. Revocation:
a. Failure to cure any ground for suspension prior to the end of a suspension order.
b. Transmission of four (4) false alarms in any one year. (1978 Code § 4-9-15)
B. Procedure: Any permit may be suspended or revoked in the following manner:
1. Notice: If any device is defectively operated or maintained, a written notice of intent to suspend or revoke such permit shall be sent to the holder
thereof. Such notice shall state the reason or reasons of intent to suspend or revoke and the date and the time of the hearing to be held on such
notice.
2. Hearing: The hearing shall be held by the chief of police, or his designated agent. At the conclusion of such hearing, the matter may be continued to
a date certain so as to give the permit holder an opportunity to cure such defect, or the permit may be suspended or revoked, at the option of the
chief of police.
3. Inspection: If the hearing is so continued, or if the permit is suspended, the holder of the permit shall request an inspection prior to the continued
hearing date or the end of the suspension period. Each such request shall be accompanied by a fee of five dollars ($5.00). If such inspection shows
that such defect has been removed or cured, the notice of intent to suspend or revoke or the suspension order shall be terminated on that date. If
such inspection shows that such defect has not been so removed or cured, then such permit shall be revoked. (1978 Code § 4-9-16)
Chapter 5
ANIMAL CONTROL
6-5-1: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 175/618
The community service officers and the police department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. (1978 Code § 10-3-1; amd. 2011 Code)
6-5-2: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
A. No person shall cruelly treat in any way any animal in the village. Any person who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overloads, or abandons any animal
shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section.
B. Any person who taunts, provokes, torments, agitates or otherwise harasses a guard dog or police dog in any manner whatsoever shall be deemed
guilty of a violation of this section. (Ord. 96-03, 1-4-1996)
6-5-3: RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any animal of any kind to permit the same to run at large or be at large on the streets, public ways, or upon
the private premises of any person other than the private premises of the owner or keeper of said animal. For purposes of this section, any animal which is
not fenced upon the property of its owner or keeper or is not chained or leashed upon said property or controlled by leash shall be deemed to be running
at large. (1978 Code § 10-3-3)
6-5-4: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
A. Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
ANIMAL: Any and all types of animals, both domesticated and wild, male and female.
KEEP OR HARBOR: To maintain, possess, control and use.
OWNER: Any person owning, controlling, keeping or harboring a dog or other animal or fowl. (1978 Code § 10-3-8-1)
B. Conduct Prohibited:
1. Noise: It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any animal to permit any dog, cat, bird, or other animal to make excessive, frequent, or untimely
loud and continued noise at any time which disturbs the comfort or repose of any person or persons in the immediate vicinity and which disturbs the
surrounding property owners' reasonable use and enjoyment of their property.
2. Failure To Remove Excrement: It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or person in control of any animal, including, but not limited to, dogs and
cats, to cause or permit such animal to be on a public way or public streets or on private property not owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or
person in control unless that person has in his immediate possession a device for the removal of animal excrement to a receptacle located upon
property owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control. It shall further be unlawful for any owner, keeper or person in control of
any animal to fail to immediately remove such excrement left by such animal on any public property, public streets or on private property not owned
or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control of such animal. Upon removal, the owner, keeper or person in control of such animal shall
deposit such excrement in a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control of such animal.
3. Accumulation Of Excrement: It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for the owner or other person in charge or control of any property
located within the village to allow animal excrement, including, but not limited to, dog excrement and cat excrement, to accumulate on such property.
4. Damage To Persons Or Property:
a. It shall be unlawful to allow any animal to molest or attack any person or other animal, or to damage or impair the value of public or private
property or to detrimentally affect the public health, safety and welfare.
b. Without the consent of an owner of private property, it shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any animal to permit such animal to injure,
destroy or carry away any item of value which may be on said private property including, but not limited to, any vegetable, plant, fruit, shrub, tree,
or flower which may be planted or seeded thereon. (Ord. 2003-93, 12-4-2003)
C. Penalties: Any person who owns, keeps or harbors such dog, animal or bird who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, nor less
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the third offense if found to be guilty of such violation or violations. If any violation shall be of a continuing
nature, each day of violation shall be deemed to be a separate offense and shall subject the violator to the progressive minimum fines contained
herein. (1978 Code § 10-3-8-3; amd. 2011 Code)
6-5-5: ANIMAL HOUSES:
A. Except as otherwise permitted, it shall be unlawful to maintain within the village any stable or poultry yard or place for housing any poultry, pigeons,
geese, ducks, boa constrictor snakes, pigs, swine, cattle, horses, goats or other similar animals or livestock.
B. No owner shall allow any place where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean or unsanitary. "Unsanitary", when used herein, shall mean a
condition which is likely to attract vermin or rodents or endanger the public health or welfare of the surrounding area. (Ord. 2003-93, 12-4-2003)
6-5-6: DISEASED ANIMALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 176/618
A. Exposure To Public Prohibited: No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be exposed in any public place whereby the
health of man or beast may be affected.
B. Removal From Owner's Premises Prohibited: No diseased animal shall be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner, except under the
supervision of the community service officer or the state veterinarian.
C. Rabies Suspects: Whenever the animal control officer receives information that any person has been bitten by a dog or other animal, he shall confine
the animal for ten (10) days at a place to be determined thereby or at the residence of the owner of the animal, all in accordance with state law. (1978
Code § 10-3-5; amd. 2011 Code)
6-5-7: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMALS:
A. Definitions:
1. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the following words and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed
to them in this subsection:
ANIMAL: Any warm or cold blooded nonhuman mammal, bird, fish, reptile, poisonous or nonpoisonous, arachnids or apiarian, the keeping or
possession of which is not otherwise prohibited.
DANGEROUS ANIMAL: Any animal which, if a dog, when unmuzzled and unleashed, or in case of another animal, when unrestrained, approaches
any person in an apparent attitude of attack, whether or not the animal completes its attack; or on more than one occasion causes property damage
anywhere within the village other than to the property of the owner of said animal.
OWNER: Any keeper, person, partnership, corporation, association or any other entity owning, keeping, harboring, possessing, caring for, or having
custody or control, whether on a temporary or a permanent basis.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: a. Any individual animal that, when unprovoked, inflicts physical injury on a human being or other animal either on public or
private property.
b. Any individual animal with an observable propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise
endanger the safety of human beings or other animals.
c. Any individual animal which attacks a human being or other animal without provocation.
d. Any individual animal which has been found to be a "dangerous animal", as defined herein, on at least two (2) separate occasions.
e. Any individual animal owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of animal fights.
f. Any individual animal which, upon a complaint or complaints by citizens or upon an observation of an official of the village of Glendale Heights,
based upon its temperament when put into contact with human beings, or other animals, is reasonably believed to be an animal with vicious
tendencies.
g. Any individual animal which has been found to be a vicious animal in another jurisdiction.
Any of the acts specified in subsections a through g of this definition shall itself be sufficient to bring the act within the definition of vicious animal, and
each such occurrence shall be a separate event upon which an offense can be based.
2. A "dangerous animal" or "vicious animal" shall not include any such animal if the behavior is exhibited as a result of teasing, torment, abuse to the
animal, or when an assault, trespass, tort, or crime occurs on the immediate premises where the animal is located at the time the action takes place,
or when the animal is protecting or defending a human being within an immediate vicinity from an attack or assault. The prohibitions of this section
shall not apply to dogs used by any police department, law enforcement agency or law enforcement official in the performance of their duties.
B. Dangerous Or Vicious Animal Prohibited: Except as otherwise provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any
dangerous or vicious animal within the corporate limits of the village. (1978 Code § 10-3-9)
C. Determination Of Dangerous Or Vicious Animal; Penalties: Upon receipt of a complaint of a violation of this section, a court of competent jurisdiction
shall first determine whether the subject animal is a dangerous or a "vicious animal" as herein defined. Upon a finding that the animal in question is
dangerous or vicious, any person found to have violated the provisions of this section for a first time shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) if the offense pertains to a dangerous animal, and not more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) if the offense pertains to a vicious animal. Any person found to have violated the provisions
of this section for a second or subsequent offense shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) if the second offense pertains to a dangerous animal, and not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) if the second offense pertains to a vicious animal. (1978 Code § 10-3-9; amd. 2011 Code)
D. Authority To Destroy Dangerous Animals: The members of the police department are authorized to kill any dangerous or vicious animal of any kind
when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property. (1978 Code § 10-3-4; amd. 2011 Code)
6-5-8: ANIMALS PROHIBITED IN RECREATION AREAS AND PARKS:
No dog or other animal, whether or not attended by the owner or keeper or other person and held or led by chain or leash, shall be permitted in any
recreation area of any public park set aside for the playing of tennis, baseball, football or other game or for use as a tot lot or other organized recreation
purposes. (1978 Code § 10-3-7)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 177/618
ARTICLE A. DOGS AND CATS
6-5A-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required; Application: Any person who owns, keeps, or houses a dog or cat within the village shall be required to obtain an annual license. The
license shall be valid from May 1 to April 30 each year. Application for a license shall be made to the administrative services department.
Any person that acquires, keeps, or houses a new or additional dog or cat during a licensing year shall be required to obtain a license within thirty (30)
days of acquiring the animal, except for a dog or cat less than four (4) months old, in which case, a license shall be obtained when the dog or cat
attains the permit age of four (4) months old.
Any license applied for and issued from the passage of this section through April 30, 2016, shall only be valid until April 30, 2016. A new license shall
be required commencing May 1, 2016, and shall follow the May 1 through April 30 annual license cycle.
B. Rabies Vaccination Required: Every person who owns, keeps, or houses any dog or cat within the village shall cause such dog or cat to be vaccinated
by a registered veterinarian with an approved vaccine capable of preventing rabies for an immunization period of either one or three (3) years. Such
inoculation shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of a license required by this section.
C. License Fee: The fee for a license required by this section shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each dog or cat.
D. Issuance Of License And Tag: The administrative services department shall issue a license and tag upon submittal of an application, valid proof of
inoculation for rabies, and payment of the required fee.
E. Collar And Tag To Be Worn: It shall be unlawful for any person that owns, keeps, or houses any dog or cat within the village to permit the dog or cat to
be off the premises where it is owned, kept, or housed without wearing a collar with the tag issued pursuant to this section attached thereto.
F. Vicious Or Dangerous Dog Or Cat: No license shall be issued for any dog or cat which has been proven to be vicious or dangerous. (Ord. 2015-72, 11-
19-2015)
6-5A-2: NUMBER OF DOGS AND CATS RESTRICTED:
No person, family, or household, except in veterinary hospitals, pet shops, kennels, or dog pounds, may keep more than three (3) domestic pets at any
time on any premises within the village; except, that a litter of puppies or kittens may be kept for up to four (4) months after birth. "Domestic pets" means
dogs or cats only, and shall not include any other kind or type of animal. The payment of a license fee or license fees on dogs or cats shall not be
construed to allow the keeping of more than the number of dogs or cats herein provided. (Ord. 2003-93, 12-4-2003; amd. 2011 Code)
6-5A-3: IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION OF DOGS:
A. Impoundment And Disposition: Any dog found running at large upon any public street or highway, or any dog for which the annual license fee has not
been paid, as required by this article, shall be impounded by the village police or community service officers. If such dog is not redeemed within seven
(7) days after being impounded, it shall be disposed of in a manner prescribed by the police. (1978 Code § 10-4-2; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Notice Of Impoundment: Upon the impounding of any dog, the police department or community service officer shall forthwith notify the owner or keeper
of the dog personally or by mail of such impounding, unless such owner or keeper is to him unknown or cannot be found. (1978 Code § 10-4-3; amd.
2011 Code)
C. Redemption Of Impounded Dog; Fees: Any dog impounded may be redeemed by the owner upon payment of a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each
day or any part thereof during which the dog has been impounded. All such fees shall be paid to the police department which shall remit the same to
the village treasurer for deposit to the general fund within three (3) working days thereafter. In addition, where the annual dog license fee has not been
paid, no dog shall be redeemed until the owner has first paid the annual license fee to the village clerk and has obtained the proper dog license. (Ord.
2011-72, 9-15-2011)
D. Place Of Impoundment: In the discretion of the village clerk and at the expense of the owner or keeper of any dog taken up by the village, the dog may
be confined with a veterinarian in the village in place of being confined in the dog pound. (1978 Code § 10-4-4)
6-5A-4: PENALTY:
A. Any person who is in violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined for each such
violation as follows:
1. The first violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine of no less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
2. The second violation of this article by the same person within a twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 178/618
3. A third or subsequent violation of this article by the same person within a twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than one
hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
B. Every day of which, or during which, a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2011-72, 9-15-2011)
ARTICLE B. FEEDING WILD ANIMALS AND WATERFOWL
6-5B-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of this article is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community and its wildlife by prohibiting the feeding of wild animals and
waterfowl, including ducks, geese, and gulls, on public and private property in the Village of Glendale Heights. This article is not intended to prohibit or
prevent the incidental, sporadic or infrequent feeding of wild animals and waterfowl (e.g., feeding ducks a single piece of bread and that which is not
immediately consumed dissolves or otherwise is consumed by fish; attaching an ear of corn to a squirrel feeder, or feeding song birds utilizing a wellmaintained
bird feeder), but rather prohibit or prevent the feeding of wild animals and waterfowl in such a manner which creates an unclean, unsafe, or
unsanitary condition, either on such person's property, on the property of another, or on public property (e.g., unnatural or atypical accumulation of
waterfowl feces, damaging or destroying vegetation and grasses due to large concentrations of waterfowl, or the "luring", "drawing", or "attracting"
waterfowl away from the natural habitat of lakes, ponds and other bodies of water into private yards or public property).
It has been established that feeding wild animals and waterfowl increases the potential for damage to public parks and private property, may elevate the
potential for the spread of disease, and contributes to water-quality problems such as summer algal blooms. In addition, it is the intent of this article to
protect the welfare of the wild animals and waterfowl themselves, as wild animal studies have shown that feeding wild animals and waterfowl can interrupt
their normal migration patterns, can make them more aggressive in demanding food, cause nutritional problems, expose them to danger by eliminating
their natural fear of predators, and promote the spread of disease and disease-carrying parasites such as fleas and ticks. (Ord. 2018-104, 12-13-2018)
6-5B-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
A. It is hereby declared unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance to repeatedly feed any wild animal or waterfowl on private or public property in a manner
described in section 6-5B-1 of this article that creates an unclean, unsafe, or unsanitary condition.
B. This article does not prohibit the feeding of song birds using a well-maintained bird feeder which is a feeder that generally protects seed against the
weather. (Ord. 2018-104, 12-13-2018)
6-5B-3: PENALTY:
In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be subject
to the penalties as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2018-104, 12-13-2018)
Chapter 6
GENERAL OFFENSES
6-6-1: ACCOUNTABILITY FOR CONDUCT OF ANOTHER:
A person is legally accountable for the conduct of another when:
A. Having a mental state described by the ordinance defining the offense, he causes another to perform the conduct, and the other person in fact or by
reason of legal incapacity lacks such a mental state;
B. The ordinance defining the offense makes him so accountable; or
C. Either before or during the commission of an offense, and with the intent to promote or facilitate such commission, he solicits, aids, abets, agrees or
attempts to aid such other person in the planning or commission of the offense; however, a person is not so accountable unless the ordinance defining
the offense provides otherwise, if:
1. He is a victim of the offense committed;
2. The offense is so defined that his conduct was inevitable incident to its commission; or
3. Before the commission of the offense, he terminates his effort to promote or facilitate such commission and does one of the following: wholly
deprives his prior efforts of effectiveness in such commission, or gives timely warning to the proper law enforcement authorities, or otherwise makes
proper effort to prevent the commission of the offense. (1978 Code § 10-6-1-1)
6-6-2: IMPERSONATING, INTERFERING WITH VILLAGE OFFICERS:
No person shall falsely represent himself to be an officer of the village or shall, without being duly authorized, exercise or attempt to exercise any of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 179/618
duties, functions or powers of a village officer or shall hinder, obstruct, resist or otherwise interfere with any village officer in the discharge of his official
duties. (1978 Code § 10-6-1-2)
6-6-3: INTERFERING WITH, RESISTING POLICE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, delay, obstruct, resist or otherwise interfere with any member of the police department or any other person
duly authorized to perform police duties in the discharge of his duties. (Ord. 2007-80, 9-4-2007)
ARTICLE A. OFFENSES AGAINST ORDER
6-6A-1: ASSAULT:
A person commits an assault and is guilty of a violation of this code when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in
reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-2)
6-6A-2: BATTERY:
A person commits battery, which is a violation of this code, if he intentionally or knowingly, without legal justification and by any means:
A. Causes bodily harm to an individual; or
B. Makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-3)
6-6A-3: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
A person commits disorderly conduct, which is a violation of this code, when he knowingly:
A. Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace;
B. With intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation thereby ensues;
C. Transmits in any manner to the fire department a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for
believing that such fire existed;
D. Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in any place and that its
explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or
explosive was concealed in such place;
E. Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the
time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense had been committed;
F. Enters upon the property of another and, for a lewd or unlawful purpose, deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other
opening in it;
G. Does any act in a violent, tumultuous or alarming manner toward another, placing that other person in danger of safety to his health, limb or life;
H. Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby public or private property of another is placed in danger of being destroyed or
damaged;
I. Endangers or interferes with the lawful pursuits of another by threats or acts of violence to that person;
J. Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the health, safety or property of another;
K. Utters "fighting words" directed at any other person resulting in that other person becoming alarmed or disturbed;
L. Congregates with one or more persons on any public place in such a manner as to impede the free flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic;
M. Knowingly or intentionally engages in any fight, riot or brawl within the village; provided, however, that any applicable affirmative defense as set forth in
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-1 shall be available; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 180/618
N. Knowingly or intentionally flashes or transmits to another, anywhere within the village, any known or clearly defined street gang signs with the intent to
create a breach of the peace or create a public disturbance. (Ord. 96-93, 10-17-1996)
6-6A-4: DRUNK AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
No person shall be drunk or shall be in a state of intoxication in any street, avenue or public place or in any private house or place to the disturbance of
any person. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-7)
6-6A-5: DISTURBING ASSEMBLIES:
No person shall wilfully interrupt or disturb any school or other assembly of people met for a lawful purpose, and no person shall interrupt or disturb any
religious assembly. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-5)
6-6A-6: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLIES:
A. No person shall assemble, congregate or collect in bodies, crowds, groups of three (3) or more for any unlawful purposes within the limits of the village;
nor shall any person in a body of three (3) or more congregate, loiter, linger, stand together or near to each other on any sidewalk, street, alley, public
parking lot, public park or public passageway or in front of, about or upon any stairway, doorway or window of any church, theater, auditorium, school,
hall or other public building so as to obstruct, block, impede or interfere with the free passage of persons on or upon said public sidewalks, streets and
ways, or so as to obstruct, impede or interfere with the free passage of persons entering or occupying any such public buildings or premises or any
premises fronting upon any public sidewalk, street or way, when requested to immediately disperse and move by any police officer.
B. Except for authorized personnel, no person shall assemble, congregate or collect, singly or in groups, within any area designated as Armitage Ditch,
Armitage Fork, Hestenman Ditch, Mill Pond, Havens/Dillon Drainage Ditch, or any waterway or watercourse within the boundaries of the village which
is provided for the purpose of carrying stormwater runoff. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-4)
6-6A-7: MOB ACTION:
Mob action, which shall be a violation of this code, consists of any of the following:
A. The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two (2) or more persons acting together and without authority of law;
B. The assembly of two (2) or more persons to do an unlawful act; or
C. The assembly of two (2) or more persons, without authority of law, for the purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to
have been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purpose of exercising correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. (1978
Code § 10-6-2-10)
6-6A-8: ENGAGING IN DANGEROUS SPORTS:
No person shall, on any public street, sidewalk, or in any public place other than a designated recreation area in the village, fly kites, play ball or engage in
any sport or exercise likely to impede the passage of vehicles or otherwise injure persons or property or obstruct the business of other persons making use
of such public street, sidewalk or public place. (1978 Code § 10-6-2-6)
6-6A-9: USE, POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic liquor, as defined by state law, on any public way or in or about any motor vehicle upon a public
way in the village.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor in or upon or about any motor vehicle upon any public way in
the village except in the original package and with the seal unbroken. (1978 Code § 11-1-11)
6-6A-10: SOCIAL HOSTING:
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings unless expressly stated otherwise:
ALCOHOL: Ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits, including dilutions and
mixtures thereof, from whatever source or by whatever process produced.
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: Alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and every liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine, beer and which contains onehalf
of one percent or more of alcohol by volume, and which is fit for beverage purposes either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined with other
substances.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 181/618
CONVEYANCE: Any vehicle, trailer, watercraft, or container operated for the transportation of persons or property.
EVENT OR GATHERING: Any group of two (2) or more persons who have assembled or gathered together for a social occasion or other activity.
HOST: To aid, conduct, allow, entertain, organize, supervise, control, permit, or condone the consumption of alcohol or alcoholic beverages by a
minor at an event or gathering at a residence or premises.
ILLICIT DRUGS: Any drug, substance, or compound prohibited by law, including drugs prescribed by a physician that are in the possession of or
used by someone other than the person to whom the drug was prescribed.
INTENTIONALLY: Conduct engaged in by a person with the conscious objective to accomplish that result or engage in that conduct.
KNOWINGLY: Conduct engaged in by a person when he is consciously aware of the nature or attendant circumstances of his conduct which
constitutes an offense under this section.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: Any foster parent, person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by court order, or person appointed guardian or given
custody of a minor.
MINOR: Any person not yet twenty one (21) years of age.
PARENT: Any person having legal custody of a juvenile:
1. As a natural or adoptive parent, or stepparent;
2. As a legal guardian; or
3. As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court.
PERSON: Any individual, person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust, or other legal entity.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways,
and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, parks, businesses or parking lots.
REASONABLE STEPS: Controlling access to alcohol and alcoholic beverages at an event or gathering; controlling the quantity of alcohol and
alcoholic beverages present at the event or gathering; verifying the age of the persons attending the event or gathering by inspecting driver's
licenses or other government issued identification cards to ensure that minors do not consume alcohol and alcoholic beverages while at the event or
gathering; and supervising the activities of minors at the event or gathering and calling for police assistance in the event people under twenty one
(21) are in possession of alcohol at the event or gathering or advising law enforcement in advance of departing a residence or premises under his or
her control that he or she will be away and that no underage person is authorized to be present and consume alcohol at residence or premises.
RELIGIOUS CEREMONY: The possession, consumption, and dispensation of alcohol or an alcoholic beverage for the purpose of conducting a bona
fide rite or religious ceremony.
RESIDENCE OR PREMISES: Any residence, home, dwelling, garage, shed, or other accessory structure, yard, farm, field, land, apartment,
condominium, hotel or motel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall or meeting room, park, or any other place of assembly, public or private, whether
occupied on a temporary or permanent basis, as a dwelling or specifically for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or
used with or without permission or compensation.
RESPONSE COST: Cost associated with responses by law enforcement, code enforcement, fire, and other emergency response providers to an
event or gathering, including, but not limited to:
1. Salaries and benefits of law enforcement, code enforcement, fire, or other emergency response personnel for the amount of time spent
responding to, remaining at, or otherwise dealing with an event or gathering, and the administrative costs attributable to such responses;
2. The cost of any medical treatment for any law enforcement, code enforcement, fire, or other emergency response personnel injured responding
to, remaining at, or leaving the event or gathering;
3. The cost of repairing any damaged village equipment or property, and the cost of the use of any such equipment, in responding to, remaining at,
or leaving an event or gathering.
B. Prohibited: Except as permitted by state law, it is unlawful for any person to permit, allow, host or fail to take reasonable steps to prevent an event or
gathering at a residence or premises under his or her control or reasonable opportunity to control, or in any conveyance over which a person has
control or reasonable opportunity to control, where illicit drugs, alcohol, or alcoholic beverages can be, are, or were consumed by a minor, if such
person either knows or reasonably should have known that a minor could, was, or did consume illicit drugs, alcohol, or alcoholic beverages.
C. Person Deemed To Have Known: A person who permits, allows, or hosts an event or gathering shall be deemed to have known or should have known
that a minor could, was, or did consume illicit drugs, alcohol, alcoholic beverages if a person has not taken all reasonable steps to prevent the
consumption of illicit drugs, alcohol, alcoholic beverages by a minor.
D. Duty To Take Responsible Steps: It is the duty of any person who permits, allows, or hosts an event or gathering at a residence or premises under his
or her control or reasonable opportunity to control, or in any conveyance under his or her control or reasonable opportunity to control, where minors will
be present, to take all reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of illicit drugs, alcohol, or alcoholic beverages by any minor at the event or
gathering.
E. Intentional Actions: A person is responsible for violating and is in violation of this section if that person intentionally aids, advises, hires, counsels,
conspires with, or solicits another person to commit a violation of this section.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 182/618
F. Prima Facie Evidence: It shall be prima facie evidence that any person present in, within, on and/or upon any residence, premises, or conveyance
where a violation of this section occurred and which was under his or her control or reasonable opportunity to control, had knowledge of such
violation(s).
G. Absent Host: A person who hosts an event or gathering does not have to be present at the event or gathering to be liable under this section.
H. Costs: In addition to any fine imposed, a person found to be in violation of this section shall be responsible for any and all response costs incurred to
investigate and/or respond to the event or gathering.
I. Exceptions: The following are exceptions to a violation of this section:
1. This section shall not apply to conduct involving the use of alcohol or alcoholic beverages that occurs at a religious ceremony or exclusively between
a minor and his or her parent or legal guardian, as permitted by Illinois state law.
2. Any person who hosts an event or gathering shall not be in violation of this section, if he or she seeks assistance from the village police department
or other law enforcement agency to remove any person who refuses to abide by a person's exercise of reasonable steps, or terminates the event or
gathering because of an inability to prevent a minor from consuming illicit drugs, alcohol, or alcoholic beverages despite having taken reasonable
steps to do so, as long as such request is made or termination occurs prior to any complaints being made about the event or gathering.
J. Penalties: Any person who is in violation of this section shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined for each such violation as
follows:
1. The first violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00).
2. A second violation of this section by the same person within a twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
3. A third or subsequent violation of this section by the same person within a twelve (12) month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
Each day of which, or during which, a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2011-67, 9-1-2011)
ARTICLE B. OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
6-6B-1: TRESPASS:
A. Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within the village upon either public or private property.
B. Acts Constituting Trespass: Without constituting any limitation upon the provisions of subsection A of this section, any of the following acts by any
person, firm or corporation shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in violation of the provisions of said subsection A:
1. An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including any public property in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main
entrance to the premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or
occupant thereof;
2. The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or exhibited
at the main entrance to the premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by
any owner or occupant thereof;
3. A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or occupant
thereof;
4. An entry into or upon any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft made without the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control thereof
or a failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle after being requested to leave by the person having such right. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-1)
6-6B-2: CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
Whoever commits any of the following acts shall be guilty of a violation of this code:
A. Knowingly damages any property of another;
B. Recklessly, by means of a fire or an explosive, damages property of another;
C. Knowingly starts a fire on the land of another;
D. Knowingly injures a domestic animal of another without his consent;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 183/618
E. Knowingly deposits on the land or in the building of another any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound and thereby intends to interfere with
the use by another of the land or building; or
F. Damages any property with intent to defraud an insurer. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-2; amd. 2011 Code)
G. 1. Removing, altering, defacing, covering, manufacturing, or destroying the manufacturer's serial number or any other manufacturer's number or
distinguishing identification mark upon any machine or other article of merchandise for the purpose of concealing or destroying the identity of such
machine or article of merchandise and being in possession of said machine or article.
2. Any machine or other article of merchandise which is affected by or used in the process of removing, altering, defacing, covering or destroying a
machine or article of merchandise shall be confiscated by the appropriate governmental authority. (Ord. 96-68, 7-25-1996)
3. Anyone found to have violated this subsection G shall be guilty of a petty offense and fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 96-68, 7-
25-1996; amd. 2011 Code)
6-6B-3: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC PROPERTY:
No person shall cut, injure, mark, alter, break, remove, destroy or otherwise damage any public street, public park or parkway, public sidewalk, public
building, any sewer or water pipe, hydrant, buffalo box, water meter, lamppost, traffic sign or signal or other public sign, any public fencing, tennis courts,
public recreation supplies or facilities or equipment, and any tree, shrub, plant, ornamental foliage or flowers growing in or upon any public park or
parkway, nor shall any person cause any damage to any grass or turf or recreation area within a public park or parkway by use of a motor vehicle or other
apparatus, or dig up or remove any grass, soil, clay, sand or gravel from any such public park, parkway or recreation area within the village. This section
shall not include grass cutting and landscaping activities and the planting, cutting or removal of trees or shrubs or recreational equipment within public
park, parkway or recreation areas by village employees or recreation personnel acting pursuant to instructions or permission given by the village
administrator or the parks, recreation and facilities director. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-7)
6-6B-4: POSTING HANDBILLS AND ADVERTISEMENTS:
No person shall paste, post, print, nail or otherwise erect any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind in any public park or parkway
including any tree, lamppost, hydrant, and utility service pole therein, or on any sidewalk, alley, street or public building within the village; provided, that this
section shall not apply to the posting of legal notices pursuant to law. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-5)
6-6B-5: DEFACING ADVERTISING:
No person shall wilfully and maliciously tear down, mutilate and deface or render illegible any poster, notice or handbill lawfully posted upon any street,
alley or other place in the village. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-3)
6-6B-6: VANDALISM; REWARD PROVISIONS:
There is hereby established a reward in an amount not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for any one person which shall be given by the village to
any person or corporation or institution who submits information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person committing an act of vandalism to any
public property or within any public place or public park or recreation area, and including therein acts of defacement or destruction or injury or damage to
or unauthorized removal of any public structure (including streetlights) or sign (including traffic signs); or to any recreation equipment or apparatus in a
public park and recreation area or public building; or to any tree or shrubbery located within a public park or on a public parkway, or to any public property,
vehicle or apparatus located within a public building or upon public grounds (including any fire station or library building located within the village). In
determining the amount of reward, the village board shall consider the cost of the damage occasioned to public property by such vandalism, the
seriousness or number of acts of vandalism involved, the length of court proceedings leading to conviction, and such other circumstances as the village
board deems proper. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-6)
6-6B-7: ABANDONED SHOPPING CARTS:
A. Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or cause to be abandoned any cart or basket obtained from any retail store within the village.
B. Determination Of Abandonment: A cart or basket obtained from a retail store shall be deemed abandoned when it has been removed from any parking
area immediately adjacent to the retail store. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-4)
C. Nuisance Declared; Impoundment, Redemption And Disposal: Any abandoned cart or basket is hereby declared to be a nuisance and shall be
confiscated by proper village officials and impounded at the village hall until claimed by a representative of the retail store owning the cart or basket.
The impounded cart or basket shall be released to its proper owner upon payment of a storage fee in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00). The
abandoned cart or basket shall be held by the village for a period of ten (10) days, after which time, any unclaimed cart or basket shall be disposed of
in any manner deemed fit by the village. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-4; amd. 2011 Code)
6-6B-8: USE OF PUBLIC BUILDINGS FOR POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
No public building in the village shall be used by any person, political organization or political party for purposes of conducting political activities, including
rallies, speeches, debates and other activities of a partisan political nature. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-5)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 184/618
6-6B-9: THEFT:
A person commits the offense of theft, which shall be a violation of this code, when:
A. He knowingly obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or
B. He knowingly obtains by deception control over property of the owner; or
C. He knowingly obtains by threat control over property of the owner; or (1978 Code § 10-6-4-9)
D. He knowingly obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to be stolen by another or under such circumstances as would reasonably
induce him to believe that the property was stolen; or
E. He knowingly obtains or exerts control over property in the custody of any law enforcement agency which is explicitly represented to him by any law
enforcement officer or any individual acting in behalf of a law enforcement agency as being stolen, and: (1978 Code § 10-6-4-9; amd. 2011 Code)
1. Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; or
2. Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such a manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
3. Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use
or benefit.
F. The property has a total value not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00). (1978 Code § 10-6-4-9)
6-6B-10: RETAIL THEFT:
A. A person commits the offense of retail theft when he or she knowingly:
1. Takes possession of, carries away, transfers, or causes to be carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale
in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
2. Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or
in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
3. Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such
merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
4. Under rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; or
5. Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart; or (1978 Code § 10-6-4-8)
6. Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of property, knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts to
convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange for money, merchandise credit or other property of the merchant; or
7. Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the
merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
8. Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the
property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such
property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring such, within ten (10) days after written demand from the owner for its
return. A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee and
shown on the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand. (2011 Code)
B. If any person: 1) conceals upon his or her person or among his or her belongings, unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale
in a retail mercantile establishment; and 2) removes that merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that merchandise in
that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise with the
intention of retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without
paying the full retail value of such merchandise. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-8)
C. The words and phrases defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16A-2.1 through 5/16A-2.11, "retail theft", shall be applicable to the provisions of this
section. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-8; amd. 2011 Code)
6-6B-11: THEFT FROM RECYCLING BINS:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not the owner or occupant of any premises upon which is located a bin or bins used for the collection of recycled
paper, glass, aluminum, tin or other recyclable materials, said bins having been furnished by or on behalf of the village, to remove, assist in removing or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 185/618
cause to be removed any material that has been placed in such a recycling bin or bins, unless authorized by the village. Any person violating any of the
provisions of this section shall be fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (1978 Code § 10-6-4-10; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE C. OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS AND DECENCY
6-6C-1: GAMBLING:
A. Definitions:
GAMBLING DEVICE: 1. Any clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machine or device for the reception of money or other thing of value on
chance or skill or upon the action of which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost, or any mechanism, furniture, fixture,
equipment or other device designed primarily for use in a gambling place.
2. A gambling device does not include:
a. A coin in the slot operated mechanical device played for amusement which rewards the player with the right to replay such mechanical device,
which device is so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and which
returns to the player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property.
b. Vending machines by which full and adequate return is made for the money invested and in which there is no element of chance or hazard.
c. A crane game. For purposes of this definition, a "crane game" is an amusement device involving skill, if it rewards the player exclusively with
merchandise contained within the amusement device proper and limited to toys, novelties and prizes other than currency, each having a
wholesale value which is not more than twenty five dollars ($25.00).
d. A redemption machine. For the purposes of this definition, a "redemption machine" is a single-player or multi-player amusement device
involving a game, the object of which is throwing, rolling, bowling, shooting, placing, or propelling a ball or other object that is either physical or
computer generated on a display or with lights into, upon, or against a hole or other target that is either physical or computer generated on a
display or with lights, or stopping, by physical, mechanical, or electronic means, a moving object that is either physical or computer generated on
a display or with lights into, upon, or against a hole or other target that is either physical or computer generated on a display or with lights,
provided that all of the following conditions are met:
(1) The outcome of the game is predominantly determined by the skill of the player.
(2) The award of the prize is based solely upon the player's achieving the object of the game or otherwise upon the player's score.
(3) Only merchandise prizes are awarded.
(4) The wholesale value of the prizes awarded in lieu of tickets or tokens for single play of the device does not exceed twenty five dollars
($25.00).
(5) The redemption value of tickets, tokens, and other representations of value, which may be accumulated by players to redeem prizes of
greater value, for a single play of the device does not exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00).
LOTTERY: Any scheme or procedure whereby one or more prizes are distributed by chance among persons who have paid or promised
consideration for a chance to win such prizes, whether such scheme or procedure is called a lottery, raffle, gift, sale or some other name.
