The third and subsequent violations of this provision within a one (1) year period shall be a petty offense punishable by a fine not less than three
hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
(Ord. 2008-48, 6-26-2008)
Chapter 2
VEHICLE LICENSES
7-2-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter, the term "resident of the Village" shall include any corporation or business in the Village. (Ord. 2009-49, 6-4-2009)
7-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; INVALIDITY:
A. License Required:
1. All residents of the Village who own, operate, maintain, house, store, rent, lease, or have custody of a vehicle or series of vehicles that is/are
registered with the Illinois Secretary of State to an address within the Village shall obtain a Village vehicle license for the current year for the use of
such vehicle on any public street or highway within the Village. Residents of the Village are required to present a valid current Illinois registration
showing that the vehicle is registered to them at their Glendale Heights address prior to obtaining a vehicle license.
2. No resident of the Village shall use, cause or permit any of his agents or employees to use any motor vehicle upon the public streets or highways in
the Village unless such vehicle is licensed by the Village.
B. Proof Of Residency:
1. All residents to whom the Village mails a current year vehicle license application shall not be required to present a valid current Illinois registration
showing that the vehicle is registered to them at their Glendale Heights address prior to obtaining a vehicle license as long as the information
contained in the application is current and valid.
2. All residents of the Village who are in possession of a rented or leased vehicle and the vehicle is not registered to them at their Glendale Heights
address shall present a valid current rental or lease agreement for the vehicle prior to obtaining a vehicle license. The rental or lease agreement
must reflect the resident's Glendale Heights address.
3. Students attending college or a technical/trade school who reside in the Village, but are not residents of the Village, and who do not possess a
vehicle registered to their Glendale Heights address, may nonetheless obtain a vehicle license by presenting a valid current housing lease or rental
agreement and current valid student identification. The housing lease or rental agreement must reflect the student's Glendale Heights address.
4. All residents of the Village who operate, maintain, house, store, or have custody of a vehicle or series of vehicles that is/are owned, rented, or leased
by their employer and not registered with the Illinois Secretary of State to an address within the Village shall present proof from their employer that
the vehicle is in the possession of the resident of the Village and that the resident is authorized to use the vehicle. In addition, the resident of the
Village must present proof that the vehicle is owned, rented, or leased by his employer.
5. If a resident is unable to present a valid current Illinois registration, then the Finance Director, or her designee, in her or her designee's sole
discretion, may accept a current utility bill, a current lease, a valid driver's license, or any other valid form of proof deemed acceptable to evidence
residency within the Village of Glendale Heights.
6. If a resident is unable to present evidence of residency, the Finance Director, or her designee, may issue a Village vehicle license to such resident at
an annual fee that is double the normal fee for a vehicle license under this chapter.
C. Invalidity Of License If Obtained Through Fraud: It shall be a violation of this chapter to obtain a Village vehicle license by or through fraud,
misinformation, misrepresentation or falsifying documentation. Any Village vehicle license obtained or displayed by such means shall be invalid and
void. (Ord. 2019-25, 4-18-2019)
7-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 201/618
Any person desiring a license required by this chapter shall prepare an application upon a form provided by the Finance Director, setting forth the name
and address within the Village of the applicant, a description of the automobile or vehicle for which the license is desired, its license plate number, the
place where such automobile or vehicle is to be kept when not in use, the number and kind of other automobiles or vehicles kept by applicant at such
place, whether the place where such automobile or vehicle is to be kept is rented or owned by the applicant, and such other information as may be
prescribed. The application shall be transmitted to the Finance Director and upon payment by the applicant of the required license fee, the Finance
Director shall issue a license which shall be attested by such Director authorizing the use of such automobile, or other vehicle, within the Village until the
expiration of the license. (Ord. 2019-25, 4-18-2019)
7-2-4: LICENSE FEES:
A. Annual Fees:
1. Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, the charge for the annual vehicle license for vehicles registered with the Illinois Secretary of State to an
address within the Village shall be as follows:
Motor vehicles not in commercial use $ 15.00
Motorcycles, motorbikes and motor scooters 12.00
Recreational vehicles 18.00
Motor trucks, motor omnibuses and other motor vehicles used for commercial purposes or for hire:
8,000 lbs. or less 25.00
8,001 lbs. to 12,000 lbs. 35.00
12,001 lbs. to 16,000 lbs. 55.00
16,001 lbs. to 26,000 lbs. 60.00
26,001 lbs. to 32,000 lbs. 70.00
32,001 lbs. to 50,000 lbs. 75.00
50,001 lbs. to 64,000 lbs. 80.00
64,001 lbs. to 80,000 lbs. 100.00
(Ord. 2009-26, 4-2-2009)
2. The weight of a vehicle, for the purpose of establishing the license fee for such vehicle, shall be determined in the manner provided by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes for determining these factors for the purpose of fixing the State license fees. (1978 Code § 11-7-5; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Transfer Fee: The fee for transfer of any license required by this section shall be one dollar ($1.00). (1978 Code § 11-7-3)
7-2-5: TERM OF LICENSE; EXPIRATION; FEES PRORATED; LATE PAYMENT CHARGE:
A. Term Of License: For the purpose of this section, the licensing year shall run from July 1 of the current year to June 30 of the following year.
B. Expiration Of License; Fees Prorated: All licenses required by this chapter shall expire on June 30 of the licensing year for which they were issued, and
the fee to be paid shall be the full annual rate for that year; provided, however, that if such vehicle has been purchased or otherwise acquired by the
applicant on or after January 1 of the licensing year for which a license is applied, or if the applicant has moved to the Village from another municipality
on or after January 1 of the licensing year for which a license is applied, the fee to be paid for the remainder of the licensing year shall be an amount
equal to one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee, but the applicant shall be entitled to such reduced fee only upon submission to the village clerk of
evidence satisfactory to him that the vehicle was purchased or otherwise acquired on or after January 1.
C. Late Charge: A late charge shall be charged in the event that such license is acquired after the date when the license shall have been obtained in
accordance with this section as follows:
1. There shall be a late charge of ten dollars ($10.00) in the event the vehicle license is purchased during the month of July.
2. There shall be a late charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) in the event the vehicle license is purchased during the month of August.
3. There shall be a late charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) in the event the vehicle license is purchased during the month of September.
4. The maximum late charge shall be thirty dollars ($30.00).
D. Payment And Collection Of Fee:
1. When a resident applies for the current year's vehicle license, the village clerk shall determine whether or not the resident has purchased a vehicle
license for the same vehicle for the prior year. In the event the resident owned the same vehicle during the prior year, had been a resident of the
village during the prior year, and has not purchased a vehicle license, the village clerk shall collect the fee owed for the prior year's license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 202/618
2. When an individual moves to the village or begins his/her temporary residence in the village or acquires a vehicle that has not previously been
licensed with the village, the individual shall be allowed a forty five (45) day grace period within which to pay the required fee and obtain a vehicle
license. (Ord. 2007-71, 6-21-2007)
7-2-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
A. Every person who pays the required license fee shall receive a vehicle license sticker, and such sticker shall be affixed permanently to the inside front
windshield on the passenger side (lower right hand corner) of the vehicle. In the case of motorcycles, such sticker shall be affixed to the license plate or
where authorized by the state.
B. Village license stickers for motor vehicles shall be kept conspicuously and readily readable at all times when such vehicle is operated, stored, housed or
maintained within the village. (Ord. 2007-71, 6-21-2007)
7-2-7: AUTOMOBILE DEALERSHIPS:
Any automobile dealership operating within the corporate limits of the village shall be required to purchase village vehicle licenses in the form and style
furnished by the village, and shall attach such vehicle license to the Illinois state license plates. The fee for said dealer vehicle license shall be seven
dollars fifty cents ($7.50) per annum, and shall be transferable among all vehicles owned by the automobile dealership. At the time of application, the
automobile dealership shall inform the village as to the number of dealer vehicle licenses it shall require, and upon receipt of said application, the village
clerk shall assign certain dealer vehicle license numbers to the automobile dealership, and maintain a record of the numbers issued to said automobile
dealership. (1978 Code § 11-7-4)
7-2-8: CARDS FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
The village clerk shall issue, without charge, upon the application of any person with a disability a special motorist card or decal for persons with
disabilities furnished by the Illinois secretary of state pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois vehicle code for the purpose of allowing said card or decal to
be used and displayed on a vehicle being used to transport said person with a disability but not owned thereby or not displaying a special license plate for
a person with a disability, so as to identify said vehicle and entitle it to all the parking privileges afforded to a vehicle possessing such special license plate
for a person with a disability. Such card or decal shall be issued only to persons with disabilities who are residents of the village, and the same shall be
displayed along the right border of the front windshield of a vehicle and shall allow the vehicle to utilize special parking privileges for persons with
disabilities when used to transport such person with disabilities. (1978 Code § 11-7-10; amd. 2011 Code)
7-2-9: ENFORCEMENT:
A. Citation And Fine:
1. Any person violating any provision of this chapter relating to the purchase and display of an annual vehicle license for a vehicle registered with the
Illinois secretary of state to an address within the village shall immediately be issued a citation by the village police department.
2. The village clerk may also request the village police department issue a citation.
3. The fine for a citation issued pursuant to this chapter shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), plus proof that the subject license has been obtained as herein
required. (Ord. 2009-49, 6-4-2009)
B. Settlement And Compromise Of Violations: Any person accused of violating any provision of this chapter relating to the purchase and display of an
annual vehicle license shall be allowed to settle and compromise such violation in the manner provided in section 7-7-13 of this title, plus proof that the
subject license has been obtained and has been displayed as herein required. (1978 Code § 11-7-9)
7-2-10: EXEMPTIONS:
A. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to owners or operators of any government vehicle.
B. No license fee shall be required for vehicles owned by the village, the village police department, the Glenside fire protection district, school districts
located within the village, or school buses operated by nonprofit corporations, public or parochial schools, by a company on a certificate of convenience
and necessity from the Illinois commerce commission, or as part of a transportation system operated by the village or by the regional transportation
authority.
C. 1. The following persons shall not be required to pay the fee associated with a vehicle license upon presentation of proper identification illustrating that
the individual is one of the following:
a. A volunteer member of the village auxiliary police department or the Glenside fire department;
b. An active duty member of any branch of the United States armed forces;
c. A disabled veteran eligible for the disabled veterans' plate under state law;
d. A person who is sixty two (62) years of age or older; or (Ord. 2007-112, 12-6-2007)
e. A person with a disability who presents current proof thereof from the social security administration. (Ord. 2007-112, 12-6-2007; amd. 2011 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 203/618
2. Only one such exempt vehicle license shall be issued hereunder to each household. (Ord. 2007-112, 12-6-2007)
Chapter 3
ENFORCEMENT OF REGULATIONS
7-3-1: AUTHORITY TO DIRECT TRAFFIC:
Members of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in accordance with the provisions of this title, or in emergencies as public
safety or convenience may require. Except in case of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by law to direct traffic. (1978 Code
§ 11-1-2)
7-3-2: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE:
No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of any police officer, fireman or school crossing guard invested by law and
authority to direct, control or regulate traffic. (1978 Code § 11-1-3; amd. 2011 Code)
7-3-3: TICKETS AND BAIL:
A. Issuance Of Tickets: Police officers of the village are hereby authorized to issue uniform traffic tickets as authorized by state law.
B. Bail: Any person arrested for a violation of any provision of this title shall be released upon proper bail being furnished as required by statute. (1978
Code § 11-1-12)
ARTICLE A. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM
7-3A-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created a system for the administrative adjudication of standing, parking and compliance violations and a system for vehicle
immobilization. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-2: AUTHORITY, PURPOSE AND EFFECT:
A. The provisions of this article shall provide a system of administrative adjudication as required by section 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code in order to
provide for fair and efficient enforcement of vehicular parking, standing and compliance regulations through administrative adjudication.
B. The provisions of this section shall also permit the village to adopt those procedures pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5 providing for
the authority to file a certified report to the Illinois secretary of state upon a person's failure to satisfy any fine or penalty imposed by this article or by a
final judgment from a court of law for ten (10) or more standing, parking, and/or compliance violations.
C. Furthermore, notwithstanding any provision of this article, the village may continue to prosecute in any court of competent jurisdiction any person
receiving vehicular standing, parking, and/or compliance violations. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-3: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIALS:
A. Traffic Compliance Administrator: The village chief of police or his designee shall designate any person to serve as traffic compliance administrator, and
that person shall be authorized to adopt, distribute and process parking and compliance violation notices and other notices required by this article,
collect monies paid as fines and penalties for violation of standing, parking and compliance ordinances and operate the administrative adjudication
system. The traffic compliance administrator may also make a certified report to the secretary of state as required under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/6-306.5.
B. Hearing Officer: An individual to be named by the village president shall serve as hearing officer and shall perform such duties as defined within this
article. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-4: ISSUANCE OF CITATIONS; CONTENTS:
A. Any officer or employee of the village authorized to issue vehicle parking, standing and compliance citations and who detects a violation of any section
of this title restricting or prohibiting parking or standing of motor vehicles or requiring display of a village vehicle license shall issue a standing, parking
and compliance violation notice by either affixing it to an offending vehicle or handing it to the operator of such vehicle if he or she is present. Any
person authorized to issue and serve parking violation notices shall certify as to the correctness of the facts entered on the violation notice by signing
his or her name at the time of service.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 204/618
B. The violation notice shall specify the date, time and place of violation, the particular regulation violated, the fine and penalty that may be assessed for
any late payment, the vehicle make and state registration number, and the identification number of the person issuing the notice. The violation notice
shall further state that the payment of the indicated fine, and of any applicable penalty for late payment, shall operate as a final disposition of the
violation. Notice shall also contain information as to the availability of a hearing in which the violation may be contested on its merits. The violation
notice shall specify the time and manner in which a hearing may be had. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-5: ACTION BY RECIPIENT OF CITATION:
A person receiving a citation or notice for a violation may make an appearance in one of the following manners:
A. By payment of a fine indicated on the citation. Such payment shall be made by the deadline stated on the citation and shall operate as the final
disposition of the violation; or
B. By requesting a hearing on the merits of the violation notice in the time and manner specified on the notice and attendance at the hearing at the time,
date and place specified by the traffic compliance administrator. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with procedures set forth in section
208.3(b)(4) of the Illinois vehicle code1. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-6: FAILURE TO APPEAR; ADDITIONAL VIOLATION NOTICES:
Failure to make an appearance shall result in additional notices of violation as indicated in this section being sent by first class United States mail, postage
prepaid, to the registered owner of the cited vehicle at his or her address as recorded with the secretary of state or to the lessee of the cited vehicle at the
last address known to the lessor of said vehicle at the time of the lease. Service of notices shall be complete as of the date of deposit in the United States
mail.
A. Second Notice Of Violation: A second notice of violation shall be sent to the responsible party as set forth in the above paragraph upon the failure of the
recipient of a violation notice to make an appearance as prescribed in section 7-3A-5 of this article. The recipient may appear by either paying the
indicated fine and assessed penalty for late charges or by requesting a hearing on the merits of the citation in the time and manner specified on the
second notice and attending such hearing at the time, date and place specified by the traffic compliance administrator. The second notice shall specify
the date and location of the violation cited in the violation notice, the particular regulation violated, the vehicle make and state registration number, the
fine and any late penalty which may be assessed, the availability of a hearing in which the violation may be contested on its merits, and the time and
manner in which such hearing may be had. The notice shall also state that failure either to pay the indicated fine and any applicable penalty or to
appear at a hearing on the merits will result in a final determination of liability for the cited violation in the amount of fine or penalty indicated thereon,
and that upon the occurrence of a final determination of violation liability for such failure, and the exhaustion of, or failure to exhaust, available
administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the village.
B. Notice Of Final Determination Of Violation Liability: A notice of final determination of violation liability shall be sent to the responsible party upon the
failure to appear pursuant to the second notice of violation and after a final determination of liability has been rendered and the conclusion of judicial
review procedures in accordance with section 7-3A-7 of this article. The recipient may appear by paying the fine and penalty within the time specified
on the notice and shall be advised that failure to do so may result in the village filing a petition in the county circuit court to have the unpaid fine or
penalty rendered a judgment as provided by paragraph 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code2, or may result in suspension of the person's driver's
license pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5 for failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or more standing, parking or compliance
violations.
C. Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension: A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the person for whom a final
determination of liability was rendered for any fine that remains due and owing on ten (10) or more violations. The notice shall state that failure to pay
the fines and/or penalties owing within forty five (45) days of the notice date shall result in notification to the secretary of state of said person's eligibility
for initiation of driver's license suspension proceedings. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the registered owner of the
vehicle, by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, at the address recorded with the secretary of state. The notice shall also inform the person
that he may obtain a photostatic copy of an original citation imposing a fine or penalty by sending a self-addressed stamped envelope to the village
along with a request for the photostatic copy. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-7: FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY; PETITION TO SET ASIDE:
A. A final determination of violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine or penalty after a hearing officer's determination of violation liability
and the exhaustion or failure to exhaust administrative review procedures as set forth herein.
B. A determination of violation liability may be set aside by filing a petition with the traffic compliance administrator within ten (10) working days after the
hearing officer's determination. Petitions to set aside a determination shall specify the grounds upon which a challenge is based and shall be limited to
the following:
1. The person owing the unpaid fine and/or penalty was neither the owner nor lessee of the cited vehicle(s) on the date or dates the violation notice
was issued;
2. The fine and/or penalty was paid for the violation in question; or
3. Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing.
C. The traffic compliance administrator shall render a decision within fourteen (14) days of the petition's receipt and shall immediately notify the hearing
officer and petitioner of such decision in writing sent to the petitioner by first class United States mail, postage prepaid. If the petitioner has shown just
cause, the traffic compliance administrator shall set aside the violation liability determination.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 205/618
D. If the petition is granted and the determination of liability set aside, the registered owner or lessee shall be provided a hearing on the merits of the
violation and shall be given notice of the time and manner in which it will take place. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-8: ADJUDICATION PROCEDURES:
The violation notice and the second notice of liability shall provide the alleged violator with the time and manner in which a hearing contesting the merits of
the alleged violation shall be held. Neither formal nor technical rules of evidence shall apply. Such hearing shall be recorded, and the person conducting
the hearing on behalf of the traffic compliance administrator shall be empowered to administer oaths and to secure by subpoena both the attendance and
testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers. Persons appearing at such hearing may be represented by counsel at their own
expense. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-9: CERTIFIED REPORT; CONTESTING REPORT:
A. Upon failure to pay fines and penalties deemed due and owing after the exhaustion of administrative procedures set forth herein for ten (10) or more
violations, the traffic compliance administrator shall make a certified report to the secretary of state stating that the registered owner of a vehicle has
failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing as a result of ten (10) or more violations of the village vehicular parking, standing, or compliance
regulations and thereby causing the suspension of that person's driver's license. A copy of the certified report shall be sent to the registered owner.
B. Persons may challenge the accuracy of the certified report by completing a form provided by the office of the traffic compliance administrator within ten
(10) days after the date of the certified report which specifies grounds on which such challenge is based. Grounds for challenge shall be limited to the
following:
1. The person was neither the owner nor lessee of the vehicle(s) receiving ten (10) or more violation notices on the date or dates such notices were
issued; and
2. The person has already paid the fine and penalty for the ten (10) or more violations indicated on the certified report.
C. The traffic compliance administrator shall render a determination within ten (10) business days of receipt of the objection form and shall notify the
objector of the determination.
D. The traffic compliance administrator shall take no further action to initiate suspension if the fines and penalties due and owing are paid or upon
determination that the inclusion of the person's name on the certified report was in error, and the traffic compliance administrator shall submit to the
secretary of state a notification which shall result in the halting of a driver's license suspension proceeding. The person named therein shall receive a
certified copy of such notification upon request and at no charge. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3A-10: PROCEDURE FOR NONRESIDENTS:
A. Persons who are not residents of the village may contest the merits of the alleged violation without attending a hearing as provided herein by submitting
a waiver of hearing and a notarized statement of facts specifying grounds for challenging the notice of violation. Such documentation must be received
by the traffic compliance administrator within the time for requesting a hearing.
B. The hearing officer shall issue to the traffic compliance administrator a finding based on the statement of facts.
C. The traffic compliance administrator shall notify the nonresident of the hearing officer's determination.
D. In all other respects, the procedures set forth in this article shall apply to nonresidents. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
ARTICLE B. VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION
7-3B-1: PURPOSE:
The provisions of this article shall provide for a program of vehicle immobilization for the purpose of facilitating enforcement of vehicular standing, parking
and compliance regulations, and this program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle found to be on the public way by
the installation of a device of restraint to prevent the operation of said vehicle. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-2: SCOPE:
Any vehicle shall be eligible for immobilization when, at the time of immobilization, the registered owner of said vehicle has accumulated ten (10) or more
unpaid final determinations of parking, standing or compliance violations in accord with article A of this chapter or by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-3: NOTICE OF INTENDED IMMOBILIZATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 206/618
At least twenty one (21) days prior to vehicle immobilization, a notice of intended vehicle immobilization and a right to a hearing to challenge the validity of
the notice of impending immobilization by disproving liability for unpaid final determinations of parking, standing, or compliance violations listed on the
notice, shall be sent to the vehicle's registered owner by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, at the address of the registered owner recorded
with the secretary of state or, in the event that a vehicle bearing a registration number of a state other than the state of Illinois, at the address of the
registered owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. The impending immobilization notice shall state the name and address of the
registered owner, the state registration number of the vehicle, the nature of the ordinances violated and the numbers and issue dates of the outstanding
violation notices. The notice shall also advise that a person may challenge the validity of the notice of impending vehicle immobilization by appearing in
person on the date, time and location as set forth in the notice and submitting evidence which would conclusively disprove liability. Evidence shall be
limited to the following:
A. That the person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the date or dates the notices of violations were issued; or
B. That the fines or penalties for the violations cited in the notice were paid; or
C. The registered owner has not accumulated ten (10) or more violation notices which are unpaid, not adjudicated or for which no appearance has been
filed. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-4: IMMOBILIZATION, TOWING AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLE:
A. Immobilization Of Vehicle: In the event the registered owner of the vehicle fails to challenge the validity of the notice in a timely manner, or fails to satisfy
those fines and penalties determined to be due and owing, then the vehicle shall be immobilized.
B. Notice Of Immobilization: Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place, and such notice shall
warn that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in damage to the vehicle. In addition, the notice shall also
state that the unauthorized removal of or damage to the immobilizing restraint is a violation of sections 16-1 and 21-1 of the Illinois criminal code. The
notice shall further provide information specifying how release of immobilizing restraint may be had and how the registered owner may obtain an
immobilization hearing.
C. Towing And Impoundment Of Vehicle: In the event the immobilizing restraint has not been released, as hereinafter provided, within forty eight (48) hours
of its placement on the vehicle, then the restraint shall be released and the vehicle towed and impounded at the direction of the village chief of police.
(Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-5: RELEASE OF IMMOBILIZED VEHICLE PRIOR TO HEARING:
Prior to a hearing on the validity of vehicle immobilization as hereinafter provided, the owner of an immobilized vehicle or other authorized person shall be
permitted to secure the release of the vehicle by paying a deposit in an amount equal to the immobilization, towing and storage fees, if applicable, as
hereinafter specified. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-6: NOTICE OF IMPOUNDMENT; HEARING; IMMOBILIZATION FEE AND TOWING AND STORAGE COSTS:
A. Notice Of Impoundment: Within ten (10) days after a vehicle has been impounded, notice of impoundment shall be sent by United States certified mail,
return receipt requested and first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the registered owner of the vehicle. The notice of impoundment shall
state that the owner has a right to a postimmobilization and posttowing hearing as hereinafter provided and that if the vehicle is not claimed within thirty
(30) days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be sold or otherwise disposed of in accordance with applicable state law.
B. Hearing: The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a hearing to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing was
erroneous if the registered owner of said vehicle files a written demand for a hearing with the village traffic compliance administrator within fourteen
(14) days after issuance of the immobilization notice or within fourteen (14) days of the immobilization, whichever is later. Any such hearing requested
shall be conducted within forty eight (48) hours of receipt of the written demand for hearing unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the parties.
Failure to request or attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. In the event of such failure, any amounts deposited
pursuant to section 7-3B-5 of this article shall be forfeited. A hearing provided pursuant to this subsection shall not determine the validity of or
otherwise adjudicate any citation or notice of parking, standing, or compliance violation issued relative to the immobilized vehicle.
C. Immobilization Fee; Towing And Storage Costs: The fee for immobilization shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). In addition thereto, the registered
owner shall be responsible for all costs associated with towing subsequent to immobilization as well as any and all storage fees incurred.
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, no fee shall be assessed for immobilization, towing, or storage when such action has been determined to be
erroneous. (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000)
7-3B-7: RELOCATING OR TOWING RESTRAINED VEHICLE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to relocate or to tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device without the prior approval of the traffic compliance
administrator. Any person who relocates or otherwise moves an immobilized vehicle or attempts to remove an immobilization device in violation of the
provisions of this article shall be fined in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 2000-17, 3-2-2000; amd. 2011 Code)
ARTICLE C. TOWING ABANDONED, HAZARDOUS OR UNLAWFUL VEHICLES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 207/618
7-3C-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings stated in this section. Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning
ascribed to it in other ordinances of the village, and if not defined in any other village ordinances, it shall have the meaning ascribed in the Illinois vehicle
code, chapter 625 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
ABANDONED VEHICLE: A. A vehicle parked or otherwise located on the public way and:
1. In such a state of disrepair that it is incapable of being driven; or
2. That has been unmoved for a period of at least seven (7) days and, from its condition, the period during which it has not been moved, or some
other circumstance, appears to have been abandoned by its owner; or
B. Vehicles parked in a public parking lot or in a private parking lot without the consent of the lot owner, proprietor or agent of the property, which
person has requested that the vehicle be towed by the village of Glendale Heights or its approved towing service operators; or
C. A vehicle defined as abandoned or capable of being towed by any other ordinances of the village of Glendale Heights and which does not fall into
the categories of "hazardous" or "unlawful" vehicles, and therefore is not subject to an immediate tow.
HAZARDOUS VEHICLE: A. A vehicle that has been involved in an accident and is disabled or cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator of
the vehicle; or
B. A vehicle that presents an immediate danger to the health or welfare of the members of the public; or
C. A vehicle abandoned or disabled on a public street, way or alley that is impeding the orderly flow of traffic or poses a potential danger to pedestrians
and other operators of vehicles.
OWNER: A person who holds legal title of a motor vehicle or the right of possession of the motor vehicle.
UNLAWFUL VEHICLE: A. A vehicle that has been reported stolen or is the subject of a search and seizure by the police department; or
B. A vehicle parked in violation of state of Illinois statutes or ordinances of the village of Glendale Heights which prohibit parking at the location in
question or for the period of time for which the vehicle has been parked, and where either the statute or the ordinance authorizes the vehicle to be
towed and the signs posted at the location in question note that fact.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street, highway or any public way, including trailers
and other devices designed to be pulled by a propelled device. (1978 Code § 11-11-1; amd. 2011 Code)
7-3C-2: AUTHORIZATION FOR TOWING:
The towing of vehicles by the village or its approved towing service operators shall be authorized only by the police department and only under the
circumstances herein provided. Towed vehicles shall be impounded at facilities designated by the police department until lawfully claimed or disposed of
pursuant to state law, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes. (1978 Code § 11-11-2; amd. 2011 Code)
A. Towing Without Notice; Hazardous Or Unlawful Vehicles: Vehicles may be towed without notice where the vehicle is a hazardous or unlawful vehicle.
Within twenty four (24) hours after towing a vehicle pursuant to this article, a notice shall be sent to the owner of the vehicle affording the opportunity
for a hearing as provided in sections 7-3C-4 and 7-3C-5 of this article.
B. Towing With Prior Notice; Abandoned Vehicles: Abandoned vehicles may be towed after prior notice and the affording of an opportunity for a hearing as
provided in section 7-3C-3 of this article. (1978 Code § 11-11-2)
7-3C-3: PRETOW NOTICE AND HEARING FOR ABANDONED VEHICLES:
A. Notice Requirements:
1. Notice pursuant to this subsection shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the
vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state. In the event that an out of state vehicle is proposed to be towed,
inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made to the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current
registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished, though in no case
will the village be required to delay towing more than seven (7) days after the date of the mailing of the notice. The notice, in all cases, shall specify:
(1978 Code § 11-11-3; amd. 2011 Code)
a. A description of the vehicle;
b. The present location of the vehicle;
c. The legal and factual basis for the towing which is proposed;
d. The citation and a general description of the particular section of the ordinance or statute which authorizes the towing;
e. The opportunity to request a pretow hearing and the procedure for filing a written request for hearing;
f. An advisement that a request for hearing must be filed within seven (7) days from mailing of the notice;
g. The address and telephone number of the office to which a request for a hearing must be made.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 208/618
2. A notice of intent to tow sticker with the earliest date upon which the tow may take place and the address and phone number of the police
department shall be placed on the vehicle. (1978 Code § 11-11-3)
B. Hearing Procedures:
1. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to be towed as an abandoned vehicle shall have seven (7) days after the date of mailing of
the notice to request, in writing, a pretow hearing. Subsequent to this seven (7) day period, and in the event no written request for a pretow hearing
has been filed, the vehicle may be towed and any hearing rights under the provisions of this article will be deemed waived.
2. In the event that a pretow notice is not received by the owner of the vehicle, posttow hearing procedures shall be available, upon request of the
owner, as provided in sections 7-3C-4 and 7-3C-5 of this article.
3. Requests for a pretow hearing are to be made in person to the office indicated on the notice. Requests for hearing by persons who reside more than
fifty (50) miles from the village may be made by phone or by mail to the police department, with hearings to be scheduled at some time prior to the
scheduled towing. Forms for such requests shall be made available at the police department. At the time of making the request, the owner will be
provided a hearing date and time by telephone, by mail or in person, as the circumstances require.
4. The chief of police, or any officer or employee of the police department designated by the chief of police, shall serve as hearing officer. In no case
shall that hearing officer be an individual who was involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle. The hearing officer shall have the authority to
require the presence of the enforcement officer who initiated the proposed tow or any other municipal personnel and to request the presence of other
witnesses at the hearing.
5. After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make a written decision based upon a preponderance of the evidence as to whether
towing of the vehicle is authorized by the laws of the state of Illinois or this title with a specific statutory or village code section cited in the decision.
The owner shall be provided a copy of such pretow hearing decision. (1978 Code § 11-11-4)
6. If the preponderance of the evidence supports towing in compliance with the provisions of this article, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle
be towed with any towing and storage costs to then be imposed upon the owner thereof. The fees to be charged for towing and storage services
shall be at the rates established in section 7-3C-4 of this article. The owner of said vehicle having had such a hearing may avoid the towing by
immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a proper, lawful location and correcting any unlawful condition of the vehicle. (1978
Code § 11-11-4; amd. 2011 Code)
7. If the preponderance of the evidence fails to support towing or immobilization of the vehicle, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle shall not
be towed. The village shall furnish a copy of such decision to the owner, who may place it inside the vehicle in a location plainly visible from the
outside, such as the dashboard or rear window. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be towed by the village unless the
circumstances under which the decision was rendered have changed. If at some subsequent time the village should wish to tow that same vehicle
from the same location, it shall follow the same procedures required for the towing of any other similarly situated vehicle, including the sending of an
additional pretow notice as outlined in subsection A of this section.
8. All pretow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a period
of at least five (5) years after each hearing, or after each tow if no hearing was requested or held.
9. Any such hearing will not be determinative of or adjudicate any citation issued relative to the vehicle. (1978 Code § 11-11-4)
7-3C-4: POSTTOW NOTICE FOR HAZARDOUS OR UNLAWFUL VEHICLES:
A. Issuance And Contents: The police department shall transmit information relating to the right to a hearing as provided in section 7-3C-5 of this article
when mailing a notice of impoundment. Notice pursuant to this section shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the
address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state. In the event that the village has towed an
out of state hazardous or unlawful vehicle, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made to the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction
for the furnishing of the most current registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the
address furnished. The notice, in all cases, shall specify: (1978 Code § 11-11-5; amd. 2011 Code)
1. A description of the vehicle.
2. The present location of the impounded vehicle.
3. The legal and factual basis for the particular tow.
4. The citation and the language of the code section or statute which authorizes the towing.
5. The opportunity to request a posttow hearing and the procedure for filing a written request for hearing.
6. An advisement that a request for hearing must be filed within fifteen (15) days from mailing of the notice.
7. The address and telephone number of the office to which the request for the hearing must be made. (1978 Code § 11-11-5)
B. Right To Hearing Signs: All approved towing service operators shall prominently post two (2) large signs with dimensions of at least twelve inches by
eighteen inches (12" x 18"), indicating the opportunity and procedures for a hearing to contest the validity of a vehicle towed pursuant to this article.
These signs shall be placed in locations readily visible to the public transacting business at any towing facility. (1978 Code § 11-11-5; amd. 2011 Code)
C. Request For Hearing:
1. Requests for hearings may be made in person at the office indicated on the notice within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of the notification of tow or
release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first; otherwise, the right to the hearing shall be deemed waived. Requests for hearings by persons who
reside more than fifty (50) miles from the village may be made by telephone or mail to the police department.
2. Towing service personnel receiving requests for hearings shall direct the owner to the police department and shall direct the owner's attention to the
posted signs referred to in subsection B of this section concerning notice and hearings.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 209/618
3. Any police personnel receiving inquiries in the field for hearings shall direct such person to the police department.
4. Police personnel in the police department headquarters, when receiving a tow inquiry, shall advise the person making the inquiry of the right to a
hearing as set forth herein. If the inquiry is made in person, the police department shall provide a hearing request form and assist the person in
preparing the hearing request form.
D. Redemption Of Vehicle:
1. Proof Of Ownership: Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove same, the owner or
other person entitled to possession shall furnish evidence of his identity, ownership of the vehicle, or his right to possession, sign a receipt for the
vehicle, and pay an amount or arrange for a hearing as set forth in subsections D2 and D3 of this section. The police chief is authorized to
promulgate regulations as to the documents or other proof necessary to establish these facts. (1978 Code § 11-11-5)
2. Fees; Time For Redemption: The owner shall pay fees in accordance with the village franchise agreement to cover the cost of towing, removal, or
storage of the vehicle, and thereupon must take possession of his vehicle within twenty four (24) hours of payment. The owner may pay the full
amount of fees and subsequently request a hearing pursuant to this section and section 7-3C-5 of this article. (Ord. 2001-10, 1-18-2001)
3. Hearing:
a. The owner may request a hearing at the time of obtaining his vehicle. In that case, the owner shall submit a request for hearing and obtain
immediate release of his vehicle after full payment of all such fees currently owed. A hearing shall take place within fifteen (15) days after such
release and request unless the vehicle owner requests a later date; or
b. If the owner wishes a hearing but cannot or does not wish to post the current amount of towing and storage fees, he may submit a request for
hearing and allow the motor vehicle to remain impounded, and request either:
(1) A hearing under section 7-3C-5 of this article to be held within twenty four (24) hours of his request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and
holidays; or
(2) If acceptable to the owner, a hearing within fifteen (15) days of said request on a date convenient to the vehicle owner and the village. (1978
Code § 11-11-5)
7-3C-5: POSTTOW HEARING:
A. Right To Hearing:
1. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle towed, as an immediate tow, by or pursuant to the authority of the police department as set
forth herein, shall be provided the opportunity for a posttow hearing to determine the validity of such tow and any towing or storage charges. The
hearing will not be determinative of or adjudicate any citation issued relative to any towed vehicle.
2. Any owner otherwise entitled to a pretow hearing, as set forth in subsection 7-3C-3B of this article, to whom actual or mailed notice, pursuant to
subsection 7-3C-3A of this article, was not accomplished, shall have the opportunity to have a posttow hearing under this section, upon request, as
provided in section 7-3C-4 of this article.
B. Hearing Officer: The chief of police, or any other officer or employee of the police department designated by the chief of police, not involved in the initial
decision to tow the vehicle shall be designated as hearing officer by the village and shall conduct said hearing. The hearing officer may be the same
person designated for pretow hearings pursuant to subsection 7-3C-3B of this article. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the
presence of the enforcement officer who ordered the tow, or any other municipal personnel, and to request the presence of other witnesses at such
hearing.
C. Time For Hearing: Hearings shall take place as follows: In those instances where the vehicle is still impounded, the hearing shall take place at the
option of the owner:
1. Within twenty four (24) hours after an owner's request for such hearing, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays; if such request is made after
three o'clock (3:00) P.M., then a hearing shall be held on the second working day following the request; or
2. If acceptable to the owner, within fifteen (15) days of said request on a date convenient to all parties.
D. Notice Of Hearing: The hearing officer, or other designated personnel of the village, processing the owner's request for hearing shall have authority to
designate in writing a hearing date and time, and to so inform the owner of the date and time of the hearing by personal service of the writing at the
time the owner files a hearing request. In the event that a hearing request is made by telephone or mail by a person residing more than fifty (50) miles
from the village, the written designation of the hearing date and time shall be mailed to the owner not less than seven (7) days before the designated
hearing date, unless the owner waives such seven (7) day period by requesting an earlier hearing date.
E. Findings And Decision:
1. The hearing officer shall review all evidence presented by the vehicle owner and the police department and make a finding based upon the
preponderance of the evidence presented as to the lawful authority for the towing and storage of the vehicle. The village must establish such
authority by a preponderance of the evidence.
2. For each hearing, the hearing officer shall complete a vehicle tow hearing decision and attach such decision to the police department's original
vehicle towing report and supply a copy of the vehicle tow hearing decision to the owner by personal delivery if the owner is present, otherwise by
mail.
3. After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make one or more of the following written findings, which must be incorporated into the
vehicle tow hearing decision:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 210/618
a. Tow Authorized: The towing and storage of the vehicle was authorized by the laws of the state of Illinois or this title. One or more specific statutory
or code sections and the amount owed for towing and storage shall be stated in such a finding.
b. Tow Not Authorized: There was no authorization by law for the towing and storage of the vehicle, or the municipal employee causing the vehicle to
be towed did not comply with the requirements of the statute or section of this title authorizing the tow.
c. Tow Authorized; Storage Reimbursement: The towing of the vehicle was authorized by law, but the owner was caused to incur additional storage
charges because of late notification of towing or other reasons not the fault of the owner. The specific amount owed by the owner and the specific
amount excused shall be stated in the decision.
d. Request Not Timely: The request for hearing was not made within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of notice of towing or the date the vehicle was
released from the towing company, whichever was earlier.
e. Owner Failed To Appear; No Continuance Requested: A hearing was requested but the person requesting the hearing failed to appear and failed
to request a continuance.
4. The hearing officer shall advise the owner of his findings at the conclusion of the hearing.
a. If the towing and storage was authorized by law, and is not otherwise reimbursable, the owner shall be so informed and further advised as to the
amount due.
b. Should the towing and/or storage be found to be unauthorized or reimbursable, the hearing officer shall:
(1) If the vehicle has been released to the owner:
(A) Note the amount of the cash deposit or towing and storage fees prepaid by the owner on the vehicle tow hearing decision.
(B) Complete a printed voucher form for the amount to be reimbursed.
(C) Transmit said decision and voucher form to the chief of police for his authorization for payment.
(D) Advise the owner that a refund of said cash deposit or fees will be transmitted to the appropriate officials of the village for payment.
(E) Transmit a copy of said hearing decision along with the original voucher and original payment receipt to the appropriate officer of the village
within forty eight (48) hours of the hearing.
(F) Unless the village files a lawsuit to contest the decision of the hearing officer, the owner shall be paid the money due within twenty eight (28)
days after the decision of the hearing officer.
(2) If the vehicle is still in the possession of the towing company at the time of the hearing, the following procedure shall be followed:
(A) An order for the release of the vehicle shall be prepared in duplicate; the owner shall be provided with the original, and a copy shall be
attached to the vehicle tow hearing decision.
(B) Upon presentation by the owner to the towing company of the order for release, said vehicle shall immediately be released to the owner
without payment of any service charge excused by the hearing decision.
5. All vehicle tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a
period of at least five (5) years after each hearing, or after each tow if no hearing was requested or held.
6. The village or the owner may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner provided by law. (1978 Code § 11-11-6)
7-3C-6: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS TO TOWING SERVICE:
Notwithstanding any other statutory provisions or provisions of this title to the contrary, any towing service operator authorized to perform tows on behalf of
the village must perform its services subject to the provisions of this article. However, the towing company shall have the right to recover the reasonable
value of its services, not paid by the vehicle owner, from the village. (1978 Code § 11-11-6)
ARTICLE D. IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES USED IN COMMISSION OF OFFENSES
7-3D-1: IMPOUNDMENT AUTHORIZED; COSTS:
Any motor vehicle operated, used or in the physical control of person within the village with the express or implied permission of the registered owner or
lessee of record, during the commission of or in furtherance of any offense or violation set forth in section 7-3D-2 of this article shall be subject to
impoundment by the village, and the owner or lessee of record of the vehicle may be liable to the village for an administrative fee in an amount not to
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), in addition to any towing and storage fees as hereinafter provided. Any and all fees for towing and storage of a
vehicle impounded pursuant to this article shall be those approved by the chief of police for all towing companies authorized to tow for the village. (Ord.
2014-36, 6-5-2014)
7-3D-2: VIOLATIONS OR OFFENSES SUBJECT TO IMPOUNDMENT:
The following are violations or offenses subject to vehicle impoundment:
A. Driving while driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303; provided,
however, motor vehicles shall not be subject to impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation, whether parking or moving, or suspension is
due to failure to comply with emissions testing.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 211/618
B. Driving under the influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-501.
C. Unlawful use of a weapon (UUW), 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1; aggravated discharge of a firearm, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.2;
reckless discharge of a firearm, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5; or unlawful possession of a firearm and/or firearm ammunition, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1.
D. Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting or attempting to solicit cannabis or a controlled substance as defined by the Illinois cannabis control
act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., or the Illinois controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq.
E. Solicitation of a sexual act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14.1; or patronizing a minor engaged in prostitution, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
18.1.
F. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission or attempted commission of any offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited
pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1.
G. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission or attempted commission or any offense in violation of the Illinois controlled substances act, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq.
H. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in connection with the commission or attempted commission of any felony offense in violation of the provisions of
the Illinois cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq.
I. Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/6-101, where the period of expiration is greater than one year.
J. Operation or use of a motor vehicle without having ever been issued a driver's license or permit in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101; or
operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101.
K. Fleeing or attempting to elude a peace officer pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-5-2014)
7-3D-3: NOTICE OF IMPOUNDMENT; RELEASE OF VEHICLE PRIOR TO IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is subject to impoundment pursuant to this article, and the police officer has
effected an arrest for any of the offenses set forth in section 7-3D-2 of this article, the police officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility
authorized by the village. At the time the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner or lessee of the
vehicle, or any person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at
the time of the alleged offense, with written notice of the fact of the impoundment and of the vehicle owner's or lessee's and any lienholder of record's
right to request a preliminary vehicle impoundment hearing to be conducted in accordance with section 7-3D-4 and subsection 7-3D-5B of this article.
The vehicle shall be impounded pending the completion of the hearing(s) provided in section 7-3D-4 and subsection 7-3D-5B of this article, unless the
owner, lessee or lienholder of record of the vehicle posts with the village a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and pays the
towing and storage charges.
B. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A of this section, the arresting police officer may release the vehicle prior to towing if the vehicle subject to
impoundment was not owned by the person placed under arrest, and the registered owner, lessee or person legally authorized to possess the vehicle
shall arrive at the scene of the arrest prior to the actual removal or towing of the vehicle, and the lawful owner, lessee or person lawfully entitled to
possession of the vehicle possesses a valid operator's license, proof of ownership or registration, proof of liability insurance and would not, as
determined by the arresting police officer, indicate a lack of ability to operate the motor vehicle in a safe manner, or who would not otherwise, by
operating the motor vehicle, be in violation of the Illinois vehicle code; or
C. If the vehicle subject to impoundment is owned or leased by the person under arrest, the arresting officer may, prior to the actual removal or towing of
the vehicle, release the vehicle to another person with the written consent of the owner or lessee; provided, that such other person possesses a valid
operator's license, proof of liability insurance and would not, as determined by the arresting police officer, indicate a lack of ability to operate the motor
vehicle in a safe manner, or who would not otherwise, by operating the motor vehicle, be in violation of the Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-5-
2014)
7-3D-4: PRELIMINARY HEARING:
A. If the owner or lessee of record of a vehicle impounded desires to contest the impoundment of the vehicle at a preliminary hearing, he or she must
make a request for a preliminary hearing within twenty four (24) hours of the impoundment. The request shall be deemed filed upon delivery to the
chief of police care of the Glendale Heights police department. The preliminary hearing request shall be in writing, and the chief of police or his
designee shall conduct the preliminary hearing within twenty four (24) hours after receipt of the request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, or village
holidays, in which case, the preliminary hearing shall be heard on the next business day.
B. All interested parties shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the preliminary hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the
preliminary hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible only if it is of the type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the
conduct of their affairs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 212/618
C. If, after the hearing, the chief of police or his designee determines there is probable cause to believe that the vehicle is subject to impoundment, he/she
shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle as provided in this article, unless the owner, lessee or person entitled to possession of the vehicle
posts with the village a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and pays any applicable towing and storage fees. If the chief of
police or his/her designee determines that there is no such probable cause to believe the vehicle was used or operated during the commission or
attempted commission of any of the offenses set forth in section 7-3D-2 of this article, then the vehicle shall be returned to the registered owner without
penalty or other fees. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-5-2014)
7-3D-5: HEARING OFFICER; PROCEDURES; HEARING:
A. Hearing Officer: A hearing officer shall be appointed by the village administrator, and he or she shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state
of Illinois for a minimum of three (3) years next preceding the date of his/her appointment.
B. Procedures:
1. Notice Of Hearing: Within ten (10) days after a vehicle is impounded, the village shall notify the registered owner, lessee and any lienholder of record
by personal service or first class mail, postage prepaid, at the address as registered with the secretary of state of the date, time, and location of a
hearing that will be conducted pursuant to this section.
2. Owner/Lessee Present:
a. The owner or lessee of record and any lienholder of record may appear at the hearing to contest the basis for the impoundment. Hearings shall be
scheduled and held no later than forty five (45) days after the vehicle was seized, unless otherwise continued by order of a hearing officer.
Continuances shall be granted only for good cause shown. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the
hearing. At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer may, at the request of any party, direct witnesses to appear and give testimony at
the hearing. Subpoenas for the production of witnesses and records may be issued upon request and for good cause.
b. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible only if it is of the type commonly relied upon
by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
c. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used or operated in connection with or
during the commission or attempted commission of those offenses set forth in section 7-3D-2 of this article, the hearing officer shall enter an order
finding the owner or lessee of record of the vehicle civilly liable to the village for an administrative fee in an amount not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00), and requiring the vehicle to continue to be impounded until the owner or lessee pays the administrative fee to the village, plus
any and all fees, to the tower or village for the towing and storage of the vehicle as the case may be.
3. Owner/Lessee Not Present: If, after proper service of notice, the owner or lessee of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing officer shall
conduct the hearing in absentia and, if appropriate, enter a default order in favor of the village, a copy of which default order shall be sent to the
registered owner or lessee by first class mail, postage prepaid. If, at the hearing, the hearing officer finds that the vehicle was not operated or used
during the commission or in furtherance of any offense or violation set forth in section 7-3D-2 of this article, the hearing officer shall order the
immediate return of the vehicle and cash bond, if any, without assessing any fees or penalties.
C. Appeal: Any party may appeal a final decision of the hearing officer pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois administrative review law. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-
5-2014)
7-3D-6: PAYMENT OF FEE AND COSTS; LIEN AND DISPOSITION OF VEHICLE:
If an administrative fee is imposed pursuant to this article, the fee shall constitute a debt due and owing to the village. If a cash bond has been posted
pursuant to this article, the bond shall be applied to the fee. If a vehicle is impounded when a fee is imposed, the village may seek to obtain a judgment on
the debt and enforce such judgment against the vehicle as provided by law. Except as otherwise provided in this article, a vehicle shall continue to be
impounded until the fee is paid to the village and any applicable towing and storage fees are paid to the tower or village, as the case may be, in which
case, possession of the vehicle shall be given to the person who is legally entitled to possess the vehicle or the vehicle is sold or otherwise disposed of to
satisfy a judgment and lien as provided by law. If the administrative fee and applicable towing and storage fees are not paid within thirty (30) days after the
expiration of time in which administrative review of the hearing officer's determination may be sought, or within thirty (30) days after an action seeking
administrative review has been resolved in favor of the village, whichever is applicable, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in
the manner provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed vehicles under the Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-5-2014)
7-3D-7: REDEMPTION OF VEHICLE:
Except as may otherwise be provided by law or by order of the hearing officer, no owner, lessee, lienholder, or other person shall be legally entitled to take
possession of an impounded vehicle until the administrative fee and towing and storage fees have been paid. However, whenever a person or other entity
with a lien of record against an impounded vehicle has commenced foreclosure proceedings prior to the date of vehicle impoundment, possession of the
vehicle shall be given to that person if he or she agrees in writing to refund to the village the amount of the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, less any
amounts required to pay all lienholders of record, not to exceed the administrative fee, plus the applicable towing and storage fees. For purposes of this
section, the owner of record or lessee of record of a vehicle shall be the record titleholder as registered with the secretary of state, state of Illinois. (Ord.
2014-36, 6-5-2014)
7-3D-8: INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
A. This article shall be in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise abrogate any existing state or federal law or ordinance that relates to the seizure
and/or impoundment of motor vehicles, and any penalty provided in this article shall be in addition to any and all penalties that may be assessed or
imposed by a court for violation of any criminal offense or local ordinance offense.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 213/618
B. The provisions of this article are inapplicable if, at the time of the offense, the vehicle used in the offense or violation was stolen or otherwise operated
without the knowledge and express or implied consent of the registered owner or lessee, and the theft was reported to the appropriate police authority
within twenty four (24) hours after the theft was discovered. (Ord. 2014-36, 6-5-2014)
ARTICLE E. AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM
7-3E-1: ADOPTION:
There is hereby adopted an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System of the Village of Glendale Heights. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article:
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM: Means a device(s) located within the Village of Glendale Heights with one or more motor
vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce clear recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a steady
red or flashing red signal indication in violation of section 11-306 or 11-309 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title. The system is
designed to obtain a clear recorded image of a violating motor vehicle and its license plate, as well as the date, time and location of the violation.
DISREGARDING A TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE: Means failure to stop and remain stopped before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as
provided for in section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title.
NO TURN ON RED: Means where the motor vehicle comes to a complete stop and does not enter the intersection as defined by section 1-132 of the
Vehicle Code, during the cycle of the red signal indication, unless one or more pedestrians are present, even if the motor vehicle stops at a point past a
stop line or crosswalk where a driver is required to stop, as specified in subsection (c) of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or this article.
RECORDED IMAGES: Means images recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system, on two (2) or more photographs; two (2) or more
micrographs; two (2) or more electronic images; or a video recording showing the motor vehicle, capturing and displaying images of the motor vehicle
violating a traffic-control signal, and with at least one clearly recorded image identifying the vehicle's license plate. The recorded image shall also display
the time, date and location of the violation.
TRAFFIC COMPLIANCE ADMINISTRATOR: Means a person appointed by the Village's Chief of Police or his designee who shall have the following
power and authority: adopt, distribute and process automated traffic law violation notices and other such notices as may be required by this article, collect
and audit money paid to the Village as fines and/or penalties, operate the automated traffic law enforcement system, and make certified reports to the
Office of the Illinois Secretary of State, as required by this article and section 208.6 of the Vehicle Code. If the Traffic Compliance Administrator is the
person who reviews the recorded images on behalf of the Village to determine whether a violation has occurred, then the Traffic Compliance Administrator
shall be a Village police officer or retired Village police officer.
VEHICLE CODE: Means the Illinois Vehicle Code1.
VILLAGE: Means the Village of Glendale Heights, DuPage County, Illinois.
VILLAGE CODE: Means the Village Code of Ordinances of the Village of Glendale Heights, DuPage County, Illinois. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-3: SIGNAGE; COMPLIANCE WITH MANUAL ON UNIFORM TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
A. Any intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall have a sign posted which is visible to approaching traffic indicating
that the intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system.
B. The location of all intersections equipped with an automated traffic enforcement system shall be posted on the official Village website.
C. All intersections equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall have a yellow light change interval that conforms with the Illinois
Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-4: VIOLATION:
It shall be a violation of this article for a motor vehicle to be operated in violation of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code, or similar violation of subsection 7-
5-2C of this title. Liability for any such violation shall be imposed upon the registered owner or lessee of the violating vehicle. All violations must be
approved by a law enforcement or retired law enforcement officer employed by the Village. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-5: VIOLATIONS, REVIEW, NOTICE, SERVICE:
A. When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a motor vehicle entering an intersection in spite of a steady red signal indication, or fails to
completely stop on a steady red signal indication prior to turning right, in violation of section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or in violation of
subsection 7-5-2C of this title, the Village shall, for each violation recorded, issue or direct to be issued, a written Notice of Violation to the owner of the
vehicle as the alleged violator. The Notice of Violation shall be delivered by first class mail, postage prepaid, within thirty (30) days after the Illinois
Secretary of State notifies the Village of the identity of the registered owner of the vehicle or the lessor notifies the Village of the identity of the lessee of
the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90) days after the violation. If any notice to an address is returned as undeliverable, a second notice shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 214/618
be sent to the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office database of the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle. The second notice shall
be made by first class mail, postage prepaid. Prior to service of a Notice of Violation, the associated recorded image shall be first reviewed by a
technician(s) employed or contracted by the Village. A final review shall be conducted by a Village of Glendale Heights police officer or retired Village of
Glendale Heights police officer employed by the Village, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the motor vehicle was operated in
violation of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or similar violation of subsection 7-5-2C of this title, and whether one of the defenses enumerated
hereinafter is visibly apparent upon inspection of the recorded image(s). Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation of one of the
foregoing provisions and that no defense, as set forth in subsections 7-3E-6A1 through A5 of this article, applies, the notice of violation shall be served
upon the registered vehicle owner or lessee in the manner herein provided. The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall retain a copy of all contested
violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the owner or lessee of the vehicle. Each notice of violation shall constitute
