evidence of the facts contained in the notice and shall be admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation under this article and shall establish prima
facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal including rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in section 7-3E-6 of this article. Each notice
of violation shall include the following:
1. The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the Illinois Secretary of State or the lessor, or,
if such information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office approved database;
2. The make, (only if discernable) and the registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation;
3. The violation charged;
4. The location where the violation occurred;
5. The date and time of the violation;
6. A copy of the recorded images;
7. The amount of the civil penalty/fine imposed under section 7-3E-18 of this article and the date by which the civil penalty/fine should be paid (14 days
from the date of issuance) if liability for the violation is not contested and a statement that payment of the fine shall operate as a final disposition of
the violation;
8. A statement that failure to pay the civil penalty/fine or contest liability by the date stated may result in a final determination of liability and a
suspension of driving privileges of the registered owner of the vehicle or of the lessee of the vehicle for failure to pay five (5) or more final
determinations of liability to the Village;
9. A statement that the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle may elect to proceed by: a) paying the fine stated in the notice of violation; or by b)
challenging the charge in court, by mail or at an administrative hearing;
10. A statement that the recorded images constitute prima facie evidence of a violation;
11. A statement of law, an administrative hearing or court hearing may be requested;
12. The signature or identification number, electronic or otherwise, of the technician(s) and/or police officer or retired police officer of the Village
reviewing the recorded images and confirming that a violation took place; and
13. A website address, accessible through the internet, where the person may view the recorded images of the violation. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-6: DEFENSES:
A. A court or Hearing Officer may consider the following in defense of a violation of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title:
1. The motor vehicle and/or registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the exclusive control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the red light signal violation, which defense may be demonstrated through the submission of a certified copy
of a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates filed with a law enforcement agency prior to the time of the alleged violation;
2. The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection in spite of a red light either to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle, or as part of a
funeral procession;
3. The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection in spite of a red light at the direction of a police officer acting within the scope of his/her
duties;
4. The operator of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer for violating section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection
7-5-2C of this title;
5. The license plate number or other source of identification on the vehicle cannot be determined;
6. The vehicle was leased to another and within sixty (60) calendar days after the citation was mailed to the lessor, lessor submitted to the Municipality
the correct name and address of the lessee of the vehicle identified in this notice of violation at the time of the alleged violation, together with a copy
of the lease agreement, the lessee's driver's license number and any additional information that may be needed;
7. Other affirmative matter asserted that defeats the legal effect of the claim as determined by the Hearing Officer. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-7: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of section 7-3E-5 of this article notwithstanding, no notice of violation shall be issued to the owner or lessee of a motor vehicle in those
instances where a motor vehicle comes to a complete stop, as defined by section 1-199 of the Vehicle Code prior to entering the intersection, as defined
by section 1-132 of the Vehicle Code, during the cycle of the red signal indication, even if the motor vehicle stops at a point past the stop line or crosswalk
where a driver is required to stop, as specified in subsection (c) of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title, unless one or more
pedestrians or bicyclists are present. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 215/618
7-3E-8: HEARING:
The owner or lessee of a vehicle being operated in violation of section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title may request a hearing
no later than the respond-by date on the Notice of Violation, (14 days from the date of issuance), to challenge the evidence or set forth an applicable
defense. The Notice of Violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice, and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of
section 11-306 of the Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title.
The owner's or lessee's failure to appear at the hearing or timely contest the violation by mail shall result in a finding of liability. In the event of a failure to
appear, a "Findings, Decision and Order Notice" will be sent to the vehicle owner or lessee. The owner's or lessee's failure to pay the fine amount by the
date specified in that notice will result in a final determination of liability. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-9: FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY:
A final determination of automated traffic law violation(s) liability shall occur:
A. Following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty twenty five (25) days after the Hearing Officer's or court's determination of automated
traffic law violation liability, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, any administrative review procedures as provided by this Code, the Illinois
Administrative Review Law or all other applicable law; or
B. Where a person fails to appear at a prior requested hearing to contest the violation on the date and at the time and place specified in a prior served or
mailed notice, or fails to contest the violation by mail in a timely manner. The Hearing Officer's determination of liability for automatic traffic law violation
shall become final upon the exhaustion of or failure to exhaust, any judicial review procedures as provided by this Code or other applicable law. (Ord.
2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-10: NOTICE OF DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY:
A determination of automated traffic law violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine or penalty, or to contest the alleged violation within
fourteen (14) days of the Notice of Violation. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified
in a prior mailed notice, the Hearing Officer or court shall enter findings, decision and orders of a determination of automated traffic law violation liability,
which shall become final: a) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination or b) upon expiration of the period for filing a petition to set
aside a determination of liability without having filed such petition. If a person appears at a hearing and is found liable, or contests the violation by mail and
is found liable, the Hearing Officer or court, as the case may be, shall enter a findings, decision and order, which is a final determination of automated
traffic law violation liability which is a final, appealable order. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-11: NOTICE OF FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY:
A notice of final determination of liability shall be sent following the final determination of liability and after the conclusion of the period for judicial review.
The notice of final determination of liability shall include the following information:
A. A statement that the unpaid fine is a debt due and owing to the Village of Glendale Heights; and
B. A warning that a failure to pay any fine due and owing to the Village of Glendale Heights within fourteen (14) days may result in a petition to the Circuit
Court of the 18th Judicial Circuit to have the unpaid fine rendered as a judgment, or may result in the suspension of the person's driver's license for
failure to pay fines or penalties for five (5) or more final determinations of liability for violations under this article. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-12: CONTEST BY MAIL:
The registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle may contest the merits of the alleged violation by mail. Such person may contest the charges using the
same available defenses set forth in section 7-3E-6 of this article, but rather than attend the administrative or court hearing, the registered owner or lessee
may submit any and all documentary evidence to the Traffic Compliance Administrator or other duly appointed official no later than the scheduled reply
date, together with a written statement setting forth with specific reason(s) as to why the owner or lessee of the vehicle believes that he/she is not liable for
the violation. The Traffic Compliance Administrator or other duly appointed official shall forward all timely-submitted materials to the Hearing Officer for
review and determination. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-13: PETITIONS TO SET ASIDE DETERMINATION:
A Petition to Set Aside a determination of automated traffic law violation liability must be filed with or mailed to the Traffic Compliance Administrator or
other designated official within fourteen (14) days of the date of mailing of the Notice of Determination of Liability. The grounds for such petition are limited
to:
A. The cited person was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date the violation notice was issued;
B. The cited person already paid the fine for the violation in question;
C. The driver of the vehicle was issued a uniform traffic citation by a Village police officer; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 216/618
D. Excusable failure to appear at a hearing, contest by mail, or request a new date for a hearing.
Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside the determination of liability, the Traffic Compliance Administrator or other designated official shall immediately
forward the petition to the Hearing Officer who shall review the petition to determine if cause has been shown to set aside the determination. If cause has
been shown, the Village shall forward the petitioner a new hearing date on which the petitioner must appear to present his case or contest the violation by
mail in a timely manner. The Village shall notify the petitioner of the Hearing Officer's decision to grant a hearing or deny the petition within fourteen (14)
days of the Hearing Officer's decision to grant or deny the petition. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-14: NOTICE OF IMPENDING DRIVER'S LICENSE SUSPENSION:
A. A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to any person or entity found liable for violations, and for which the fines or penalties
remain due and owing on five (5) or more final determinations of liability for violations of this article. The notice of impending driver's license suspension
shall state the following information:
1. The failure to pay the fine due and owing within forty five (45) days of the notice's date will result in the Village of Glendale Heights notifying the
Secretary of State of the State of Illinois that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under section 6-306.5 of the Vehicle Code;
and
2. A statement that the person may obtain a copy of the original Notices of Violation imposing fine(s) by sending a self-addressed, stamped return
envelope to the Village, attention Traffic Compliance Administrator, along with a request for a copy of the Notice of Violation imposing the fine(s).
The Notice of Impending Driver's License Suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the Illinois
Secretary of State or, if any notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office
approved database. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-15: DRIVER'S LICENSE SUSPENSION:
A. The Traffic Compliance Administrator or other duly appointed official, by certified report, shall request that the Illinois Secretary of State suspend the
driving privileges of an owner of a registered vehicle who has failed to pay fines or penalties due and owing as a result of five (5) final determinations of
liability. The report shall be certified and contain the following:
1. The name, last known address of the owner of the vehicle as recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State, or as provided by the lessor of the cited
vehicle at the time of lease, or as recorded in a United States Post Office approved database if any notice sent under this article is returned as
undeliverable, and driver's license number of the person who failed to pay the fine(s) or penalty(ies), and the registration number of any vehicle
known to be registered to such person in another state;
2. The name of the Village of Glendale Heights as making the report; and
3. A statement that a Notice of Impending Driver's License Suspension has been sent to the person named in the report at the address recorded with
the Office of the Illinois Secretary of State, or at the last address known to the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of the lease, or, if any notice sent
under this article is returned as undeliverable, at the last known address recorded at a United States Post Office approved database, the date on
which such notice was sent and address to which such notice was sent.
The Traffic Compliance Administrator shall notify the Illinois Secretary of State whenever a person named in the certified report has paid the
previously recorded fines or penalties or whenever the Village determines that the original report was in error. A certified copy of such notification
shall also be given, upon request, and at no additional charge to the person named therein.
Any person receiving notice from the Secretary of State that their driving privileges may be suspended at the end of a specified period may challenge
the accuracy of the certified report prepared by the Traffic Compliance Administrator. The person shall, within seven (7) days after having received
notice from the Secretary of State, request an opportunity to speak with the Traffic Compliance Administrator to challenge the accuracy of the
certified report. If the Traffic Compliance Administrator determines that the original report was in error due to the fact that the person challenging the
report was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle or that the person has already paid their fine for the five (5) or more automated traffic violations, the
Traffic Compliance Administrator shall immediately notify the Secretary of State of such error in a subsequent certified report. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-
2018)
7-3E-16: EXCLUSIVITY:
Notwithstanding any provision of this Code to the contrary, and unless a moving violation citation is issued, the provisions of this article shall be the
exclusive method of notice, citation, processing, adjudication and final disposition and review of automated traffic enforcement of violations of section 11-
306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or subsection 7-5-2C of this title. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-17: CONFIDENTIALITY:
Recorded images made by the automatic traffic enforcement system shall be confidential and shall be made available only to the alleged violator and
his/her attorney, governmental agencies, technicians employed or contracted by the Village for purposes of reviewing the recorded images, and the Village
of Glendale Heights Police Department and its personnel for purposes of adjudicating violations, statistical or other governmental purposes. (Ord. 2018-
106, 12-13-2018)
7-3E-18: PENALTY:
The owner (or lessee) of a motor vehicle is subject to a penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per automated traffic law violation. In the event that such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 217/618
penalty is not paid within fourteen (14) days after service of a final determination of liability, an additional one hundred dollar ($100.00) late payment
penalty shall be imposed. A penalty shall not apply if the driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer at the time of the
violation. The Village may not charge court costs or hearing fees to persons found liable after exercising their right to appear and contest the violation at an
administrative hearing. (Ord. 2018-106, 12-13-2018)
Chapter 4
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
7-4-1: APPLICATION TO BICYCLES AND ANIMALS:
Every person riding a bicycle or an animal, or driving any animal drawing a vehicle upon a roadway, shall be subject to the provisions of this title applicable
to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions of this title which by their nature can have no application. (1978 Code § 11-1-4)
7-4-2: EMERGENCY STREET CLOSURES:
In the event of a vehicular accident; fallen trees, light standards or power lines; snow, flooding, ice or mud slide; pavement damage due to explosion,
buckling or other means; sudden obstruction in a traffic lane; or of any other emergency situation rendering a street hazardous and unsafe for public travel,
the chief of police, or the ranking officer of the police department acting in his stead, is hereby authorized to close any street or streets so affected to traffic
and to reroute or to direct traffic away from such street or streets for such period of time as is necessary to correct the emergency situation. (1978 Code
§ 11-1-2)
7-4-3: ACCIDENTS:
The driver of a vehicle which has collided with or been in an accident with any vehicle, person or property in such a manner as to cause injury or damage
shall stop immediately and render such assistance as may be possible, and give his true name and residence to the injured person or any other person
requesting the same on behalf of the injured person, or the owner of the property damaged and to a police officer, if one is present. A report of each such
accident shall be given by the driver of each vehicle concerned in the accident to the chief of police within twenty four (24) hours after the accident. (1978
Code § 11-1-10)
7-4-4: VEHICLE NOISE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon any public street, alley or highway in the village in such a manner as to cause or
produce unnecessary loud, raucous, excessive or unusual noise by the racing of the motor, by lack of a muffler or use of a muffler bypass or cutout, by tire
friction upon rapid turning or weaving, by spinning of the wheels from standing or slow moving position produced by sudden unnecessary motor
acceleration, or by continuous unnecessary sounding of a horn or other signal device. (1978 Code § 11-6-3)
7-4-5: VEHICLE WEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
A. Weight Limit Established; Exceptions: No vehicle or combination of vehicles shall be operated, with or without a load, upon any public street or highway
under the exclusive control of the village if the gross weight thereon exceeds ten thousand (10,000) pounds except for vehicles making deliveries of
materials or products to local residences, hospitals or governmental buildings.
B. Prima Facie Evidence: If a vehicle displays a registration above a class D license plate, it shall constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle is in
violation of the limitations of this section. (Ord. 2005-61, 10-6-2005)
C. Signs Posted: The director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to cause the posting of signs at the entrances to and upon such public
streets and highways so as to give reasonable notice of the provisions of this section. (Ord. 2005-61, 10-6-2005; amd. 2011 Code; Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-
2014)
D. Penalties: Any driver of a vehicle operated in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a
first offense, nor less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second and subsequent offense, but not more than a maximum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for any offense, if found to be guilty of the offense. (Ord. 2005-61, 10-6-2005; amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 5
TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS AND SIGNALS
7-5-1: SPECIFICATIONS:
All signs and signals established by direction of the governing body shall conform to the Illinois state manual and specifications. (1978 Code § 11-3-5;
amd. 2011 Code)
7-5-2: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL LEGEND:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 218/618
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time, or with lighted green arrows, only the
following colors shall be used, and such terms and lights and lighted green arrows shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as
follows:
A. Circular Green (Alone):
1. Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. Vehicular
traffic shall yield the right of way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection at the time such signal is exhibited.
2. Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk, unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian
signal.
B. Steady Yellow:
1. Vehicular traffic facing a steady yellow signal is thereby warned that the related green movement is being terminated or that a red indication will be
exhibited immediately thereafter when vehicular traffic may not enter the intersection.
2. Pedestrians facing a steady yellow signal, unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal, are thereby advised that there is insufficient time
to cross the roadway, and no pedestrian shall start to cross.
C. Steady Red Indication:
1. Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal alone must stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side
of an intersection, or if none, then before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown, except as
provided in subsections C2 and E1 of this section.
2. When a sign is in place permitting a turn, vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to make the turn indicated
by such sign after stopping as required by subsection C1 of this section. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right of way to pedestrians lawfully
within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection.
3. No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he can do so safely without interfering with any vehicular traffic or unless a separate
"walk" indication is shown.
D. Green Straight Through Arrow (Alone):
1. Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through, but shall not turn right or left. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right of way to
other vehicles and to pedestrians legally within the intersection at the time such signal is exhibited.
2. Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within the appropriate marked or unmarked crosswalk, unless otherwise directed by
a pedestrian signal.
E. Green Turn Arrow (With Circular Green, With Steady Yellow, With Steady Red Or With Green Straight Through Arrow):
1. Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall comply with the meaning of the circular green, steady yellow, steady red or green straight through arrow
indication as if it were shown alone; except, that such vehicular traffic may cautiously enter the intersection to make the movement indicated by the
green turn arrow. Vehicular traffic shall yield the right of way to pedestrians lawfully within the crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the
intersection.
2. Pedestrians facing such signal shall comply with the meaning of the circular green, steady yellow, steady red or straight through arrow indication as if
it were shown alone, unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian signal. (1978 Code § 11-3-1)
7-5-3: SIGNAL NOT AT INTERSECTION:
In the event an official traffic control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of section 7-5-2 of this chapter
shall be applicable except as to provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be at a traffic sign or a marking on the
pavement indicating where the stop shall be made or, in the absence of such sign or marking, the stop shall be made at the signal. (1978 Code § 11-3-1;
amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 6
DRIVING RULES
7-6-1: SPEED LIMITS:
A. Generally: Except as otherwise provided herein, the speed limit on all streets under village jurisdiction shall be posted and set at twenty five (25) miles
per hour. (Ord. 97-03, 1-2-1997; amd. 2011 Code)
B. School Zones:
1. Speed Limit: No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour while passing a school zone or while traveling
upon any public thoroughfare on or across which children pass to and from school during school days when schoolchildren are present.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 219/618
2. Signs Posted: This subsection shall not be applicable unless appropriate signs are posted to indicate the restriction. Such signs shall give proper
due warning that a school zone is being approached and shall indicate the school zone and the maximum speed limit in effect during school days
when schoolchildren are present. (1978 Code § 11-2-6; amd. 2011 Code)
C. Use Of Speed Detecting Devices By Police; Restrictions: The village police department is hereby authorized to use radar or other speed detecting
devices on any street within the village upon which maximum speed limit signs are posted, but not within five hundred feet (500') beyond any such sign
in the direction of travel. If used in violation of this subsection, evidence obtained thereby shall be inadmissible in any prosecution for speeding.
D. Violation: No person may drive a vehicle upon any highway or street within the village at a speed limit which is greater than the applicable posted
maximum speed limit, as established by this code or statute. (1978 Code § 11-2-6)
7-6-2: MISCELLANEOUS DRIVING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Emerging From Building, Private Road Or Driveway: The driver of a vehicle emerging from a building, private road or driveway within an urban area
shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving into the sidewalk area extending across such building entrance, road or driveway, or in the event
there is no sidewalk area, shall stop at the point nearest the street to be entered where the driver has a view of approaching traffic thereon, and shall
yield the right of way to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right of way to all
vehicles approaching on the roadway. (1978 Code § 11-2-17; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Pedestrian Right Of Way On Sidewalks: The driver of a vehicle emerging from or entering an alley, building, private road or driveway shall yield the right
of way to any pedestrian approaching on any sidewalk or any sidewalk area extending across such alley, building entrance, road or driveway. (1978
Code § 11-2-18)
C. Entering, Leaving Restricted Access Roadways: No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from any controlled or limited access roadway except at such
entrances and exits as are established by public authority. (1978 Code § 11-2-33)
7-6-3: CRUISING:
A. Definitions: The following words or phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
CRUISING OR TO CRUISE: To operate a motor vehicle, or as a custodian or owner of a motor vehicle, to permit its operation, past a point in a
prohibited cruising area more than four (4) times in any direction during a two (2) hour period between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and three
o'clock (3:00) A.M.
PROHIBITED CRUISING AREA: Any village park, as defined in section 8-4-1 of this code, and the immediate area surrounding said park(s) that is so
designated by clearly marked and permanently fixed signs advising the public that the area is subject to the regulation prohibiting cruising.
B. Cruising Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle for the purpose of cruising or for any custodian or owner of a motor
vehicle to permit or allow any person to operate said vehicle for the purpose of cruising in a "prohibited cruising area" as defined in subsection A of this
section.
C. Exemptions: This section shall not apply to any municipal, emergency, police, fire, ambulance, or other governmental vehicle when same is being
operated in an official capacity, nor shall this section apply to any duly licensed public transportation vehicle or any vehicle utilized for business and/or
commercial purposes while in the course of that business or commercial purpose. (Ord. 2002-42, 6-20-2002)
7-6-4: TOY VEHICLES:
A. Use Of Roadways Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person upon any coaster, sled, skates or other toy vehicle to go upon any roadway other than
at a crosswalk. (1978 Code § 11-1-7)
B. Motorized Skateboards And Motorized Scooters:
1. Definitions: For purposes of this subsection, the following words and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them as follows:
MOTORIZED SKATEBOARD OR MOTORIZED SCOOTER: Any wheeled, seated or seatless device, unregistered by the Illinois secretary of state,
consisting of a board or other horizontal platform surface or some form of framework whereby the wheels are operated or propelled, in whole or in
part, by some form of attached gasoline powered motor or engine of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeter displacement or designed to obtain a
maximum speed of less than thirty (30) miles per hour and primarily designed to hold or carry one or more persons, excluding: a) motorized Segways
or similar devices used by the village or any other governmental agency in the performance of its business, affairs, or duties; and b) those motorized
devices designed or manufactured primarily for the transport of disabled persons.
PARKING LOT: Any public or quasi-public area primarily used for the parking or temporary storage of motor vehicles including, but not limited to,
shopping centers, public parks, apartment or housing complexes, and municipally maintained parking areas.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb line or lateral lines of any street or roadway, and adjacent to property lines, intended for use of
pedestrians, or any similar walkway located in any public park, shopping center, school, multi-family housing or apartment complex, including hiking
paths and nature trails.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 220/618
STREET: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel, including alleys, bicycle paths, and service roads.
2. Prohibited Operation: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorized scooter or motorized skateboard, as defined in subsection B1 of
this section, upon any street, public or quasi-public parking lot, sidewalk, or public park within the village.
3. Exemptions: The prohibition of this subsection shall not apply to the use of motorized scooters or motorized skateboards when such use is approved
as part of any village sponsored or approved parade or similar event. (Ord. 2004-48, 6-17-2004)
4. Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this subsection shall be fined as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 2004-
48, 6-17-2004; amd. 2011 Code)
7-6-5: RIDING OUTSIDE OF, CLINGING TO VEHICLES:
A. Riding Outside Vehicle: It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, running boards or outside step of any vehicle. (1978 Code § 11-1-9)
B. Clinging To Vehicles: Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, motor driven cycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall not attach
the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. (1978 Code §§ 11-1-9, 11-8-1)
Chapter 7
PARKING REGULATIONS
7-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle of the second division, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-146, used for the transportation of
persons or property in the furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for hire or not for hire, having a gross weight, as evidenced by the weight
and use classification code contained on the license plate, in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds, having a maximum length in excess of two
hundred sixty four inches (264"), and having a maximum height and width in excess of ninety six inches (96") (exclusive of mirrors); construction
equipment; and permanently mounted equipment trailers, not including however, a commuter van, a vehicle used in a ridesharing arrangement or a
recreational vehicle not being used commercially.
TYPE II COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle of the second division, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-146, used for the
transportation of persons or property in the furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for hire or not for hire, having a gross weight, as
evidenced by the weight and use classification code contained on the license plate, not in excess of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds, having a maximum
length not in excess of two hundred sixty four inches (264"), and having a maximum height and width not in excess of ninety six inches (96") (exclusive of
mirrors); construction equipment; and permanently mounted equipment trailers, not including however, a commuter van, a vehicle used in a ridesharing
arrangement or a recreational vehicle not being used commercially.
TYPE II SCHOOL BUS: A school bus with a gross vehicle weight rating of ten thousand (10,000) pounds or less as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-213.5. (Ord. 2001-04, 1-4-2001)
7-7-2: MANNER OF PARKING:
A. Except as otherwise provided in this section and except for those streets that have been marked for angle parking, every vehicle stopped or parked
upon a two-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand wheels parallel to and within twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb or as
close as practicable to the right edge of the right hand shoulder. On those streets marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the
curb indicated by such marks.
B. Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of
authorized traffic movement, with its right hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of
the right hand shoulder, or with its left hand wheels within twelve inches (12") of the left hand curb or as close as practicable to the left edge of the left
hand shoulder. (1978 Code § 11-4-6; amd. 2011 Code)
C. No vehicle shall be parked on any lines or markings designating parking spaces or in such a position so that the vehicle is not entirely within the area
designated by lines or markings. (1978 Code § 11-4-6)
7-7-3: UNATTENDED VEHICLE:
No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key
from the ignition, effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any perceptible grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the
street. (1978 Code § 11-4-7; amd. 2011 Code)
7-7-4: STARTING PARKED VEHICLE:
No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. (1978 Code
§ 11-4-8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 221/618
7-7-5: PARKING PROHIBITED AT SPECIFIC PLACES:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or to comply with the directions of a police officer or official traffic sign or signal:
A. Within an intersection.
B. On a crosswalk.
C. Upon any bridge or viaduct or in any subways and the approaches thereto.
D. Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of the safety zone.
E. Within thirty feet (30') of an official traffic signal or stop sign on the approaching side.
F. Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk.
G. At any curb within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant; said distance to be measured from that point on the curb perpendicular to the exact location of the
fire hydrant. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006)
H. At any place within twenty feet (20') of the entrance to any fire station, and on the side of any street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within
seventy five feet (75') of said entrance, when properly signposted. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
I. At any place where the standing of any vehicle will block the use of any public or private driveway.
J. Within any sidewalk area; however, residents may park across the sidewalk on their respective driveways between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., or within twenty four (24) hours after a snowfall of one inch (1") or more between November 1 and March 31.
K. Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
L. On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street.
M. At any place where official traffic signs have been erected prohibiting stopping, standing or parking.
N. Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.
O. Within any designated bus zone, where such zone is marked by signs or pavement markings.
P. In any alley within twenty feet (20') of the inner sidewalk line projected across such alley, or in such position as to block a driveway or entrance to any
abutting property, or such position as to leave less than ten feet (10') of alleyway width available for free movement of vehicular traffic, or for any period
of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle.
Q. Under the lowest portion of any fire escape. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006)
R. Upon a railroad track or between any railroad track and a line parallel with and fifty feet (50') distant from the outer rail thereof. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006;
amd. 2011 Code)
S. Upon any park or parkway, except in the case of emergency. However, vehicles parked upon a driveway perpendicular to the street between the curb
and the property line, without parking on or above the sidewalk, shall be permitted. Furthermore, vehicles parked upon a driveway parallel to the street
between the curb and the property line, without parking on or above the sidewalk, shall be permitted only on the designated street maintenance day for
the address where the vehicle is parked. (Ord. 2018-76, 11-29-2018)
T. Within twenty five feet (25') of any highway divider or roadway median strip. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006)
U. Within any properly designated fire lane or bus stop area. (Ord. 2006-34, 6-1-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
7-7-6: COMMERCIAL VEHICLE PARKING:
A. It shall be unlawful to park any commercial vehicle or vehicle for hire on or upon any street, alley or public way within the corporate limits of the Village,
except a commercial vehicle or vehicle for hire may park on such streets for the purpose of:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 222/618
1. Making an immediate delivery or pick up for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) minutes;
2. Loading or unloading passengers of vehicles for hire for a period of time not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes;
3. Waiting for a passenger of a vehicle for hire for a period of time not to exceed five (5) minutes, when instructed by the passenger to do so;
4. Residential construction and repair and landscaping, while such vehicles are needed for use in conducting the work, during the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M.; or
5. Loading or unloading of a person's household belongings when such person is in the process of moving his residence from one location to another,
between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight only. (Ord. 2007-84, 9-20-2007)
B. It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle of the second division, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-146, in a Commercial District, unless the
property has designated parking spaces for such vehicles pursuant to an approved site plan. This subsection shall not apply to second division vehicles
parked on property wherein the sale of such vehicles is lawfully conducted, or when these vehicles are in the process of loading or unloading.
C. Nothing in this section is intended to permit any type II commercial vehicle to operate upon any public street or way in the Village with an actual gross
weight in violation of the size and weight limitations as set forth in section 7-4-5 of this title. (Ord. 2001-04, 1-4-2001)
7-7-7: ON STREET PARKING OF RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND TRAILERS:
Parking of all nonmotorized recreational vehicles, trailers, boats (whether on a trailer or otherwise), any camper not mounted on a vehicle, and any motor
home or mini-motor home of any length on any public way within the Village is prohibited. However, a motor home or trailer attached to a tow vehicle may
be parked in an otherwise legal manner on the public way for a period not to exceed forty eight (48) hours for the purpose of loading or unloading. (Ord.
2007-69, 6-21-2007)
7-7-8: PARKING DURING SNOWFALL:
A. Prohibitions:
1. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street designated as a snow route in the Village at any time within twenty four (24) hours after a
snowfall of one inch (1") or more has occurred.
2. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any other public street in the Village at any time within twenty four (24) hours after a snowfall of two inches
(2") or more has occurred.
3. In the event of a continuous heavy snowfall of five inches (5") or more having occurred, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street in
the Village at any time within a period of seventy two (72) hours after such snowfall unless the Village Administrator should, in the interim, declare
that parking may be earlier resumed on any named street or streets.
B. Impoundment Of Vehicle: The Chief of Police, or any member of the Police Department designated by the Chief of Police, is hereby authorized to
remove or have removed, at the owner's expense, any vehicle parked on any public street within the Village in violation of the provisions of this section;
provided, that before such removal action is undertaken, efforts shall be made to identify the vehicle owner and to notify such owner to voluntarily
remove his vehicle. (1978 Code § 11-4-3)
7-7-9: MISCELLANEOUS PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Private Residential Property:
1. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on private property which is zoned for residential uses except within a garage, upon a paved driveway or upon
a paved parking lot. (1978 Code § 11-4-2)
2. It shall be unlawful to park any commercial vehicle on private property which is zoned for residential uses except within a garage or except type II
school buses parked in driveways on school days between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. (Ord. 2001-05, 1-4-2001)
B. Property Used For Fire Prevention And Firefighting Purposes: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property used for fire
prevention or firefighting purposes when the property is properly posted to that effect. (1978 Code § 11-4-4)
C. Vehicles For Sale; Sale Of Merchandise:
1. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled.
2. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any commercial or industrial property for the purpose of displaying it for sale without the expressed
approval of the property owner or tenant. Commercial property specifically licensed for the sale of vehicles is exempt. (Ord. 98-72, 12-17-1998)
D. Parking On Certain Sides Of Streets Generally:
1. Where a fire hydrant or fire hydrants are located on a street, parking shall be restricted to the side of the street opposite to that wherein such fire
hydrant or hydrants are located.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 223/618
2. Where there are no fire hydrants located on a street running in a northerly and southerly direction, parking shall be restricted to the east side of the
street.
3. Where there are no fire hydrants located on a street running in an easterly and westerly direction, parking shall be restricted to the north side of the
street.
4. The parking restrictions provided in subsections D1, D2 and D3 of this section shall not apply to that portion of any public street which is a cul-de-sac
area. (Ord. 2005-48, 6-3-2005)
E. Overnight Parking: Parking of any vehicle on any public street within the Village, when parking on such street is otherwise permitted, shall be prohibited
from the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M., unless the vehicle displays a Village vehicle license pursuant to chapter 2 of this
title. (Ord. 2007-81, 9-4-2007)
7-7-10: UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PARKING PLACES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
A. Definition: As used in this section, "authorized holder" means an individual issued a disability license plate under section 3-616 of the Vehicle Code, an
individual issued a parking decal or device under section 11-1301.2 of the Vehicle Code, or an individual issued a disabled veteran license plate under
section 3-609 of the Vehicle Code. (Source: P.A. 94-619, effective 1-1-2006.) (Ord. 2006-12, 3-16-2006)
B. Unauthorized Use:
1. It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not properly displaying registration plates, decals, or devices issued pursuant to provisions of
the Illinois Vehicle Code ("Vehicle Code") to persons with disabilities or to disabled veterans in any parking place, including any private or public off
street parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of an official sign as designated under section 11-301.1 of the Vehicle Code, for motor
vehicles displaying such registration plates, decals, or devices. It shall be further unlawful to park any motor vehicle in a designated access aisle
adjacent to any parking place specifically reserved for persons with disabilities.
2. An official parking decal or device must be displayed either by hanging the decal or device from the rearview mirror or by placing it on the dashboard
of the vehicle in clear view. Any motor vehicle properly displaying a disability license plate or a parking decal or device containing the international
symbol of access issued to persons with disabilities by any local authority, state, district, territory or foreign country shall be recognized by the village
as valid, and that vehicle shall receive the same parking privileges as residents of the village. (Ord. 2006-12, 3-16-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
3. An individual with a vehicle displaying disability license plates or a parking decal or device issued to qualified persons with disabilities or to disabled
veterans shall be in further violation of this section if:
a. The person using the disability license plate or parking decal or device is not the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or
device or is not transporting the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device to or from the reserved parking location;
and
b. The person uses the disability license plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges granted to the person with disabilities.
C. Removal Of Vehicle: Any person or local authority owning or operating any public or private off street parking facility may, after notifying the village
police department, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved
for use by a person with a disability which does not display disability registration plates or a special decal or device as required under this section. (Ord.
2006-12, 3-16-2006)
D. Prohibited Defense: Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, it shall not be a defense to a charge under this section that either the sign posted
pursuant to this section or the intended accessible parking place does not comply with the technical requirements of section 11-301.1 of the vehicle
code, department regulations, or this section, if a reasonable person would be made aware by the sign or notice on or near the parking place that the
place is reserved for persons with disabilities. (Ord. 2006-12, 3-16-2006; amd. 2011 Code)
E. Penalties: Any person found liable or guilty of violating the provisions of subsection B1 of this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for each offense in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or
storage of any such motor vehicle removed and stored pursuant to this section. Any person found liable or guilty of violating the provisions of
subsection B3 of this section shall be fined not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2011-70, 9-1-2011)
7-7-11: UNAUTHORIZED MOVING OF PARKED VEHICLE:
No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any prohibited area or away from the curb such a distance as is unlawful. (1978 Code
§ 11-4-2; amd. 2011 Code)
7-7-12: SIGNS POSTED:
Where a provision of this title or a provision of the Illinois vehicle code requires signs to be posted limiting or prohibiting parking, the chief of police shall
cause signs to be posted indicating such limitation or prohibition in those areas. (1978 Code § 11-4-1)
7-7-13: SETTLEMENT AND COMPROMISE OF PARKING VIOLATIONS:
A. Citation:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 224/618
1. Any person accused of violating any provision of this chapter relating to or restricting the place or length of time for vehicle parking, and other similar
parking regulations, may be issued a citation without the filing of a complaint in court against him for such violation, which citation may be affixed to a
motor vehicle owned or operated by him or owned by him and operated with his consent. (1978 Code § 11-4-10)
2. Said citation shall be in a form suitable for mailing, shall state the specific section of this chapter or chapter 8 of this title that was violated and shall
inform the alleged violator that he may avoid the filing of a complaint in court charging him with such violation upon payment of an amount hereinafter
prescribed in full settlement of his liability for such violation. (1978 Code § 11-4-10; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Payment Of Fine; Amounts:
1. Payment shall be due on or before the date set forth in the citation and, in any event, not more than thirty (30) days from the date the violation was
committed. Such payment shall be made at either the village hall or the village police department during normal business hours, either in person or
by mail with the envelope portion of the citation. A receipt shall be issued for all monies so paid, and the amount paid shall be forwarded to the
village treasurer for deposit in the proper fund. (1978 Code § 11-4-10)
2. Liability of any person for any violation specified in a citation pursuant to provisions of this section may be settled without court action upon payment
by the violator of the sum of thirty five dollars ($35.00) for such violation on or before the due date set forth in the citation; except that liability for a
violation specified in a citation issued pursuant to the provisions of section 7-7-10, "Unauthorized Use Of Parking Places For Persons With
Disabilities", of this chapter may be settled without court action upon the payment by the violator of the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for
such violation on or before the date set forth in the citation. (Ord. 2011-70, 9-1-2011)
C. Failure To Pay; Notice To Appear: In the event that no payment is received during the period set forth in the citation or in a subsequent final notice (if
one is issued), then the issuing police officer shall cause a notice to appear to be served upon the alleged violator and shall file and prosecute a
complaint for the violation in the county circuit court, or unpaid citations shall be enforced pursuant to administrative adjudications established in
chapter 3, article A of this title. (Ord. 2007-24, 3-8-2007)
D. Payment During Additional Period; Amounts: Where payment is made during the additional period set forth in a final notice, the amount to be paid shall
be fifty dollars ($50.00) for such violation, except in the case of a violation issued pursuant to the provisions of section 7-7-10, "Unauthorized Use Of
Parking Places For Persons With Disabilities", of this chapter the amount to be paid shall be two hundred sixty five dollars ($265.00) for such violation.
E. Suit To Recover Fine: Where suit is brought to recover the fine due for violations of this chapter, the amount of the fine required to be paid shall be
determined by the court or administrative hearing officer, but shall not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for each offense, exclusive of costs, except where suit is brought to recover the fine due for a violation of section 7-7-10, "Unauthorized Use Of Parking
Places For Persons With Disabilities", of this chapter the amount of the fine required to be paid shall be determined by the court or administrative
hearing officer, but shall not be less than two hundred sixty five dollars ($265.00), exclusive of costs. (Ord. 2011-70, 9-1-2011)
F. Prima Facie Evidence: The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally parked is registered with the secretary of state in the name of said
alleged violator, or in the alternative, the fact that a municipal vehicle sticker has been issued in the name of the alleged violator, shall be prima facie
evidence that such person was in control of or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at the time of such alleged violation. (1978 Code
§ 11-4-10)

Park only. (Ord. 2005-48, 6-30-2005)

2. Issuance Of Permit: The Village Police Department shall issue each resident of the streets referenced in subsection C1 of this section one parking
permit for each vehicle registered to that respective address, and in addition, guest parking permits will be issued to the residents of said streets
upon request.
3. Display Required: Any vehicle failing to display a parking permit clearly visible through the windshield of said vehicle is in violation of this subsection.
4. Violations: Any vehicle parked in violation of the provisions of subsection C1 of this section is an unlawful vehicle as stated in section 7-3C-1,
definition of "unlawful vehicle", subsection B, of this title, and said vehicle shall be ticketed and is subject to immediate towing without notice pursuant
to section 7-3C-2 of this title.
5. Exemptions: This subsection shall not apply to construction or landscaping vehicles parked on said streets while such vehicles are needed to
perform work at residences located on said streets. (Ord. 2005-48, 6-30-2005)
D. Parking During Street Maintenance: Parking on Village streets shall be prohibited between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four o'clock (4:00)
P.M. in April, May, October, and November for street maintenance based upon the following schedule: (Ord. 2011-66, 9-1-2011)
1. Mondays: All Village streets north of the Canadian National Railway line to the northern boundaries of the Village.
2. Tuesdays: All Village streets west of Bloomingdale Road to the western boundaries of the Village and north of Fullerton Avenue to the Canadian
National Railway line, and on all Village streets west of President Street to the western boundaries of the Village and from Golfview Drive north to
Fullerton Avenue.
3. Wednesdays: All Village streets east of Bloomingdale Road to the eastern boundaries of the Village and from the Canadian National Railway line
south to North Avenue.
4. Fridays: All Village streets south of North Avenue to the southern boundaries of the Village, all Village streets west of Bloomingdale Road to
President Street and from Armitage Avenue north to Fullerton Avenue, and all Village streets west of President Street to Schmale Road and West
Lake Drive south to North Avenue. (Ord. 2010-46, 6-17-2010)

7-8-6: PROHIBITED TURNS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 238/618
A. Prohibited Turns During School Hours:
1. Left Turns: The following are prohibited left turns on school days during school hours:
a. Motor vehicles traveling westbound on Stevenson Drive to turn left from westbound Stevenson Drive into any driveway of 43 East Stevenson Drive
(Pheasant Ridge School).
b. Motor vehicles to exit either driveway of 43 East Stevenson Drive (Pheasant Ridge School) by turning left onto westbound Stevenson Drive.
c. Turning left from southbound Gladstone Drive into the south driveway of Blackhawk School.
2. Right Turns: It shall be unlawful on school days during school hours for the operator of any motor vehicle to turn right from the north driveway of
Blackhawk School onto northbound Gladstone Drive. (Ord. 2006-24, 5-4-2006)
B. Right Turn On Red Prohibited: Right turns against a steady red signal are prohibited at the following intersections:
Fullerton Avenue, eastbound, turning north onto Bloomingdale Road, daily, between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 10:00 P.M.
Fullerton Avenue, westbound, turning south onto Bloomingdale Road, daily, between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 10:00 P.M.
(1978 Code § 11-9-5; amd. 2011 Code)

Chapter 9
PEDESTRIANS
7-9-1: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE AND TRAFFIC SIGNALS:
At intersections when traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop and go signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway other than
with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1978 Code § 11-5-4)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 239/618
7-9-2: USE OF CROSSWALKS IN BUSINESS DISTRICTS:
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district. (1978 Code § 11-5-5; amd. 2011 Code)
7-9-3: STANDING ON ROADWAYS:
No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway, other than in a safety zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1978 Code § 11-5-3;
amd. 2011 Code)
Chapter 10
BICYCLES
7-10-1: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
Every bicycle owned or kept by a resident of the village shall register the same with the police department of the village upon forms supplied by the chief of
police. Each bicycle so registered will receive a registration tag which shall be permanently affixed to the frame of the bicycle. Such tag shall be
nontransferable and shall be retained upon the frame of the bicycle to which it is affixed until the same has been disposed of by gift, sale, junking or
permanent removal from the village. (1978 Code § 11-8-6)
7-10-2: TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY:
A. Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a
vehicle by the Illinois vehicle code and by the provisions of this title except as to those provisions of laws and ordinances which, by their nature, can
have no application. (1978 Code § 11-8-1; amd. 2011 Code)
B. The regulations of this title applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or public sidewalk or upon any public path
set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated herein. (1978 Code § 11-8-7)
7-10-3: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
A. Any person operating a bicycle shall comply with official traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles unless otherwise
directed by a police officer.
B. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left turn or a turn in the opposite direction is permitted, no person operating a bicycle
shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event, such person
shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. (1978 Code § 11-8-3)
7-10-4: OPERATION OF :
A. Speed: No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.
B. Emerging From Alley, Driveway Or Building: The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk
or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on said sidewalk or sidewalk area and, upon
entering the roadway, shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway. (1978 Code § 11-8-1)
C. Carrying Articles: No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the use of both hands on the handlebars at all
times.
D. Riding On Bicycles:
1. A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
2. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped; except, that an adult rider may
carry a child securely attached to his person in a backpack or sling. (1978 Code § 11-8-1; amd. 2011 Code)
E. Riding On Sidewalks:
1. No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district.
2. No person fifteen (15) or more years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in any district. (1978 Code § 11-8-2)
3. A person propelling a bicycle upon and along a sidewalk or across a roadway upon and along a crosswalk shall yield the right of way to any
pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 240/618
F. Riding On Streets And Bicycle Paths:
1. Any person operating a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle upon a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the
conditions then existing shall ride as close as practicable and safe to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway except under the following
situations:
a. When overtaking and passing another bicycle, motorized pedal cycle or vehicle proceeding in the same direction; or
b. When preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway; or
c. When reasonably necessary to avoid conditions including, but not limited to, fixed or moving objects, parked or moving vehicles, bicycles,
motorized pedal cycles, pedestrians, animals, surface hazards, or substandard width lanes that make it unsafe to continue along the right hand
curb or edge. For purposes of this subsection F1c, a "substandard width lane" means a lane that is too narrow for a bicycle or motorized pedal
cycle and a vehicle to travel safely side by side within the lane; or
d. When approaching a place where a right turn is authorized.
2. Any person operating a bicycle or motorized pedal cycle upon a one-way roadway with two (2) or more marked traffic lanes may ride as near the left
hand curb or edge of such roadway as practicable. (1978 Code § 11-8-2; amd. 2011 Code)
3. Bicycles shall not be operated upon any street where the operation of bicycles has been prohibited, and signs have been erected indicating such
prohibition.
4. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride other than single file except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of
bicycles.
5. Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and not use the roadway. (1978
Code § 11-8-2)
7-10-5: PARKING BICYCLES:
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against
a building or at the curb in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. (1978 Code § 11-8-4)
7-10-6: EQUIPMENT:
A. Lights And Reflectors: Every bicycle operated on any street, sidewalk, alley or roadway or any other public area within the limits of the village during the
period from sunset to sunrise or at any other time when visibility is so limited as to require the use of lights for safety shall be equipped on the front with
a lamp which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet (500') to the front and shall be equipped on the rear with a red
reflector of a type approved by the Illinois department of transportation which shall be visible from all distances from one hundred feet (100') to six
hundred feet (600') to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. (1978 Code § 11-8-5; amd. 2011 Code)
B. Sirens: A bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren; except, that this subsection shall not apply to a bicycle
that is a police vehicle or fire department vehicle. (1978 Code §§ 11-6-4, 11-8-5; amd. 2011 Code)
C. Brake: Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will adequately control movement of, and stop and hold, the bicycle. (1978 Code § 11-8-5;
amd. 2011 Code)
7-10-7: RESPONSIBILITY OF PARENT OR GUARDIAN:
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this
title applicable to bicycles. (1978 Code § 11-8-7)
Chapter 11
PARADES, PROCESSIONS AND MARCHES
7-11-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to participate in any manner in a parade, procession, or march on the public streets or sidewalks as described herein without first
having obtained a permit to do so as described in this chapter. (1978 Code § 11-10-2)
7-11-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
It is unlawful for any person, group of persons, or organization to conduct or participate in any parade, procession, or march, either pedestrian or vehicular,
or a combination thereof, in more than one specific area or location in the village or in conflict with any of the traffic laws, ordinances or regulations of the
village whereby normal vehicular or pedestrian traffic may be disrupted or impeded, except upon application in writing to the village clerk not less than
fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the parade, procession, or march. Each application shall contain the following information and be
accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) which may be waived by the village clerk upon request of the applicant for
good cause: (1978 Code § 11-10-1; amd. Ord. 2011-09, 4-7-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 241/618
A. The name, address and telephone number of the person, group of persons, or organization organizing such parade, procession, or march and
responsible for its conduct.
B. The time of inception and duration of the parade, procession, or march; starting point and termination point and the specific route to be traveled for the
parade, procession, or march.
C. The composition of the parade, procession, or march; the approximate number and the maximum number of persons, vehicles and animals expected to
participate in such parade, procession, or march, together with a description of the type of animals and vehicles involved. (1978 Code § 11-10-1)
7-11-3: REFERRAL OF APPLICATIONS; APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
A. Referrals: Upon receipt of such application above described, the village clerk shall refer to the chief of police any application which has a maximum
number of vehicles or animals expected to participate of twenty five (25) or less or a maximum number of persons expected to participate of one
hundred (100) or less; and the clerk shall refer to the president and board of trustees any application which has a maximum number of vehicles or
animals expected to participate of more than twenty five (25) or a maximum number of persons expected to participate of more than one hundred
(100).
B. Action On Applications Referred To Chief:
1. On all applications referred to the chief of police, the chief of police shall determine whether that parade, procession, or march will unreasonably
interfere with the rights of others to use the streets and sidewalks with respect to time, route, composition, or number of participants, and based upon
this determination, the chief of police shall direct the village clerk to issue or deny a permit for the conduct of that parade, procession, or march.
2. In the event that the chief of police shall direct the village clerk to deny such permit, the chief of police shall designate the area or areas wherein the
plan for the parade, procession, or march shall be appropriately adjusted, including the setting of a limitation on the number of persons allowed to
participate, with the provision that a new application setting forth such changes in the plan be delivered to the chief of police within five (5) days of his
direction to the village clerk to deny the permit.
3. In the event the person or group making application for a permit shall change the plan for the parade, procession, or march to conform to the
designation of the chief of police, and provided the new application is received by the chief of police within the time limits set forth hereinabove for
the submission of a changed plan, the chief of police shall direct the village clerk to issue a permit for that parade, procession, or march. (1978 Code
§ 11-10-1; amd. Ord. 2011-09, 4-7-2011)
C. Action On Applications Referred To Board Of Trustees:
1. On all applications referred to the board of trustees, the board of trustees shall determine whether that parade, procession, or march will
unreasonably interfere with the rights of others to use the streets and sidewalks with respect to time, route, composition, or number of participants,
and based upon this determination, the board of trustees shall direct the village clerk to issue or deny a permit for the conduct of that parade,
procession, or march. (1978 Code § 11-10-1)
2. In the event that the board of trustees shall direct the village clerk to deny a permit, the board of trustees shall designate the area or areas wherein
the plan for the parade, procession, or march shall be appropriately adjusted, including the setting of a limit on the number of persons allowed to
participate, with the provision that a new application setting forth such changes in the plan be delivered to the village board of trustees within five (5)
days of the board of trustees' direction to the village clerk to deny the permit.
3. In the event the person or group making application for a permit shall change the plan for the parade, procession, or march to conform to the
designation of the board of trustees, and provided the new application is received by the village board of trustees within the time limits set forth
hereinabove for the submission of a changed plan, the village board of trustees shall direct the village clerk to issue a permit for that parade,
procession, or march. (1978 Code § 11-10-1; amd. 2011 Code)
7-11-4: EVENTS REQUESTED FOR SAME DATE:
In the event the village clerk receives applications for more than one parade, procession, or march to be held on the same date, the chief of police may
route each of said parades, processions, or marches so that they will not conflict with each other, or the chief of police may deny one or more permits for
such parades, processions, or marches. The first applicant shall have priority over later applicants. (1978 Code § 11-10-1; amd. Ord. 2011-09, 4-7-2011)
7-11-5: PROHIBITED HOURS:
It shall be unlawful to participate in any manner in any parade, procession, or march between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. (1978 Code § 11-10-3)
7-11-6: EXEMPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to the following:
A. Funeral processions proceeding by vehicle under the most reasonable route from the funeral home, church, or residence of the deceased to the place
of interment.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 242/618
B. A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. (1978 Code § 11-10-1)
7-11-7: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined an amount not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2011-09, 4-7-2011; amd. 2011 Code)
Title 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
8-1-1: STREET OPENING DEPOSIT:
There shall be a deposit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) paid to the village before any street opening is made in the village. (1978 Code § 8-2-5;
amd. 2011 Code)
8-1-2: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
No sidewalk shall be constructed or replaced in the village without first obtaining a permit therefor. The fee for such permit shall be thirty dollars ($30.00).
(1978 Code § 8-2-3; amd. 2011 Code)
8-1-3: OBSTRUCTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way except as may be
specifically authorized by ordinance or by the director of public works. (1978 Code § 8-2-2; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
8-1-4: INJURY TO PAVEMENT PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to walk upon, drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure any newly laid street or alley pavement while the same is guarded by a warning
sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure or deface any street, sidewalk or alley pavement. (1978 Code § 8-2-1)
8-1-5: SNOW AND ICE DEPOSITS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or institution, other than authorized village personnel, to plow, place, or cause to be placed, deposit or
cause to be deposited, any snow or ice upon any public street or portion of any public street in the village. (1978 Code § 8-2-2-1)
8-1-6: LOCATION OF MAILBOXES IN PARKWAY AREAS:
Public parkway areas may be used for the erection of mailboxes serving the premises adjacent to said parkway; provided, that no portion of any such
mailbox shall be closer than one foot (1') from the back of the curb line of said parkway area. (1978 Code § 8-2-7)
Chapter 2
CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN RIGHTS OF WAY
8-2-1: PURPOSE; SCOPE; INTERPRETATION:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights of way within the village's jurisdiction,
which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the village rights of way and the
village as a whole.
B. Intent: In enacting this chapter, the village intends to exercise its authority over the rights of way in the village and, in particular, the use of the public
ways and property by utilities, by establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by utility facilities, including, without limitation:
1. Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places;
2. Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic;
3. Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the village utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights of way or public property;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 243/618
4. Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees, from the installation of utility facilities;
5. Protect against increased stormwater runoff due to structures and materials that increase impermeable surfaces;
6. Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are installed;
7. Preserve open space, particularly the tree lined parkways that characterize the village residential neighborhoods;
8. Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the rights of way; and
9. Assure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties adjacent to utility facilities locations.
C. Scope: This chapter applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the rights of way within the jurisdiction of the village. A
facility lawfully established prior to the effective date hereof may continue to be maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently
constructed and located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement.
D. Franchises, Licenses Or Similar Agreements:
1. The village, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of
locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the village rights of way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into
