F. Final Review; Fee: Upon completion of construction, the contractor shall notify the appropriate village department requesting final review of the work.
The contractor shall televise the completed extension in the presence of village staff who will take immediate possession of the videotape prior to
leaving the site. The village shall review the work for conformance with village requirements and adherence to the approved plans and specifications
for which the village sewer extension permit was issued. If deficiencies are found in the work, the village shall furnish the contractor with a listing of
such deficiencies. When the contractor believes that the deficiencies have been corrected, the contractor shall request a re-review of the work. Should
the re-review of the work show that the deficiencies as set forth have not been corrected, the contractor shall make the necessary corrections, and
subsequent to that, shall notify the village and request another review. The village shall charge a fee for each additional review and/or inspection after
the first inspection following the issuance of the list of deficiencies. The fee for each additional review and/or inspection is published as part of article S
of this chapter.
G. Location: All sanitary sewers shall be constructed within public rights of way or within easements dedicated for public utilities. No sanitary sewer mains
shall be installed in the rear or side yard of any property unless first approved by the village administrator.
H. Size Of Mains: Minimum sanitary sewer main size shall be eight inch (8") diameter for public sewer mains of sewer mains serving more than one
building.
I. Manholes:
1. Manholes shall be precast reinforced concrete sections meeting ASTM C-478 and ASTM C-443 standards. Manholes for sanitary sewers twenty four
inches (24") or less in diameter shall have a minimum inside diameter of forty eight inches (48"). Manholes for sanitary sewers greater than twenty
four inches (24") in diameter shall have a minimum inside diameter of sixty inches (60") and be spaced at a maximum of four hundred feet (400').
Additionally, manholes shall be installed under the following conditions: termination of existing and future lines, changes in direction (horizontal or
vertical), changes in pipe shape or pipe size, or junctions with other sewers.
2. Drop manholes shall be provided for manholes with any pipe having a difference in invert elevation more than twenty four inches (24") above the
invert of the sewer leaving the manhole. All drop manholes shall be of the external type. No internal drop manhole connections will be allowed. (Ord.
2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3B-4: COMPLETION OF PROJECT:
No connection permits shall be issued or building permits released until such time that final approval of the improvement has been made in writing by the
village. Final approval is contingent upon the following:
A. All punch list work has been completed.
B. As built plans prepared by a registered Illinois professional engineer are furnished to the village.
C. The sewer has been televised by the contractor or by the permittee in the presence of village personnel.
D. A video record of the television inspection has been provided to the village. In addition to a video record, air exfiltration testing as outlined in division III,
section 31-1.11 of the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer" shall be completed prior to acceptance. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3B-5: CONNECTION TO EXTENSION:
No connection shall be made to the sanitary sewer until sewer connection permits have been issued by the village under article C of this chapter. (Ord.
2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3B-6: PERFORMANCE BOND RELEASE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 288/618
The performance bond will not be released until the guarantee period has expired and the following documents are filed with the village engineer and
approved by the village board:
A. As built drawings: one reproducible electronic format on disk and two (2) sets of prints;
B. Release of all permits;
C. Copies of all tests required by the village engineer;
D. Bill of sale for all constructed public improvements; and
E. Such other documents as may be reasonably requested by the village. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
ARTICLE C. SEWER CONNECTION PROCEDURES
9-3C-1: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
A. Discharges Of Human And Animal Wastes: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit or allow to be deposited any human or animal
excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the village or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the village. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
B. Discharges Into Natural Outlets: It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the
village, any wastewaters without the express approval from the director of public works (DPW) that all state and federal effluent limitations have been
met and there are no reasonable alternative methods of disposal. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
C. Private Systems: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
D. Connection To Public Sewer Required: The owners of all the houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or
other purpose situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which there is now located or may in the future be located
any public sanitary sewer of the village is hereby required at their expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly
with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter within ninety (90) calendar days after date of official notice to do so;
provided that said public sewer is within one hundred feet (100') of the property line. All public sewer extensions shall be made in accordance with
article B of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-2: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
No person shall construct a private wastewater treatment facility within the corporate limits of the village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village
for the purpose of treating wastewater and discharging same to a watercourse unless the following provisions are met:
A. Nonresidential Source Wastes:
1. For the purpose of treating nonresidential source wastes, the division manager of water pollution control facilities (DMWPCF) determines that the
wastewater treatment facilities have inadequate capacity and issues a permit for the construction and operation of a wastewater treatment facility. No
village permit shall become effective until:
a. The DMWPCF has approved the plans and specifications in writing;
b. Approval has been obtained from the county department of health;
c. An IEPA permit issued to construct the facility has been received;
d. An IEPA NPDES permit to operate the facility has been issued and received;
e. The installation is completed to the satisfaction of the DMWPCF; and
f. The final inspection has been completed.
2. Persons operating a private wastewater treatment facility shall file copies of all operating reports sent to the USEPA and IEPA with the DMWPCF
and such other reports as the DMWPCF deems necessary.
B. Subsurface Absorption Facilities:
1. If a public sewer is not available under the provisions of section 9-3C-1 of this article and the wastewater source to be treated is domestic in nature,
the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system employing subsurface absorption facilities.
2. No person shall construct a private wastewater treatment facility with subsurface disposal without previous approval from the DMWPCF. If approval
is given, the person must adhere to the following limitations:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 289/618
a. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by a DMWPCF.
The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the village which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications
and other information as deemed necessary by the village. A permit and inspection fee as set out in article S of this chapter or reimbursement of
costs shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. The permit shall not be issued until applicable state and county permits are on
file with the village.
b. The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all regulations and provisions of the state of Illinois
private sewage disposal licensing act and code, with the state of Illinois environmental protection agency and the county health department, as
appropriate, latest revision. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where
the area of the lot is less than forty thousand (40,000) square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet.
c. A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the village. The
village shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the village when
the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within two (2) village
workdays of the receipt of written notice by the village; except, that no inspections will be made at any time other than regular village working
hours. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
C. Grinder Pump Systems:
1. General Requirements: If gravity sewers and conventional sewer systems are not practical, the village administrator may approve grinder pump
systems on a discretionary case by case basis. In order to implement a grinder pump system, a developer or individual homeowner must prove to
the village that a grinder pump system is the only viable option as determined by the village administrator. A permit and inspection fee as set forth in
article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. A permit for a private wastewater treatment facility employing a
grinder pump system shall not be issued until the design and installation is completed to the satisfaction of the village administrator. (Ord. 2009-57,
10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
2. Inspections: The village shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify
the village administrator when the grinder pump system is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered.
3. Operation And Maintenance: The DMWPCF or his designee shall be entitled to inspect the grinder pump system if said DMWPCF has any reason to
believe that the grinder pump system is not operating properly or pursuant to a routine inspection protocol developed by the DMWPCF. Should the
grinder pump system fall into disrepair or otherwise need maintenance as determined by the village, and the owner refuses to repair, replace or
otherwise fix the grinder pump system to the specifications of the village, the village may do so at its own expense and obtain reimbursement from
the individual owner. In that regard, and as a condition of obtaining a village permit for a grinder pump system, the individual owner shall enter into a
contractual agreement indemnifying the village for any costs the village may incur with regard to maintaining the grinder pump system and further,
allow the village reasonable access to the grinder pump system for inspection purposes.
D. Operation Of Private System: The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times and at no
expense to the village.
E. Connection To Public Sewer When Available: As provided in subsection 9-3C-1D of this article, at such time as a public sewer becomes available to a
property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within ninety (90) calendar days in
compliance with this chapter. Any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with
suitable material such as clean bank run gravel or dirt.
F. Additional Requirements: No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by
the county department of health or any other governmental body having jurisdiction, as appropriate. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-3: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
A. Permit Requirements:
1. Permit To Connect:
a. Permit Required:
(1) No person shall construct a new wastewater source or alter, repair or reconstruct an existing source and connect same to the wastewater
treatment works of the village without first obtaining a written permit from the village. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
(2) No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance
thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the village department of community development, with sign off by the director of public works
(DPW) and receipt of an IEPA permit when required under 35 Illinois administrative code 309. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code; Ord.
2014-15, 3-20-2014)
(3) No connection to, addition to or alteration of any building sewer shall be made or caused to be made by any person without a permit from the
DPW. Such connections, additions or alterations shall only be made through a licensed sewer contractor. No permit shall authorize anything not
explicitly stated in the application. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
b. Classes Of Permits; Application And Fee:
(1) There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits:
(A) Residential user; and
(B) Nonresidential user which includes commercial, institutional, and industrial facilities or other nonresidential sources. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-
2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 290/618
(2) Application shall be made on a form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by plans, specifications, and other
information considered necessary in the judgment of the director of community development and/or the DPW. A permit and inspection fee as set
forth in article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code; Ord.
2014-15, 3-20-2014)
c. Information Required: Persons desiring to construct a new waste source and connect it to the wastewater treatment works of the village shall state
the quantity, quality and rate of discharge into the public sewer. A nonresidential user, as a condition of permit authorization, shall also provide
information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics and type of activity per section 9-3D-1 of this chapter.
d. Conditions Of Permit: A building sewer permit shall only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the
downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to
adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load based on the population equivalent.
e. Term Of Permit: The building sewer connection permit shall be issued for a period of twenty four (24) months consistent with the IEPA permits.
2. Building Permit: The user shall secure a building permit if the waste source is new equipment to be installed in an existing building with an existing
sewer.
3. Excavation Permit: Each excavation for any of the purposes set out in this subsection shall require a separate connection permit.
4. Revocation Of Permit: Any permit issued in this section may be revoked as per article M of this chapter and other appropriate articles of this chapter.
(Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
B. Building Sewer Connections:
1. Separate Building Sewers Required: A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except, that where one building
stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley,
court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building
sewer and may be done only with the written authorization of the DPW.
2. Use Of Existing Sewers: An existing building sewer may be used in connection with a new building only when it is found, on examination and test by
the village engineer or DPW or his designee, to meet all requirements of this article. All costs and expenses for this examination shall be paid by the
applicant as set forth in article S of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
3. Specifications:
a. The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing,
testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations
of the village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of
the American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation Manual Of Practice No. 9", and "Standard Specifications For Water
And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois" shall apply. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
b. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet (3') of any bearing wall. No building sewer shall be installed in any place where it may
be subject to freezing temperatures unless adequate provisions are made to protect it from frost. Changes in direction shall be made only with
properly curbed pipe and fittings, or a manhole, as determined by the DPW. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
c. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewers, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall
be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. Where possible, all building sanitary services shall be "overhead"
installations. Buildings having basements shall have a pump or ejector provided to pump the wastewater to the building sewer for gravity transport
to the public sewer. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
d. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the branch fitting, if such is available at the suitable location. If the
public sewer is twelve inches (12") in diameter or less and no properly located branch fitting is available, the applicant shall, at its expense, install
a branch fitting in the public sewer at the location specified and an installation approved by the DPW. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-
15, 3-20-2014)
C. Conditions Of Construction: Construction of a building sewer connection shall not be started until fees are paid consistent with section 9-3C-4 of this
article and a written building sewer connection permit is issued by the village after issuance and receipt of an IEPA permit for the project when
applicable. The following conditions are also required: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
1. Street Opening Permit Required: The applicant shall secure a street opening permit from the community development department in conformance
with the provisions of this code. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
2. Excavations To Be Guarded And Restored: All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so
as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a
manner satisfactory to the village administrator. Failure to properly barricade shall be cause for the construction site to be shut down, and a fee as
provided in article S of this chapter shall be paid before any further work can commence. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
3. Notice Of Inspection; Supervised Connection: The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the community development department two (2)
village workdays prior to the start of any underground piping installation and when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the
public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of a qualified duly authorized agent of the village during regular village working
hours. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
4. Size And Materials: Minimum building sewer size shall be six inch (6") diameter. All cleanouts shall be installed on the owner's property and not in
village rights of way. The maximum distance between cleanouts shall be one hundred twenty feet (120'). The building sewer shall be constructed
using any of the following listed materials:
a. Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe and fittings with solvent welded joints or compression type rubber ring gasket joints, conforming to the latest
revision of ASTM specification D3034-SDR 35, installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations;
b. Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) sewer pipe and fittings with solvent welded joints or compression type rubber ring gasket joints, conforming
to the latest revision of ASTM specification D2751, installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 291/618
c. Type 1 asbestos-cement nonpressure small diameter sewer pipe and fittings class 3300 with compression type rubber ring gaskets and coupling
joints, conforming to the latest revision of ASTM specification C644, installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations; or
d. Extra heavy cast iron soil pipe and fittings conforming to the latest revision of CISPI specifications HS-67 with compression type rubber ring gasket
joints, conforming to the latest revision of ASTM specification C564, installed in accordance with the latest revision of the Illinois state plumbing
code. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
5. Connection Restrictions: Building sewers shall not be connected to manholes. All building sewers serving single-family residences shall have "blind"
connections to the public sewer. The only exception to this requirement is when homes are located in a cul-de-sac and the blind connection to the
public sewer would be impractical. This exception must be approved by the community development department prior to construction. (Ord. 2009-57,
10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
6. Sewer Beds: All building sewers shall be bedded on a layer of gravel or crushed stone, size no. 67, conforming to the latest revision of STM
specification D448, to provide a minimum thickness of four inches (4") under and extending to the top of the pipe.
D. Uses Outside Corporate Limits: No new permit shall be issued for the tapping into or use of wastewater treatment works under the jurisdiction of the
village for any location outside of the corporate limits of the village but within one hundred feet (100') of the public sewer unless an agreement written
by the village board and the party seeking connection to the sewer system is executed.
E. Building Sewer Connection Acceptance:
1. A one year warranty shall be submitted to the village by the contractor doing the building sewer installation against all defects including poor
workmanship, improper installation, or material failure. The warranty shall require the contractor to correct any problems with the installation
occurring during the one year period.
2. A video recording shall be required of the entire length of the building sewer from the building to the public sewer including the connection into the
public sewer. The video shall be in a format readily viewable by the village. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
F. Costs And Expenses Of Installation And Connection; Licensed Contractor Requirements: All costs and expenses incident to the installation and
connection of the building sewer shall be paid by the applicant. The person installing the building sewer for the owner shall be a licensed plumber or
sewer contractor and shall indemnify the village from loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by said installation. Before a building
sewer permit is issued, the plumber or sewer contractor shall file with the village clerk an indemnity bond in the amount as provided in section 4-4-2 of
this code, with corporate surety licensed to do business in the state of Illinois, on a bond approved by the village administrator. In addition, the plumber
or sewer contractor shall file with the village clerk a certificate of insurance covering public liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00) to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) covering property
damage. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
9-3C-4: FEES:
The following types of fees shall be charged when permitting and constructing a new source of wastewater and connecting it to the wastewater treatment
works of the village. All review, inspection and connection fees shall be based upon the current fees as set forth in article S of this chapter and shall be
reviewed and updated annually.
A. Review And Connection Fee: A review and connection fee for the building sewer connection permit shall be paid to the village at the time the residential
application is filed. Nonresidential user fees shall be on an individual case basis, measured by the impact on the current facility and current capacity,
coupled with the water meter size as defined in article S of this chapter. A minimum sewer connection fee shall be established for any nonresidential
users at four (4) population equivalents (PE). The review and connection fee includes the first inspection required for a service. A separate review fee
may be charged based on the cost and expense to review equalization and/or pretreatment facilities required at a nonresidential user site.
B. Additional Inspection Fees: Additional inspection fees shall be paid for any additional inspections. Additional inspections include, but are not limited to,
inspections of sampling manholes, flow metering or sampling equipment, garbage grinders, grease, oil and sand interceptors, and grease traps. Fees
for inspections of equalization and pretreatment facilities shall be paid for based on the cost and expense to conduct the inspection. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-
1-2009)
C. Connection Fees Involving Extra Strength Wastewater; PE Determination:
1. The DPW may require nonresidential users to provide to the DPW concentrations and flow rates of wastewater discharged to the wastewater
treatment works. Flow rate averages shall be calculated based on the number of actual days discharged. For wastewater, the strength of which
exceeds residential wastewater in any constituent, the fees shall be based as follows: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
a. A PE connection fee shall be calculated on the basis of the impact on a treatment works as the equivalent of the highest PE of the three (3)
parameters: flow, BOD5 or TSS. Any increase in PE will be added to the baseline PE of the property.
b. In the event that the wastewater exhibits a ratio of COD to BOD5 that is greater than 3, the BOD5 PE will be calculated on the basis of 0.33 of the
COD value.
c. The difference between the PE connection fee and the wastewater connection fee based on water meter size in article S of this chapter shall be
identified as the strength connection fee. In the event that the PE connection fee is larger than the water meter size based connection fee, the
strength connection fee will be added to the water meter size connection fee.
2. When the volume and strength of the wastewater to be discharged to the public sewer is not known at the time of the connection, the fee shall be
estimated and adjusted to reflect actual conditions during the billing period after a full year of operation.
3. The volume and strength of the wastewater for fee purposes shall be based on the maximum workday discharge of constituents. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-
1-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 292/618
4. When a connection is made based on the applicant's statement that the strength of the wastewater does not exceed residential wastewater in any
constituent, and at the end of the billing period, after a full year of operation, it is determined that the wastewater does exceed residential wastewater
in strength, the DPW may accept or reject the wastewater and back charge the user for fees plus penalties for the extra strength wastewater or have
the service disconnected.
5. The DPW may review nonresidential user flows and loadings on an intermittent frequency to identify increases to the baseline PE. The DPW shall
bill the nonresidential user, for increases to the baseline PE, a connection fee as set forth in article S of this chapter. Upon payment of the fee, the
current site baseline PE shall be adjusted to the newly established site baseline PE. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
D. Properties Outside Corporate Limits: The connection fee for any use not located within the corporate limits of the village that has been previously
grandfathered but has not yet connected shall be two (2) times the applicable connection fee as set forth in article S of this chapter combined with the
strength determination.
E. Review Of And Updating Fees: All review, inspection and connection fees are set forth in article S of this chapter and may be reviewed and updated
from time to time. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-5: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS:
A. It shall be unlawful to discharge or cause to be discharged to the wastewater treatment works of the village, any substance, without having first
complied with the terms of this chapter. At minimum, all users are subject to the prohibited discharge standards in section 9-3E-2 of this chapter,
change notification in section 9-3I-7 of this chapter, and hazardous waste notification in section 9-3I-10 of this chapter, if applicable. Spill/slug control
planning may also be necessary for some nonresidential users as identified in section 9-3F-4 of this chapter.
B. No user shall connect roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building drain
or building sewer which in turn connects directly or indirectly to a public sewer. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-6: MONITORING FACILITIES:
The inspection fee(s) provided in section 9-3C-4 of this article shall be paid to the village prior to issuance of the building sewer connection permit if the
village determines that the user is required to install any of the following structures: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
A. Sampling Manhole:
1. Required; Exemptions:
a. All users located in areas zoned industrial and such other users as required by the DPW, except residential users, are required to install a
monitoring manhole for each separate discharge in the building sewer in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the DPW.
b. The DPW may determine subclasses of businesses that do not require the installation of a sampling manhole; provided, however, sampling
manholes shall be required in zoned business or industrial parks. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
2. Location:
a. Each manhole shall be situated on the user's premises in an easement dedicated to the village.
b. The sampling manhole shall be located on the sewer connection pipe at a point where there are no changes in grade or alignment for at least
fifteen (15) pipe diameters upstream and downstream from the manhole. The grade (slope) of the pipe shall not exceed one percent (1%) (1 foot
per 100 feet) through the manhole and for a distance of fifteen (15) pipe diameters upstream and downstream from the manhole. (Ord. 2009-57,
10-1-2009)
c. Where such a sampling manhole location would be impractical or cause extreme hardship on the user, the DPW may permit the sampling manhole
to be constructed in the public right of way, provided the sampling manhole is located so that it shall not be obstructed by landscaping or parked
vehicles. If a sampling manhole is located in a parking lot, a permanent barricade, such as a vertical pipe, shall be placed around the sampling
manhole to prevent vehicles from driving or parking over the sampling manhole cover. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
3. Ample Room For Sampling: There shall be ample room in or near such sampling manhole to allow accurate sampling and preparation of samples for
analysis.
4. Responsibilities Of Owner/User: The manhole shall be installed and maintained by the owner and/or user at its sole cost and expense and shall be
safe and accessible to the authorized agents of the village at all times. The failure of a user to keep its monitoring facility in good working order shall
not be grounds for the user to claim that sample results are not representative of its discharge. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
5. Postponement Of Installation:
a. The DPW may postpone the installation of the sampling manhole when specific circumstances (e.g., weather) prevent the installation of a
manhole.
b. A postponement for a sampling manhole shall be handled on a case by case basis by the DPW when it is determined that the discharge is solely
from a residential source and the site is not in a zoned business park/industrial area.
c. When a postponement for a sampling manhole installation is granted by the DPW, an affidavit shall be signed by the property owner indicating that
the sampling manhole shall be installed at a later date should business practices change at the location. The affidavit for sampling manhole
installation postponement may be recorded by the village against the property.
B. Liquid Quantity Measurements:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 293/618
1. All significant industrial users may be required to install an open channel flow measuring device in said sampling manhole. When required, the
sampling chamber shall contain a Palmer-Bowlus or Parshall flume or equivalent, unless a weir or similar device is approved by the DPW. (Ord.
2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
2. The village may, at its option, based on the water usage and/or waste loadings, require the user to install a device with a recording and totalizing
register for measurement of the liquid quantity. The device shall include a recorder suitable to display seven (7) calendar days of flow at a time. The
equipment required to indicate, record and totalize the flow shall be located in a warm, dry location and be accessible to the village for reading. This
equipment shall be installed and maintained by the user at its sole cost and expense. The user shall complete installation of the flume and secondary
flow measuring device based on the installation schedule approved for such device by the village.
3. The user shall be required to calibrate and maintain the flow metering equipment in accordance with the manufacturer's recommended procedures
and frequencies. Users who operate flow measuring devices shall submit the procedure for operation and maintenance (O&M) to the pretreatment
coordinator. The user shall further document O&M in a log which shall be available for inspection by authorized agents of the village. At a minimum,
the user shall submit a semiannual calibration report performed by an outside representative by the deadline defined in the user's discharge permit.
The user may be required to submit flow records to the pretreatment coordinator monthly.
C. Sampling Equipment:
1. The village may, at its option, based on water usage and/or waste loadings or when the waste loads cannot be accurately evaluated by time
composite samples, require the user to install sampling equipment. This equipment shall be installed and maintained by the user at its sole cost and
expense.
2. Users shall submit the procedure for operation and maintenance to the pretreatment coordinator. The user shall further document O&M in a log
which shall be available for inspection by duly authorized agents of the village. At minimum, the user shall submit an annual report confirming the
accurate operation of the equipment performed by an outside representative by the deadline defined in the discharge permit. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-
2009)
9-3C-7: ADDITIONAL STRUCTURES REQUIRED:
A. Garbage Grinders; Interceptors; Neutralizing Basins: Inspection fee(s) as provided in section 9-3C-4 of this article and set forth in article S of this
chapter shall be paid to the village prior to issuance of the building sewer connection permit should it be determined that the user is required to install
any of the following structures: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
1. Garbage Grinders: Garbage shall be properly shredded prior to discharge to the public sewer. Wastes classified as properly shredded garbage
contain all particles being carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch
(1/2") (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4)
horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to review and approval by the community development department. Garbage grinders are
prohibited to be connected to a grease interceptor. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
2. Grease, Oil, And Sand Interceptors: Interceptors shall be provided in facilities connected to the public sewer where it is determined by the DPW that
they are necessary for the proper handling of wastewater that contains excessive amounts of grease, oil, and sand; except, that such interceptors
shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interception units shall be of type and capacity approved by the community
development department and shall be so located to be easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Oil and sand interceptors used for petroleum
grease and oils may be located inside the building. Such interceptors shall be inspected, cleaned and repaired regularly, as needed, by the user at its
sole cost and expense. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code; Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
3. Neutralizing Basins:
a. Laboratory and facilities commonly using acid or alkaline chemicals or compounds shall install a neutralizing basin to treat process wastewater
prior to the discharge to the public sewer. All basins shall be of type and capacity approved by the community development department and shall
be so located to be easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
b. Equipment and devices installed under this section are not defined as pretreatment facilities for wastewater. Any user operating devices installed
pursuant to this section shall submit operating data as may be required by the DPW.
B. Equalization And Pretreatment Of Equipment Or Facilities:
1. Review fee(s) as provided in section 9-3C-4 of this article and set forth in article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village prior to issuance of the
building sewer connection permit if it is determined that the user is required to install equipment or facilities for equalization or pretreatment of
wastewater. The design and installation of such equalization and pretreatment equipment or facilities shall be subject to the review and approval of
the DPW and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, chapters and laws. The DPW shall require the user to submit the equalization and
pretreatment equipment to IEPA for its approval consistent with IEPA regulations or issuance of a written determination that a permit is not needed.
(Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
2. Inspection fee(s) as provided in section 9-3C-4 of this article and set forth in article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village after the inspection is
completed based on cost and expenses.
3. All equalization and pretreatment equipment or facilities shall be properly maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the user
at its sole cost and expense. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-8: SEWER LINE MAINTENANCE AND REPLACEMENT:
A. Responsibilities Of Owner: The owner is responsible for the maintenance and repair of all building sewer lines, including the tap into the public sewer,
located on its property which connect directly or indirectly to the public sewer.
B. Excavations In Public Ways:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 294/618
1. In those instances when an owner has to excavate the building sewer for maintenance and replacement, and as a result, the sidewalk, curb and
street have been removed or damaged, the property owner shall be responsible for the restoration of the sidewalk, curb and street (surface and
subsurface).
2. In those instances where subsection B1 of this section is involved, tunneling under the curb and sidewalk whenever practical is recommended.
Sidewalk and curb must be cut when removal is required.
C. Compliance Required; Inspections: All work, as it is related to the replacement and/or repair of the building sewer, shall be in conformance with all
village codes and shall be inspected by a duly authorized agent of the village during the repair and replacement. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
9-3C-9: FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS:
Food service establishments (FSE) shall comply with the following requirements: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
A. Grease Traps And Interceptors:
1. General Requirements: Grease traps and interceptors (collectively referred to as grease interceptors or GI) shall be installed in all new FSE. All GI
shall be of a type and capacity approved by the DPW based on an evaluation of the volume and characteristics of the discharge in conjunction with
the operating plan of the FSE. The DPW may require GI to be installed or modified in an existing FSE where said FSE has caused or contributed to
overflows and/or blockages in a public sewer, or at an existing FSE that significantly remodels its site, or when streetscapes or street/sewer
replacements are installed. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
2. Location: All GI shall be easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All GI shall be located on the exterior to the building for all new construction
and, when feasible, at an existing FSE. The GI shall not be located in drive-through lanes. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
3. Sizing: Each FSE GI shall be sized using a formula provided by the DPW so that it shall continuously produce an effluent containing less than the
guideline limit of fats, oils and grease (FOG) as provided by section 9-3E-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
4. Inspection Fee: An inspection fee as provided by section 9-3C-4 of this article and set forth in article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village prior
to issuance of the permit. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
5. Maintenance: Such grease traps shall be inspected, the grease cap and solids blanket cleaned every three (3) months, and the entire contents of the
trap cleaned annually and repaired regularly, as needed, by the owner and/or user at its sole cost and expense. It shall be the responsibility of the
FSE to inspect its GI during the pumping procedure to ensure the trap is properly cleaned out and that all fittings and fixtures inside the trap are in
working condition and functioning properly. In the event that actual operations of the GI fail to produce results that consistently prevent prohibitive
discharges as defined in section 9-3E-2 of this chapter, the owner and/or user of the FSE shall have the GI cleaned at a more frequent rate, as
determined by the DPW, or install additional pretreatment as necessary.
6. Modifications: The DPW may make determinations of GI adequacy, need, design, appropriateness, application, location, modification(s), and
conditional usage based on review of all relevant information regarding GI performance, facility site and building plan review by all regulatory
reviewing agencies and may require repairs to or modification or replacement of the GI. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
7. Permit Required: All FSE are required to be issued a general permit as provided by articles G and H of this chapter.
B. Grease Interceptor Criteria: GI installed at new and existing FSE must meet the following criteria: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
1. Size: The size shall be determined by a formula that is approved by the DPW. The minimum capacity of any one unit shall be five hundred (500)
gallons, and the maximum capacity shall be one thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons. Where sufficient capacity cannot be achieved with a single
unit, installation of GI in series shall be required. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
2. Twenty Five Percent Requirement: The GI shall provide for a minimum hydraulic retention time of twenty four (24) minutes at actual peak flow
between the influent and effluent baffles, with twenty five percent (25%) of the total volume of the GI being allowed for any food derived solids to
settle or accumulate and floatable grease derived materials to rise and accumulate, identified as a solids blanket and grease cap, respectively.
3. Access Manholes: Access manholes, with a minimum diameter of twenty four inches (24"), shall be provided over each exterior GI chamber and
each sanitary tee. The access manholes shall extend at least to finished grade and be designed and maintained to prevent water inflow or infiltration.
The manholes shall have readily removable covers to facilitate inspection, grease removal, and wastewater sampling activities.
4. Prohibitions: Dishwashers and food waste disposal units shall not be connected to or discharged into any GI. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
C. Waivers: Waivers available to FSE are set forth below. A request for a waiver is required to be filed with the DPW on a form provided by the village, and
a waiver review fee as set forth in article S of this chapter shall be paid to the village at the time of the filing. Waiver requests are not considered to be
filed until the request has been reviewed and determined complete. If the DPW fails to act on a completed waiver request within forty five (45) calendar
days, a request for waiver shall be deemed to be denied. The issuance of a waiver does not eliminate the requirement to prevent prohibitive discharges
through alternate technologies and best management plan practices.
1. Existing External FSE GI Installation Waiver: The requirement to install and to properly operate and maintain a GI is conditionally stayed by the
DPW. Terms and conditions for the waiver issued for a GI installation shall be set forth in a permit. The terms may include the requirement to install
grease trap(s) inside the FSE, alternate technology and/or the use of best management practices. The waiver shall not apply to any existing FSE that
has not operated as an FSE for the last twelve (12) consecutive months prior to November 1, 2009. Such FSE shall be required to install a GI in
order to operate an FSE in the village.
2. Common GI Waiver: "Common GI" means one or more interceptors receiving FOG laden wastewater from more than one FSE. Common
interceptors may be used in lieu of an individual GI at each FSE, provided a waiver has been issued by the DPW. A common GI may be located at
shopping centers, malls, entertainment complexes, sporting arenas, hotels, multitenant "flex" spaces, mixed use spaces, and other sites where
multiple establishments are connected to a single GI. The owner of the property on which the common GI is located shall be responsible for
operation and maintenance of the common GI including program documentation, upkeep, and repair. In such cases, a permit will be issued to the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=688 295/618
owner of the property for the GI, and general permits will also be issued to each FSE connected to the common GI that contains best management
practices requirements.
3. Limited Food Preparation Establishments GI Installation Waiver: Waivers for installations at FSE with only a snack bar with no food preparation other
than food warming will be handled on a case by case basis by the DPW and are deemed to be limited food preparation establishments.
4. Constraint Waivers At Existing FSE:
a. Where the installation of a GI is not feasible and no equivalent alternative pretreatment can be installed, a waiver from the installation of the GI
requirement may be granted. The DPW determination to grant the waiver shall be based upon, but not limited to, evaluation of the following
conditions: (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
(1) There is no adequate space for installation and/or maintenance of a GI;
(2) There is no adequate slope for gravity flow between the kitchen plumbing fixtures and the GI and/or between the GI and the private collection
lines or public sewer; and
(3) The use of alternative pretreatment technology is not possible that is equally effective in controlling the FOG discharge.
b. If a constraint waiver is granted, a grease disposal mitigation fee as set forth in the FSE fees in article S of this chapter shall be imposed. (Ord.
2009-57, 10-1-2009)
5. Alternate Technology Waiver: The use of an automatic grease removal system is permissible only upon the written approval of the DPW, the
plumbing inspector of the village, and the county health department. Approval of the technology shall be based on empirical data acceptable to the
DPW demonstrating removal efficiencies and reliability of operation. The DPW may approve these types of technologies dependent on
manufacturer's specifications on a case by case basis. The DPW shall require in a permit that any user of an alternate technology shall attain a
grease wastewater discharge limit, as measured from the unit's outlet. Any user utilizing an alternative technology may be subject to additional
operational requirements imposed by the DPW.
6. Cleaning Cycle Waiver: The FSE may petition the DPW to reduce the cleaning and servicing of the GI from every three (3) months to a maximum of
every six (6) months upon demonstration that the amount removed every three (3) months is significantly less than the twenty five percent (25%) rule
for the basin capacity and the discharge does not exceed the oil and grease local limit. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-15, 3-20-2014)
9-3C-10: AUTOMOBILE SERVICE, REPAIR AND FUEL DISPENSING PROPERTIES:
A. Sampling Manhole: Any user involved with automotive repair or the handling, sale and dispensing of petroleum products and/or automotive fluids shall
install a sampling manhole consistent with the requirements of section 9-3C-6 of this article. All such sampling manholes of this type shall be monitored
throughout the year in a manner prescribed by the pretreatment coordinator. Additionally, any user involved in the repair or servicing of automobiles,
trucks, or engine powered equipment shall install a triple basin oil separator in the sanitary line (per state of Illinois plumbing codes) servicing the repair
area(s) of its building. The system shall be cleaned, serviced and inspected at least four (4) times per year at the owner's sole cost and expense. The
user may petition the pretreatment coordinator to reduce the cleaning and servicing of the triple basin oil separator to two (2) times per year upon
demonstration that the amount removed quarterly is significantly less than the twenty five percent (25%) rule for the basin capacity and the discharge
does not exceed the oil and grease local limit. The pretreatment coordinator may require the system to be cleaned at a more frequent rate if the
discharge requirements cannot be met.
B. Separate Drainage System: When property use involves automotive repair or the handling, sale and dispensing of petroleum products and/or
automotive fluids, there shall be a separate drainage system constructed to collect all fluids from all areas associated with pump islands and under
pump canopies. The separate drainage system shall collect these fluids and hold them in a separate sealed tank for testing and removal by approved
special waste handling methods. All fuel dispensing equipment, piping and venting shall be installed in accordance with the standards listed below and
be in accordance and in compliance with all village codes and the following provisions:
1. "Guidance Manual For LUST Cleanups In Illinois", September 1989; and "Leaking Underground Storage Tank Manual", September 1991; both
published by IEPA, 2200 Churchill Road, P.O. Box 19276, Springfield, IL 62794-9276.
2. "Recommended Practices For Installation Of Underground Liquid Storage Systems", PEI/RP 100, 1994; published by Petroleum Equipment Institute,
P.O. Box 2380, Tulsa, OK 74101.
3. "Flammable And Combustible Liquid Code", NFPA/30, 1993; "Automotive And Marine Services Station Code", NFPA/30A, 1993; "National Electric
Code", NFPA/70, 1993; and "Underground Leakage Of Flammable And Combustible Liquids", NFPA/329, 1992; all published by National Fire
Protection Association, 1 Batterymarch Park, P.O. Box 9101, Quincy, MA 02269-9904.
4. "Underground Storage Tanks; Technical Requirements And State Program Approval; Final Rules", 40 CFR parts 280 and 281, part II, Federal
Register, Friday, September 23, 1988; and "Musts For USTs: A Summary Of The New Regulations For Underground Storage Tank Systems, And
Hazardous Waste Management Standards", Federal Register, July 14, 1986, both published by USEPA, Office Of Underground Storage Tanks, 401
M Street S.W., Washington, DC 20460.
5. "Rules Of The Illinois State Fire Marshall", parts 170 and 180, title 41, chapter 1, state of Illinois, office of the fire marshal, 1035 Stevenson Parkway,
Springfield, IL 62703.
C. Application Of Provisions:
1. The requirements of this section shall be met by any property use involving automotive repair or the handling, sale or dispensing of petroleum
products and/or automotive fluids where any water main, wastewater or stormwater facility is under the jurisdiction of the village, regardless of
whether or not such property lies within the corporate limits of the village.
2. The requirements of this section shall not apply to property uses involving automotive repair or the handling, sale or dispensing of petroleum
products and/or automotive fluids existing on November 1, 2009; except, when a permit is required for new construction or reconstruction of a
property use associated with or a discharge has occurred that does not meet the local limits or a blockage has been caused or contributed to,
compliance with the provisions of this section shall be required. (Ord. 2009-57, 10-1-2009)
